column8: postContent

Slide of the Week

Being a patient is hard.  Providing care is hard. 

Neither should be, but when we couple rapid fire scientific breakthroughs with ever more complex healthcare systems and insurance benefit design, we turn what should be the most humane, compassionate industry out there into a source of frustration. Unintentionally, we compound the suffering caused by illness with the suffering caused by an incomprehensible healthcare ecosystem.  Good people and good care can help the former, but we need to fix our system to help the latter.  We need to streamline complexity and simplify health. 

Focusing on the basics is the right place to start.  For patients, that means being able to find care, access care, and navigate care.  My favorite slide for this week is all about finding care.  Back when I started in practice, patients found the right doctor to help them by referrals from family, friends, or another clinician.  Last year for the first time, our Press Ganey data showed the #1 way patients found care was on-line. 

My doctor friends, this means making sure your on-line profile and presence reflects who you are and what you do.  For patients to find you, you need to make sure your story is out there.  And reviews count.  A lot.  Patients won't see docs rated less than 4 stars.  Make sure all those patients that love you review you, not just the few that are unhappy. 

My health plan and health system friends - focus on that digital front door.  Those provider directories really matter. Patients count on those lists of affiliated/participating clinicians, including the phone numbers and addresses.  It's amazing how often those are out of date or simply wrong. And help docs get reviews on line.  The more reviews each provider has, the more trustworthy the data they convey. 

Helping patients find, access, and navigate the care they need is simple to describe but hard to execute; ensuring patients can easily find the care they need is step one.   Don't our patients deserve that? 

Pranav Desai Chrissy Daniels Thomas Lee, MD Chris Skiffington Zeev Neuwirth, MD Estee Neuwirth Susan Mullaney Kristy LoRusso Jason Mitchell, M.D. Christopher Cornue David Shapiro Dan Litwer Sara Vaezy Michael Myint Susan (Sue) Brandenburg Darren Dworkin

Good morning.Â We just passed through Ft. Scott, Kansas. 

The good news.Â We are more than halfway, having biked more than 1750 of the 3041 miles. 

Tuesday night into Wednesday morning was a low point.Â After making great progress, we faced brutal conditions in western Kansasâ€”rain and strong, 20-30 mile headwinds.Â For bikers, headwinds are a weight both physically and mentally.Â It is like running with a 40-point backpack strapped to your back.Â A tough uphill eventually ends; headwinds can last for days.Â When I went to sleep Tuesday night, I had real doubts about whether we could make it.Â We were exhausted and feeling down.Â Tempers were short.Â Several other Race Across America racers and teams dropped out in Kansas, defeated by the wind. 

After 20 or so hours of difficult conditions, miraculously, the weather cooled, the winds stopped and a giant Midwest storm capable of tornadoes passed in front of us. 

Our crew of Tim, Jack (17), and Tucker (15) Punke, and I, took over our shift at around 1 p.m. on Wednesday afternoon about 100 miles west of Wichita, Kansas, and rode around 225 miles toward the Missouri border.Â The ride was glorious with one exception - a flat tire.Â Since we could not stop, for the first time in my life, I changed a tire in the back seat, enabling me to take a last shift at 3:30 a.m.Â We rolled into a $57 per night roadside at 5:30 a.m.Â A 17-hour shift was long, but it was a beautiful, moonlit night with relatively cool weather. While Tim was out on a long shift, we all stopped at Subway for a sandwich, the best meal we have had since starting.Â For the rest of the time, we have lived on salami and cheese on tortillas, bars, and energy gel.Â We slept from 6-10 a.m. and then hit the road again, meeting up with the crew which is currently biking toward Jefferson City, Missouri.

We face two major challenges going forward, in addition to exhaustion: hills and heat. As we move into Missouri, we go deeper and deeper into the heat dome that has built over the eastern United States.Â Humidity will exceed 90%.Â We are using "ice socks"â€”pantyhose filled with ice that we ride with stuffed into our bike shirts.Â One might intuitively conclude that the major elevation gains lie in the westâ€”the southern Sierras, the climb out of the desert to Flagstaff, and the Rocky Mountains.Â As we enter eastern Missouri, Illinois, and Ohio, we will face a series of 500-1000-foot "rollers".Â But when we get to West Virginia and Western Maryland, we will encounter endless 1000-2000 foot ups and downs. 

Our crew: AU grads Natalie Oliver and Inken Ehlers have been amazing, keeping the RV and truck going, handling logistics, and keeping us going.Â They have tireless energy, and boundless enthusiasm and have shared an unforgettable experience crossing the United States.Â So far, 104 donors have given more than $35,000 in scholarships. Let's keep it going! Inken Ehlers Natalie Oliver Timothy Punke Lori Otto Punke Brian Pomper

Did you happen to notice a minor adjustment to the setting on your Wi-Fi thermostat last week? Itâ€™s what we call â€œDemand Responseâ€ in the wonky and technical energy community. On hot humid days like weâ€™ve been having, demand on the electric grid is significant. For those signed up for our ConnectedSolutions demand response program, small adjustments are made to the thermostat for a couple of hours to reduce demand on the grid. 

Last week Amy Findlay, P.E. and her team were hard at work overseeing this choreography. The chart below shows what happened on Thursday, when along with utilities across New England, we were able to drop the peak by 300 MW during the three-hour peak energy event timeframe â€“ equivalent to powering approximately 200,000 homes. Amy and her team are already delivering on the vision for Virtual Power Plants. 

#VirtualPowerPlants #VPPs #Decarbonization #DemandResponse

Still on a high from an incredible week of Cannes.  The week is as much about celebrating the inspiring work and people in this industry as it is about learning from one another catching up with career-long friends and colleagues.  Highlights included...

Speaking with the incredible women at the The Female Quotient Equality Lounge to discuss how  brands are authentically connecting with audiences and driving conversations globally alongside Kellyn Smith Kenny, Chief Marketing and Growth Officer, AT&T, Inc., Maggie Schmerin, Chief Advertising Officer, United Airlines, Jess Spaulding, Chief Marketing Officer, PepsiCo Foods Canada, and Tammy Henault, Chief Marketing Officer, NBA.

Having the privilege of talking with Myles Garrett of the Cleveland Browns and US soccer legend Megan Rapinoe about the power of athletes as creators at Stagwell's awesome Sport Beach.

Keynoting the Young Lions kick-off, watching the next generation of the creative community on the precipice of their brilliant careers.

Speaking with the legendary Jim Stengel, Emily Ketchen, CMO of Lenovo, and Menaka Gopinath, CMO of the Project Management Institute, about the unique challenges facing Chief Marketing Officers -- or "Change Management Officers" -- at this point in time.

Chatting with Laura Desmond, CEO of Smartly, Angela Ruggiero, Co-Founder of the Sports Innovation Lab, Thayer Lavielle, EVP of The Collective at Wasserman, Lina Polimeni, Chief Brand Officer at Eli Lilly and Company, and LSU's dominant basketball player Flaujae Johnson about the power and opportunity for brands in women's sports.  (Side note, not only is Flaujae destined for greatest in the WNBA and as a rapper, but based on what I heard, she may find her way to the CMO seat one day.)

Catching up on Spotify's stage with the brilliant Kay Hsu, Head of the Spotify Creative Lab, about the opportunity for Young Creators.

And just getting incredible quality time with long-time and new friends who are doing incredible things across the industry like Scott Larson, Franke Rodriguez, Laura Jones, David Tokheim, Ehren Hozumi, Eric Hall, Vineet Mehra, and so many more.  I'm very tired, but am returning with new energy about what's possible in the industry.

Design is broken. Young and not-so-young designers are becoming increasingly aware of this. Many feel impotent: they were told they had the tools to make the world a better place, but instead the world takes its toll on them. Beyond a haze of hype and bold claims lies a barren land of self-doubt and impostor syndrome. Although these feels might be the Millennial norm, design culture reinforces them. In conferences we learn that "with great power comes great responsibility" but, when it comes to real-life clients, all they ask is to "make the logo bigger."

Silvio Lorusso's book 'What Design Can't Do' probes the disillusionment that permeates design. It tackles the deskilling effects provoked by digital semi-automation, the instances of ornamental politics fashioned to please the museum-educational complex, the nebulous promises of design schools.

Read more about the book over in the Near Future Laboratory's Reading Nook, and listen to my conversation on Episode 089 of Near Future Laboratory Podcast!

We were lucky to keynote The Millennium Alliance's CHRO Summit in Atlanta, meeting some of the most passionate HR leaders in the country, trying to solve today's most pressing issue.

Half of the worldâ€™s populationÂ will experience a mental health disorderÂ in their lifetimeâ€”and yet, the vast majority of those impactedÂ wonâ€™t receive any treatment at all.

What's been most surprising to me is that the responsibility to solve this issue has fallen not on therapists or on the government, but instead, on HR leaders, who have been pressured to understand how employee mental health needs are growing so quickly, while mental health benefit utilization remains shockingly low. 

I'm proud of all the work we've done at Zeera to build a new care model that adequately supports mental health needs, without requiring folks to sit on a waitlist, with tremendous engagement rates. There is still so much work to do to solve the accelerating rate of mental illness; excited to continue working at it alongside the HR leaders on the frontlines.

Thrilled to share that I am now cancer-free and on a slow and steady road to recovery. ðŸ’œ ðŸ’ª 

A few months ago, a preventative MRI revealed a rare tumor on my pancreas (solid pseudopapillary neoplasm). Thanks to early detection, we acted quickly before it spread, removing just 25% of my pancreas while largely preserving my spleen and other vital organs.  The tests are back, and the cancer is gone.

Key learnings from this journey:

ðŸ”¹ Proactive Health: Early detection can save lives, and in my case, it did. My cancer was found through a preventative MRI. I had no signs or symptoms of cancer, in fact I was the healthiest I'd been in years.
ðŸ”¹Self-Advocacy: If you're unsatisfied with your healthcare provider, seek a second opinion at another institution.  Advocate for yourself, even when it feels deeply uncomfortable.
ðŸ”¹Â Empathy: You never know what someone is going through. Be kind and supportive, as they may be putting on a brave face. 
ðŸ”¹ Gratitude: Immense thanks to Biograph's diligent team for the early detection, my employer and team at OpenAI for their unwavering support, my all star husband Connor O'Brien, and our friends, family, and community for standing by our family through this. Special thanks to the world-class team at Stanford University for their exceptional care through every step of my journey. Truly the best healthcare institution in the world.

Looking forward, I'm increasingly optimistic about the future of healthcare, especially with AI's potential. Numerous promising AI companies in healthcare are emerging, and I'm excited to support their growth through any way possible. I believe that AI will revolutionize healthcare, making early detection and effective treatment more accessible.

Thank you all for your support and encouragement. This experience has strengthened my resolve to live fully and prioritize health, wellness, and family. ðŸ’œ

Today we are announcing that we are the first observability platform to integrate with NVIDIA NIM (NVIDIA Inference Microservices). This announcement continues our strategy of extending our AI investment, and follows previous announcements of AI monitoring, New Relic (our GenAI Assistant), and AIOps.
 
Several organizations are rapidly adopting generative AI for a variety of use cases, and whether they are in experimentation, limited testing or full scale production, understanding how their AI investment is performing and returning value is critical. That is because running and deploying AI applications is costly and hard to get right. NIM helps this, but often LLMs are a part of the overall application, so New Relic allows you to observe all parts of the application, both AI and non-AI portions. Our investment in NVIDIA NIM allows customers to extend observability to NVIDIAâ€™s microservices architecture.

Observability is uniquely suited to solving these challenges for business. This integration further reduces complexity and costs of developing, deploying, and monitoring AI applications. 

Customers can use New Relic AI monitoring to gain a comprehensive view of AI applications built with NVIDIA NIM, along with key metrics on throughput, latency, and costs while ensuring data privacy. 

I am proud that our team is always anticipating and solving for our customers' needs ahead of the market. And there is still so much more to come. 

You can read more here:

Bain Capital doesn't just want to invest.Â Its mission is to make a lasting impact and build great companies. 

The private investment firm - which was founded in 1984 and boasts $185 billion in assets under management - partners closely with management teams to improve on strategy, operations, or other key business areas.Â Technology is one of the key sectors it focuses on and it has the flexibility to meet the needs of companies at various stages from early stage to growth to industry incumbent.

column8: I am thrilled to be part of this talented group of BCG Health Care colleagues elected Managing Director and Senior Partner. Congratulations to all!

After 5 incredible years, today is my last day at Ginkgo. It has been such a privilege to work alongside some of the most extraordinary minds in the field and imagine a future where biology can be engineered to tackle the most significant problems in the world. While leaving is bittersweet, I am deeply grateful for the relationships and experiences that will stay with me for life. Iâ€™ll be Ginkgoâ€™s biggest cheerleader and am excited to find ways to collaborate in the future. 

Whatâ€™s next? First, enjoying Costa Rica for a few weeks (we live there in the summer so the kids keep their Spanish). Thenâ€¦ stay tuned! Ginkgo has inspired me to think well beyond our own four walls and Iâ€™m excited about some opportunities to drive much broader systemic change in the way science is done.

Making sense of the vast amounts of data we have in healthcare is a significant challenge. At Zelis, our mission is to modernize the healthcare financial experience by enabling our clients to leverage actionable insights from their data to improve care. 

Thanks, Gunjan Khanna, and the McKinsey & Company team for talking with me about price transparency data and how it is enabling improved member engagement in healthcare.

It is with great sadness that we share the sudden passing of Karen Vanaskie, Innovation Care Partnersâ€™ Chief Clinical Officer. 

Karen has been with ICP since 2014 and played a key role in the development and implementation of ICPâ€™s care management program. She remained an integral part of the care team and a member of ICPâ€™s executive leadership. Prior to joining ICP, Karen was the Director of Case Management at HonorHealth since 2008.

Karen has been the heart and soul of the care management team and has touched countless lives through her work and dedication. Her reach and impact extend far beyond her work at ICP, as she was a leader in her field â€“ words cannot express how profoundly sheâ€™ll be missed. 

Please keep Karenâ€™s family and the ICP family in your thoughts and prayers during this difficult time.

column8:
Generative artificial intelligence can have positive applications in the healthcare industry, said Keith Perry, Senior Vice President and Chief Information Officer, when he spoke recently at the annual Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) Discover conference. The event, held in Las Vegas, is a technology showcase held for HPE business and government customers. 

During the session, Perry said he and his staff see key training opportunities in respect to AI that work to enhance the productivity of highly skilled clinical, research, and administrative professionals. These groups all need to have both a grasp on the evolution of AI, as well as how it can and will impact their respective operations. 

To help advance our knowledge and discovery of pediatric diseases, St. Jude built a GenAI framework to integrate deep learning models into data science programs. The effort supports the institution's ongoing strategic investments in data science, which date back to the Pediatric Cancer Genome Project which at the time was the largest investment and most comprehensive effort to identify and understand the genetic origins of cancer. 

Perry was also recently honored by Becker's Healthcareâ€™s 2024 â€œCIOs to knowâ€ list, which recognizes IT executives at health systems and hospitals throughout the U.S. who are leading strategic initiatives, implementing new electronic health record systems, enhancing cybersecurity and deploying telehealth services. Congratulations, Keith! 

#HPEDiscover #GenerativeAI #HealthcareInnovation #StJude #PediatricCancer

column8: May I make a recommendation? If you get the incredible opportunity to eat at the best restaurant in the world, go by yourself. Being alone allows my mind to move freely. Add art. Add music. Add food. Add history. Add Massimo. Add Italy. Add a time in my life when I need all of those things. I brought a fresh moleskin journal to lunch as my companion, and filled it. Arrived at noon, and left at four. Where did the time go Massimo?! Only the best restaurant can do that. In a dream. I am very happy to share my successful completion of #ISB's Chief Digital Officer (#CDO) programme. This comprehensive, twelve-month course provided in-depth insights into leading enterprises through the disruptive digital trends reshaping the technology landscape. 

I would like to take this opporutnity to express my heartfelt gratitude to the exceptional faculty, success coaches and the support staff. Prof. Nandu Nandkishore set a high bar for storytelling while advocating principled leadership, Prof. Venkatesh Natarajan shared his deep expertise in digital solutions. Additionally, Karthik Chakkarapani, Prof. Ramnarayan S, Prof. Anand Nandkumar and Prof. Vishal Karungulam covered various aspects of the digital transformation journey. And, I am especially very thankful to Milind Naik for his encouragement throughout the core elements of the course on leadership.

The learnings from this course are multifold, spanning #DigitalStrategy, #Leadership, #GenAI and many other areas. I am eager to apply these concepts within my organization and to support our customers and partners to be successful. 

I feel privileged to have been part of a highly qualified cohort with deep expertise in data and analytics. Numerous lively discussions with particiption from everyone made this a unique learning experience. Undoubtedly, everyone in the cohort had to balance work, family and many other many other priorities that could not have been ignored. Yet they were always available to discuss ideas, explore new directions and share their unique experiences. I am hence very thankful for this shared experience and look foward to continued interactions in future. 

Anand Bakshi Paramprit S Bakshi Anil Bhagavatula Suhas Bindu (he/him) Shiva Biswas Radha Krishna Chandrapati Sushankar Daspal Diptarag Deb Jayen Desai Rajinish Erukulla RameshKumar Garikipati Manish Gupta vinod karma SaiKrishna Mallipeddi Kiran Kumar Narasipuram Sampath Manickam Jayamurugan Natarajan Nikhil Patwardhan Nilesh Powar Balaji Raghunathan Rozarani Reddy Rahul Sagar Govardhan Rao Sakkuri Lt. Col. Anand Sasmal Ganapathy Shankar Rafi Ahmed Syed Kalpana Timmapuram Gowtham Thotapalli Ramakrishna Vajapeyayajula

column8:
Excited to announce that my co-authors Natarajan Balasubramanian, Amit Joshi and I, have signed up with Taylor & Francis Group to release a book on The AI-Centered Enterprise by the end of this year.Â ðŸš€ 

As we continue to work through our vision and message, we are also eager to hear from you on your experience with AI of all kinds, including generative AI, in an enterprise context. Please reach out to me or my co-authors if you would like to chat. 

InterestingÂ fact here is that I spent many late evenings at the UCLA Anderson School of Management, 20 years ago, discussing data, technology and its impact on organizations with both Natarajan and Amit. None of us ever worked togetherÂ after that because we were in different fields (Natarajan: Strategy, Amit: Marketing and yours truly in Operations Research). But with the Gen AI revolution bringing AI to the fore, the timing has never been better to bring those ancient discussions back to life and expand on their future.

Needless to add, a lot of these ideas have also made their way into my startup samvid.ai co-founded with Arun Rao, who has also been a great source of encouragement in this book journey.

#enterpriseai #responsibleai #aiCenteredEnterprise

We are proud to announce our Crain's Detroit Business 2024 Healthcare Heroes!

ðŸ† Dr. Evelyn Jiagge, our assistant professor of hematology/oncology, was awarded Physician Hero for her work to head a collaborative program between our organization and 11 African health institutions to identify the genes responsible for the different rates of breast cancer occurrence and treatment success among African and African American patients.

ðŸ† Rox Gatia, our vice president of pharmacy shared services, was awarded Administrative Hero for his work to create our Centralized Pharmacy Services Center in Detroit to distribute common non-narcotic medicines to our 5 hospitals and 40-plus ambulatory medical centers with hundreds of outpatient clinics - marking the first health system-owned centralized pharmacy center in the country.

ðŸ† Wendy Kim, our vice president & chief nursing for our central market, and the Jackson Milk Bank team were awarded Allied Health Hero for their work to open Michigan's second donor breast milk bank - which has already collected close to 50,000 ounces of milk. 

Congratulations to our awardees!

This one was found in Novotel hotel room while I was in Plastics Recyclers Europe show last week. It has it all. The structure is multilayer monster with LDPE-Aluminium-Cardboard-LDPE and cap most likely bio-PE.
Anyways, I claim that at least statements "ECO friendly" , "100% recyclable" and "paper based bottle" are all false and greenwashing. "No deposit" is correct.
And bottom line is that this is bottled water.
I encourage hotels to promote tap water where ever it's clean and safe to drink.
If needed, please use monomaterials like PET bottles - and prefer deposit systems.
#greenwashing #recycling #plastics

I am pleased to share an article published in the most recent Innovation Issue of the Indianapolis Business Journal that highlights AES Indiana's recent efforts to demonstrate how we can increaseÂ  grid capacity through innovative technologies.
 
The United States is experiencing a rapidly shifting energy landscape due to the rising use of electricity, including electric vehicles and big tech data centers, which highlight the need for energy production and delivery to keep pace with growing customer demand. At The AES Corporation, weâ€™re piloting innovative projects, such as LineVision's Dynamic Line Ratings (DLR), to better understand how we can deliver more energy on the grid as safely and efficiently as possible.
 
You can read the full article where I share more about AES Indianaâ€™s LineVision pilot project, initial findings, and key learnings so that we can get more value from our existing grid assets with improved information. This pilot project reinforces that innovation is a crucial component for a greener, safer, and more equitable energy future.
 
#AES #Innovation #SustainableEnergy

column8:
Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity Lions is a wrap, and Smartly came to play. Here's a glimpse into our week of sparking industry love and creative revolution, anchored by our campaign of Falling back in love with advertising again:

We kicked off the week with a powerful article from Laura Desmond:
"Reinvention is at the heart of advertising, from the age of media to the rise of AI, our industry has constantly adapted. We dared to transform Cannes in 2005, and the data-driven, programmatic era followed. But consumers are telling us the experience is broken: irrelevant ads, exploding production costs, and a lack of privacy. It's time to fall in love with advertising again. We need to bring creative, media, and intelligence together to create meaningful experiences that power brand love and performance. Brands that tightly connect creative with media, think full-funnel, and leverage AI will win." 

Our First Smartly Branded Cannes HQ: We brought the Smartly vibe with a stunning Croisette view from our penthouse rooftop, hosting industry legends across holdcoâ€™s platforms, brands and sports & fueling passionate conversations about the power of technology to power creativity. #FallInLoveWithAdvertisingAgain

Tech + Creativity = â¤ï¸: We championed the power of creative technology to reignite brand love and unlock growth. Smartly is the bridge between the fragmented landscape and a future of storytelling that's both creative & impactful.

Global Thought Leaders: From global creative leaders Rob Reilly, Alexandre Abrantes, Jo Shoesmith, Claudine Cheever, Chaka Sobhani, to storytellers like Double Oscar Winner Ben Proudfoot, we hosted insightful talks that challenged the status quo and ignited a passion for innovation.

The Business of Womenâ€™s Sports Take Center Stage: We spotlighted the booming business of women's sports with two powerful panels including Thayer Lavielle, Heather Hopkins Freeland, Flaujae Johnson, Angela Ruggiero, Jessica Berman, Meg Linehan. Smartly sits at the heart of the social & streaming channels driving this growth. #InvestInHer

Leaving Cannes, we're energized to lead the charge towards a future where intelligent creative fuels brand love and growth. The best is yet to come! #SmartlyatCannes2024 #CannesLions2024

P.S. Big thanks to Cheerful Twentyfirst 21 for bringing our vision to life!

column22: Jordan Richards thank you. The Smartly Team rocked it. We are so thankful for so many smart, bright and thoughtful leaders in advertising, brands, and womenâ€™s sports investing their time with Smartly this week.

Iâ€™ve been refining my social marketing model for designing programs from a behavioral point of view. Iâ€™d love your feedback to see if you find it helpful.

The usual model of the Social Marketing Mix focuses on the â€œ4 Psâ€ (Product, Price, Place, Promotion) that originally come from commercial marketing, and my â€œ8 Psâ€ social marketing mix added on Publics, Partnerships, Policy and Purse Strings. 

But Iâ€™ve found that many have a hard time making the leap from the marketing mix to what the actual programmatic strategy would look like. 

Iâ€™ve transitioned from the Ps to 4 strategic directives, which together increase the likelihood that an individual will engage in the target behavior. If youâ€™re familiar with other behavioral models, it wonâ€™t look entirely new. And unlike the separate Promotion â€œPâ€ in the social marketing mix, the tactics for messaging about and implementing each element are embedded throughout.

This is a high-level introduction because I didnâ€™t want to make this post too long. The elements of the model (determined by research with your intended audience) are:

1ï¸âƒ£ Make it appealing - We need to offer an irresistible behavioral product thatâ€™s so compelling that our audience wonâ€™t want to refuse. This involves how we frame the behavior and its benefits, showing how it aligns with their core values, identity and aspirations. We can do this through methods like stories, working with trusted partners, and personalizing the product or message.

2ï¸âƒ£ Make it easy - By identifying the barriers (ie, price) that stand in the way of adopting the behavior, we can implement strategies that smooth the path as much as possible. These are the barriers as perceived by the individual, and could be based on a lack of knowledge, skills, negative attitudes, physical, financial or psychological factors. Through methods like simplifying the behavior, connecting it to whatâ€™s already familiar to them, and helping people understand how to build it into their lives, they can more easily move forward.

3ï¸âƒ£ Apply social persuasion - While social factors could also apply in the first two elements, this is where we put the â€œsocialâ€ in â€œsocial marketing.â€ Bring in the power of social norms, influencers, social proof, social interactions, and social support to increase the lure of the crowd and the comfort of belonging.

4ï¸âƒ£ Design the context - We need to reach people where they are, both physically and mentally. This means identifying the times, life stages, and places where theyâ€™re most likely to be receptive to messages and able to take action. And this includes designing an environment that supports the behavior, with contextual reminders, cues to action or relevant policies.

If you are a social marketer, what do you think of this approach? Anything thatâ€™s missing? If youâ€™re not a social marketer, what do you think of this as a model to help you start to think through creating a behavior change campaign or program?

#SocMar #SocialMarketing #BehaviorChange

column8:
I learned a great deal from the conversation yesterday moderated by Akia Ng about the partnership between Greenlight and U.S. Bank. Greenlight is a financial app for families that provides tools for parents to teach kids about financial literacy.

Jennifer Miller discussed two of the biggest needs facing the customer base of U.S. Bank: 1) The need to educate younger people on financial topics; and 2) The need to provide banking solutions for parents looking to open accounts for kids under 13. In U.S. Bank's college campus efforts, one piece of feedback from the chancellor's office of many colleges is that their financial aid department spends an inordinate amount of time speaking with students about basic financial concepts such as the importance of a budget.

Brandon Horne shared how these are areas at the core of Greenlight's mission. Over the past 10 years, they have learned lessons on delivering financial education and building a product that is authentic and sensitive to parents' different views about money. Authenticity is important because brands that develop trust with young people and provide solutions throughout their life journey can create sustainable customer loyalty.

Al Dominick emphasized the importance of trust and innovation. Gaining trust in this digital worldâ€”especially among the younger generationâ€”is challenging. But there can be business outcomes tied to the investment in young people that can enable brands to achieve near-term reputational gain and long-term financial upside.

My key takeaway is that not only can financially literate young people become loyal customers for financial institutions, they can become ð˜£ð˜¦ð˜µð˜µð˜¦ð˜³ customers. As they earn more, invest, and grow their net worth, they may need to utilize additional products and services, thereby increasing customer lifetime value. The learner benefits and many players in the ecosystem can win as well with increased financial literacy education. 



#FinancialEducation #FinancialLiteracy #Fintech #Greenlight #USBank

I'm so proud that The World Bank is a bank - a financial institution â€“ that does so much good in the world! The World Bank is steadfast in its support for member countries delivering technical assistance, low-cost financing, and risk management to end poverty and boost shared prosperity on a livable planet. 
Our Treasury just launched our Impact Report for 2023. Big congratulations to my colleagues, including Jorge Familiar and Colleen Keenan, for publishing this critical report.

column8:
What exactly is the 10-Second Customer Journey?

It happens when all the elements of #customerexperienceâ€” #marketing, #product, #commerce, and #service--work together to create a customer in just a few seconds.

You know the feeling when it happens. 

You see an ad that speaks to you in your #social media feed, maybe for something you didnâ€™t even know you wanted.

Youâ€™re hooked in just a few seconds and decide to click â€œlearn more.â€

The landing page is clear and compelling and addresses your concerns.

You hit â€œbuy now,â€ auto fill your #payment info, or use Apple Pay. 

Boom, youâ€™re done.

How long did that take? If it worked well, about 10 seconds from start to finish.

Easy for you, but not so easy to orchestrate on the other side to make this happen. This takes teamwork, collaboration and organization leadership to unify the #growth levers of the organization around the customer.

Seem like a dream? It's not.

What did you come across today that took you on a 10-Second Customer Journey?

Find out more about orchestrating a unified #customer #journey in my new book, The 10-Second Customer Journey.Â (link in comments)

This past weekend, I had the privilege of joining other top CEOs, innovators, and world-changing thought leaders for an ultra-chic day of impact and engagement at the "Billions House," in Southhampton, owned by the incredible Michael Loeb. 

I'm a super fan of the hit show "Billions" on Showtime which details the fictional journey of Billionaire & Investor Bobby Axelrod. Many of the most iconic scenes were taped in the fabulous home. I couldn't pass up the opportunity to head back to my hometown of NYC and prep for what would be one of the most notable events of the summer alongside sponsors from EY and incredible peers.

From conversations with Laurie Ann Goldman, CEO of Tupperware Brands, to reconnecting with the rockstar that is Jason Feifer of Entrepreneur Media, and meeting the amazing Katie Couric, so many ah-ha moments were had. Sitting beside founders and leaders from 1-800-Flowers.com, Edelman, Google and more was incredible.

Leadership, networking, resilience, and transparency were common themes heard from guest speakers throughout the day. With three pages of notes, dozens of follow-ups, and mind-shifting strategy points, my heart was so full. Safe spaces to share fears, best practices, and vulnerability are so needed for all entrepreneurs.

I first met Katie Loeb, a few years ago during our journey and pivot to increase public restroom period care access. Katie's support was invaluable, as she showed up in ways that truly made a difference to further our business. It was awesome to fill her and Michael in on all of the way's @femly has grown. 

Overall, in a post-pandemic world, in person opportunities to network, engage, and learn are super important. As the event came to a close and our #ean family circled together, we were all filled with gratitude. As myself and team continue our journey we will continue to be inspired. 

This is #uncharted. What a day ! Cynithea (Nit) Reeder Travis Lay Sam Johnson Courtney Caldwell, MBA Katie Couric Sarah Davis Grandmaster Maurice Ashley Anouck Gotlib

â€œItâ€™s going to feel like youâ€™re working for a completely different company.â€

I didnâ€™t believe it when they told me and now, Iâ€™ve learned what it means to move to a different department in an organization with over 20k employees.

This marks 120 days as a leader in Real Estate Lending and this morning, I found myself reflecting on the failures from these first few months. I got things right too though, so Iâ€™m giving myself a moment to celebrate the small wins where I set myself up to succeed. 

ðŸ“Œ Planned vacations before I even started

Iâ€™m notorious for rolling over the maximum amount of vacation hours year to year. That needed to change and you wonâ€™t catch it happening again. Iâ€™ve become a better friend and leader for it.

ðŸ“Œ Kept up with my strong connections

With the additional distance and lack of shared work, this has been the most challenging. The effort is worth it though. When the ground beneath me has felt like shifting quicksand, itâ€™s been these connections that created a solid place to stand. Even if it was just for an hour lunch date.

ðŸ“Œ Leveraged a Challenge Network

I learned about this concept when I read Adam Grantâ€™s book, Think Again. They are my expert listeners and perspective sharers. By engaging in healthy debate and calling out my bias, these folks have made me a better decision maker.

While everything feels foreign right now, I know that ultimately, Iâ€™m still working towards the same mission. I get to see our culture from a different vantage point. My community of people is still there, it has just grown. The challenges Iâ€™ve gotten to take on are moving us towards the same goals.

Hereâ€™s to the next 120 days! ðŸŽ‰

#LessonsLearned #NavyFederalCreditUnion #MomentsThatMatter #PersonalDevelopment #Culture #Leadership #LifeAtNavyFederal #CareerJourney #HomeLending #Strategy

Forget much of what you thought you knew about what consumers want to see from advertising ðŸ›‘ 

Our new research, launched at Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity deep dives into how people across generations & demographics want brands to show up across their brand experience journey. Here are a few highlights:

â€¢When consumers are in the discovery phase, production quality of the ad is 2x more important than the product featured, alone.

â€¢Mirroring Gen Z's preferences, 52% of Gen Alpha gravitate towards short- form videos between 2-5 minutes. However, longer content isn't entirely out of favor.

â€¢In the Mid Funnel Consideration phase, consumers want to see Product, Product, Product. Product information is 2.4x more effective than price and promotion. 

â€¢Price and promotions are not in the top five most important creative considerations during the Discovery & Consideration phases of their brand experience journey.

â€¢Only at the purchase phase of the brand experience journey, do consumers rate the actual product offer the most important. Product is 1.6x more important than production which is rated #1 in the Discovery phase.

â€¢While affordability remains a consideration, product information trumps price promotions when influencing purchase decisions.

People are looking for a journey, not a sales pitch. They want brands to guide them from discovery to consideration to action, with creative messaging that truly resonates.

Read the report and learn what truly matters to today's consumers + what winning creative across the funnel looks like ðŸ‘‡

column8:
I'm shutting down my startup, RAVACAN.

5 years after I founded it.

Here are 5 lessons and reflections:

â†“

1. We don't have product-market fit

- Building an enterprise-grade software is incredibly costly
- No buying intent from Direct procurement
- Procurement managers lack the authority to drive changes internally

2. Creating a new category is hard

- Manufacturing companies prefer highly customizable solutions over SAAS
- Educating the market about a new category requires significant time and resources
- Buyers can't compare and feel the risk is higher

3. Why I'm Stopping This

- We had minimal returns despite significant effort
- We cannot build what the market needs with minimal capital, and open-source solutions exist (more on this soon!)
- Manufacturers are secretive and don't share the word with their peers even when they are very happy

4. Things I Would Have Done Differently

- Targeted more dynamic niches like semiconductors or raw materials
- Engage smaller companies instead of enterprises
- Offer the product for free to get references

5. My Most Critical Learnings

- Don't build something people need, but something they want
- Better be the second best than the first (Edit: Better be challenger than pioneer)
- Use funding momentum and don't let it go away

Richard Branson said, "The brave may not live forever, but the cautious do not live at all." I try to live by this every day.

On one hand, it's tough to shut down something I've poured my heart into. 
On the other hand, I feel a sense of relief and gratitude. The journey with RAVACAN has been an incredible learning experience. The lessons I've gained, the skills I've developed, and the insights I've gathered are invaluable.

While RAVACAN's chapter is closing, these experiences will undoubtedly shape my future endeavors. Iâ€™m eager to apply what Iâ€™ve learned to whatever comes next.

Thank you to my talented and tenacious teammates Benjamin BEGUIN, Carles Ballester, to our first clients who saw the future with us, especially Mike Maloney, to our investors who supported me every step of the way Vincent Diallo, Laura Brady, Benjamin Ling, Collin Gutman, Jeff Weinstein. My mentor Gary Geschwind.
column22: Sounds like you achieved some amazing returns from this investment, albeit in the form of experience and wisdom rather than shareholder value. Sorry this one didn't work out.  I applaud your grit and the honesty of your reflections.

column8:
PTO isn't important.  Negotiating PTO is selfish. Worry about your work, not your time off. 




I read those comments on my post this week. 

In February of 2010 my mom was diagnosed with cancer. In April of 2010 she died. 

In August of 2023 my dad was diagnosed with cancer. In October of 2023 he died. 

Both of my parents were happy and healthy one minute and no longer here the next.

 They are why I think PTO is important. 


Losing my parents has taught me how fragile life is, how finite time is and how important it is to make memories with my own kids.

Everyone should advocate for themselves. Being laid off sometimes means accepting a job that is less than ideal.  I had to. But we can still fight for what we believe is right.

Work isn't all about PTO, it's about giving it your all while youâ€™re working. Doing your best every day, whatever that "best" is from day to day.

But life isn't about working 24/7 either.  It's about finding what works for your family and embracing what matters.

Wanting time off makes you no less dedicated or hard-working.

Be a good human. 

#worklifebalance #worklifeharmony #workingmom #momlife #pto #negotiations

column8:
My first experience with the devastating effects of climate change was the Cedar Rapids Flood of 2008. Almost 10% of the people in my hometown were displaced from their homes, and this flood caused 7x more damage because of climate change. 

Since then, itâ€™s been my goal to contribute to the fight against climate change. Today, we have the chance to reduce suffering on a global scale, by acting now to minimize our greenhouse gas emissions.

This mission has taken me through the University of Iowa and University of California, Berkeley, where I gained the knowledge and skills necessary to begin tackling this immense challenge. During my PhD at Berkeley, my team at Berkeley Lab and I identified heavy industry as one of the most difficult sources of emissions to tackle, with huge potential for positive impact. 

During the next several years, we explored what it would take to decarbonize industrial process heat, which makes up 1/4 of all energy used in the world and accounts for 10% of global carbon emissions. We designed a thermal storage material and system that could provide this industrial heat at prices competitive with fossil fuels, and proved many of the critical features of this technology on a lab scale!

Our results were so promising that I decided to begin looking into what it would take to commercialize this, and bring the technology into the real world. This brought me to the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE)'s Cradle to Commerce program, where I met Pauliina Meskanen.

Very quickly after meeting Pauliina, I knew this was somebody I wanted to work with. She has the determination, motivation, skills, and personality required to build a successful company from the ground up, and we decided to start working together almost exactly a year ago.

From these initial conversations, Calectra was born! Pauliina and I founded Calectra together with the mission to electrify and decarbonize industrial process heat. Since last May, weâ€™ve found that high-temperature industry (steel, cement, glass, chemicals, aluminum) is especially lacking in solutions for decarbonization. We are full steam ahead on filling this gap!

Weâ€™ve got big plans, please follow along as we work to build Calectra and change the world!

Iâ€™m very happy to announce the impending publication of my book â€œA Bandana and A Bluebird: The Path to a Patient Centric Healthcare Systemâ€ â€“ coming July 1, 2024. 
 
Powerful memories of my relationships with patients as a young doctor inspired me and my work in pharma. The benefits of Patient Centricity for drug development and healthcare delivery convinced me this is the right path. Patient Centricity is the way to better outcomes for patients, and we can achieve it! 

Thanks to Astellas Pharma for providing a platform for this important work.

Have you used your LinkedIn QR code to connect with people at events?

It's one of my favourite icebreakers and now I've found a FASTER way to make connections. Here's how:

1. Find the LinkedIn button on your smartphone and hold it for a few seconds.
2. In the dropdown menu, click on "Scan QR code"
3. Scan or share your code with other connections.

It's that simple!

Remember: It's a good idea to deepen and nurture relationships AFTER the event too. 

Follow up with a personalized message, so you can remember the context about how you met each other. 

If you found this video helpful, share it with your friends. ðŸ‘ 

Let me know if I can help you, your team or your organization use LinkedIn to create more opportunities and stand out with your brand out. ðŸ˜„

column8:
It was an honor to be invited to the White House for the inaugural Latino Venture Summit to join other Latino business leaders from across the country spanning startup founders, emerging fund managers, institutional venture, private equity, banking, big tech, and non-profit. During the Summit, we discussed the importance of the innovation gained by Latino led businesses and their impact on our economy. I particularly enjoyed conversations led by Steve Benjamin, Senior Advisor to President, & Director White House Office of Public Engagement; Tom Perez,  Senior Advisor to President, & Director White House Office of Intergovernmental Affairs; Isabel Guzman, Administrator U.S. Small Business Administration; and Alejandra Castillo, Assistant Secretary U.S. Department of Commerce, Economic Development Administration. The important work towards the expansion, diversification, and betterment of our global economy led by all is an inspiration to me, and to many others. Special thanks to Vincent Cordero for his vision on initiating this important forum. 
Alejandra Y. Castillo

Do you also suffer from ONE thing that can hinder your career progression and may make your day to day work a struggle?



These statements were taken randomly from some of my clientsâ€™ worksheets, do you recognise yourself in any of them?


ðŸ¥º Usually, I doubt myself and find out later that I was right at first.


ðŸ˜Ÿ I do care very heavily about what people think about me.


ðŸ¤¨ I want people to know that â€œheâ€™s goodâ€ at what he does. I want that reputation.


ðŸ˜’ I worry about the perception from colleagues


ðŸ˜° My procrastination on the task that scares me the most: prepping well for the evaluation session. I am to some extent afraid of being successful, so I donâ€™t even try.



So, what is that ONE thing?



These days it is conveniently referred to as â€œthe impostor syndromeâ€ however, it is a combination of several intertwined thought patterns and behaviours that may be difficult to dissect and understand. They could include:

-Depending excessively on external validation

-Self doubt

-Lack of confidence

-Feeling not good enough (or a fraud)

-Fear of failure

-Fear of success

And moreâ€¦

If you have experienced similar thoughts, moods, emotions that have impacted your performance, your clarity and drive and as a result you are â€œselling yourself shortâ€ or are not being as bold as youâ€™d like, know that:

âœ³ï¸ Even the most successful, powerful people have these experiences

âœ³ï¸ Consistent work on yourself will pay off â€“ understanding your limiting beliefs is a first step!

âœ³ï¸ You can â€œfeel the fear and do it anyway!â€ but thatâ€™s so much easier if someone has your back

âœ³ï¸ What other people think of you â€“ is none of your business!

âœ³ï¸ What you think of yourself is entirely your business!

âœ³ï¸ Focus on YOU and not on others. Do what you can, with what youâ€™ve got â€“ NOW

âœ³ï¸ Love your life and your life will love you back!

And if this is not enough, do talk to me â€“ Iâ€™m very high on compassion (according to Jordan Peterson - more than 93 people in a room of 100) and I can also teach you some saboteur-slaying techniques! ðŸ¤£ ðŸ˜œ

#careersuccess #impostorsyndrome #careercoaching

True story... on a recent flight, the guy sitting across from me says politely "what do you do for a living? I'm guessing you're an engineer by the way you move." I thought to myself, well that's kind of an odd thing to say, am I robotic in my demeanor?!

Turns out the guy works at Oracle and after talking explains to me that he's been working on AI for three decades. He is certainly a big deal in the industry and likely somewhat famous to AI followers. We had a good chat about math and algorithms, and what he thinks about the future of AI.

I could not have asked for a more interesting AI conversation, nor a better reason to wonder why someone might perceive me as somewhat non-human. I'll be pondering both of these topics!

Jumped from Pittsburgh to Palo Alto for a fantastic conversation last night with an incredible group of technology and people leaders. From Splunk and Tesla to Datadog, Fastly, and Visa, it was inspiring to hear how these companies are innovating their approach to hiring #technicaltalent around the world. And while we all agreed that #AI has great potential, it is clear that the need for humans in the interview process has never been more important.

My sincere thanks to Michael Ross for hosting, and to Charmaine W., David Lau, Manish Asnani, Min Wang, Puja Jaspal, Sagnik Nandy, and Sunil Seshadri on behalf of all of us at Karat for the energy, insights, and partnership. Hereâ€™s to creating the future of hiring together, one interview at a time!

ðŸ‘ Standing ovation for the first 100% renewable energy company in Colombia! 

In their recently published sustainability report, AES Colombia outlined plans to triple its installed renewable capacity by 2030, reaching 3000 MW. The great team led by the visionary Federico Echavarria is working on an impressive pipeline of solar, wind and energy storage projects that will triple our renewable portfolio in Colombia. 

With a goal of carbon neutrality by 2025, AES Colombia is a true leader in sustainability. This ambitious goal will become possible thanks to the dedication and professionalism of the team, who is constantly expanding the boundaries of innovation, offering the cleaner and greener energy solutions our customers need. 

At The AES Corporation, we are proud to be strategic allies in Colombia's energy transition, enabling our customers in the country achieving the decarbonization of their energy matrix. In 2023 our solar parks in Colombia generated nearly 150,000 MWh of renewable energy and contributed to the reduction of 54,000 tons of carbon dioxide. 

This way we are also supporting the country's commitments in the 2030 Agenda of reducing carbon emissions by 51% and the 2050 Agenda of achieving carbon neutrality. 

Endless applause to the great AES Colombia team for accelerating the future of energy, together!Â ðŸŒŽ

The Association of Plastic Recyclers (APR) is expanding its Design for Recyclability Recognition Program. This initiative is crucial for encouraging innovative, sustainable packaging designs that can be effectively recycled. By recognizing companies that prioritize recyclability in their designs, APR is paving the way for a circular economy and reducing plastic waste. 

At Graham, we incorporate APR guidelines right from the design stage, and we understand the importance of creating packaging that is visually appealing, sustainable and recyclable.

column8:
Time for a personal update.

After 3 great years at Okta, I've decided to try something new and will be joining Docusign in early August as their CTO.

It has been an amazing ride and experience at Okta. When I left Google after 15+ years, I wasn't sure what to expect in the world outside the Big G. But Okta was a great mutual fit right from the very start. Todd McKinnon, Frederic Kerrest, and the entire team at Okta welcomed me and made me feel right at home. Their focus on the customer, continuous push for innovation, and building products, systems and teams that scale really connected with me. The last 3 years flew by. Be it building new governance, privileged access and threat protection products to continued innovation in the IDaaS and orchestration offerings to rolling out a new and powerful platform - we got a lot done and had a lot of fun doing it. Which is why now felt like a good time to move on and try something new. I'm very thankful to Todd, Freddy, the entire leadership team at Okta, my amazing team and every Oktanaut for making my time at Okta so much fun. The criticality of Identity and its role in security and running efficient modern organizations is only increasing. Iâ€™ll continue to root for Okta, and I eagerly look forward to all the excitement and continued innovation in this space.

This brings me to the next chapter of my journey at Docusign. I've always been a fan of this iconic company and its massive impact and reach. The prevalence and criticality of intelligent and efficient agreement management is growing by the day. Allan Thygesen is someone I've always admired and when we chatted about the future of Docusign and how transformative AI-powered agreement management can become, I felt I had to be part of that journey. He has built a great leadership team at Docusign and in all my conversations with them, the excitement and belief in the company and where it's headed echoed. There's a lot to learn, a lot to do, a lot of impact to be made, and a lot of fun to be had â€” Iâ€™m really looking forward to that.

I'm going to take some time off in July to recharge a little bit before starting at Docusign. Fun fact: I literally had a 2 day break between leaving Google and joining Okta and wanted to do it differently this time around. I'm looking for suggestions for books (I'm still trying to do my book-a-month thing but can probably speed that up in July) as well as any fun and productive activities/projects that people have picked up during breaks and transitions. So please keep the recommendations coming!

#grateful #humbled #excited

Grateful today for an utterly amazing week of inspiration with over 600 Holman leaders from across the business.

The week got started Sunday with our Holman 100 Anniversary NJ event. Over 7,000 partners and their families were fired up with concerts from BNL and Carrie Underwood and heart warmed with our gift to the United Way.

Monday kicked off Holman CONNECT our annual leadership meeting. As action packed as I anticipated and highlighted by; 
- Spending time with my amazing TEAM CANADA colleagues and meeting countless new US and INTL colleagues. 
- Chris McChesneyâ€™s workshop on the 4 disciplines of execution to get to breakthrough.
- Our panels on the outlook for the business, enriching our partner experience and our bold ambitions innovating our customer experience.
- Two somber hours together learning more about homelessness and packing and personalizing over 1,200 Dignity Bags for Covenant House.
- And CEO Chris Conroy letter to his 24 yr. old self was brilliant. Insightful, Funny, Graceful and Gratitude filled. 
Congrats to Kaitlyn Pitts and her team for an extraordinary experience.

Crossing my 100 days with Holman in the most brilliant way - in the company of over 600 leaders at our annual Connect summit. 

We heard from John Foley on his mantra of â€˜Glad to be hereâ€™ along with the power of learning, debriefs and accountability. 

We learnt from Chris McChesney about the Excellence in Execution. How might we transform while executing the daily? 

We shared out deep insights across multiple panels covering businesses, leadership and customer expectations that together allow us to deliver on our mission. 

I am grateful to have an opportunity to share with fellow panelists Petter Witt Frank Beideman Frank Cardile hosted by Denise Wildish. Denise masterfully crafted the conversation to cover our past century of progress to where we go next. Some key points I shared: 

1. Change is inevitable, organizations that are nimble, adaptable, sense and respond tend to retain customer loyalty 

2. We live in a hyper connected global economy that is experience driven. How might we show up successfully? 

3. A belief that a â€˜healthy partner experienceâ€™ will deliver a great client and brand experience.

The week was topped off by an inspiring letter from Chris Conroy to his younger self that deeply resonated with all and even brought out some tears. Empathetic leadership at its finest was on display. 

Thanks to Chris Conroy Mindy Holman Kimberly Andreola Kaitlyn Pitts for an impactful week! 

#customercentricity #strategy #transformation #employeeexperience

GASP!!!Â Coming up for air after an amazing 6 weeks at Ulta Beauty.  What'd I miss??? ðŸ˜€ 

Netflix just release their latest iteration of their Culture Memo.Â One of the things I love is how direct and honest this memo is.  They know where they need to improve and move to address it.  I especially love the "Sports Team" analogy. 

Culture needs to be actionable.Â A piece of paper with some hand-wavy "values" is meaningless without the ability to hold people accountable, and just as important, enable and trust your people in creating something great. 

While I'm only 6 weeks in, I can FEEL the great culture here at Ulta Beauty.Â I intend to make it even better.Â Those of you who know me know that I'm big on culture and I put my money where my mouth is on enabling it.

Ulta have a mission to bring #joyforward.Â I would add that we are also creating an amazing #techforward culture!  Would love to hear from you and share ideas on culture, or better yet, come join us!

#LFG

I am thrilled to embark on my third year with Gwinnett County Public Schools, where I have the privilege of teaching Financial Literacy, Marketing, and Entrepreneurship to Georgia's exceptionally diverse and talented students. My lifelong passion has always been to inspire, educate, and empower young minds, helping them discover and achieve their fullest potential.

LinkedIn family,

It's been a while, so thank you for allowing me a moment to share some updates via a very long post. Iâ€™m eager to reconnect and hear from you as well.

Reflecting on my 25-year journey in cybersecurity, I'm grateful for the people, experiences, and milestones that have enriched my professional life. From shaping go-to-market strategies for emerging cybersecurity companies to achieving a number of strategic exits, each experience has been a blessing.

As an immigrant displaced by the Russian invasion of Afghanistan, the boundless opportunities in America profoundly influenced my work ethic and values. The legacy of dedication and resilience instilled by my father, who served with the US Department of Defense, and my mother's bravery which helped us escape a war torn country, continues to inspire my commitment to the cybersecurity and defense sectors.

A career highlight was my tenure at Proofpoint, where we as a team grew the company from $20 million to $1.4 billion in annual recurring revenue over 13.5 years, from early-stage to IPO, and later acquisition by Thoma Bravo. I'm thankful for the friendships forged and lessons learned.

Along the way, I developed an obsession with the US venture capital ecosystem and how it consistently generates the world's most significant companies. Starting with pre-IPO investments in Facebook and Palantir I went on to invest in and help over 100 innovative startups over the last 15 years. This path eventually led me to launch my own VC fund called Inflection Ventures in December of 2022.

At Inflection Ventures, we focus on private companies in cybersecurity, defense, and technology infrastructure, primarily looking for growth stage companies (at their point of inflection) but also supporting and advising friends in the ecosystem across all stages.

These photos are from a visit with Shield AI in Dallas, where I met with cofounder and CEO Ryan Tseng. Shield AI leads in developing AI systems for defense applications, enhancing autonomous decision-making in critical missions where GPS and communications are compromised. Their mission aligns perfectly with our goals, and represents the impactful work we support.

Please message me if you want to catch up or learn more. I'd love to hear your voice. 

I appreciate all of you and am extremely grateful to all the LPs on this journey with us!

All the best, 
Kabe


#CyberSecurity #Defense #VentureCapital #Investment #AI #Startups #TechInfrastructure #Entrepreneurship #Databricks #Anduril #Abnormalsecurity #Proofpoint #SpaceX #Cyera #Oasiscyber #Crowdstrike #PaloAltoNetworks #ShieldAI
Iâ€™m happy to share that Iâ€™m starting a new position as Department Manager of the Manhattan Electric Control Center at Con Edison!

The New York Times had a headline today that said "Can Apple think different on AI?" The whole story is about "Apple has lagged behind its rivals" in AI, because "Big Tech C.E.O.s have fallen over themselves to show they are in the race," "but Apple hasnâ€™t yet introduced a new A.I. offering."

Ok. This is gonna make me lose my mind. Like, fine, Apple hasn't released an "AI offering" - but nobody else has released one that actually works! Does Google get points for their search thing that everyone hated?? Does Microsoft, for adding a gimmicky Copilot thing to Windows that nobody seems to like? Are companies who are tacking bad chatbots onto their products better than those that aren't because it shows that you're in the race?? Is acquihiring a bunch of AI researchers for billions of dollars - even though nobody seems to have figured out how to make any of this stuff all that useful - automatically a brilliant investment??? 

I swear, some Wall Street analysts saw the ChatGPT demo and got excited, and some tech Twitter influencers realized they could write buzzy threads about "what it takes to win with AI," and we all became immediately convinced of this stuff's inevitability. How is Apple's apparent AI strategy - "We're gonna wait a minute to see what we can do with this thing that's actually useful and good" - not a *better* strategy than, I duoon, adding a worthless 'Ask Meta AI!' bar to the top of Instagram??

Do you feel bad taking vacation? 

You shouldn't, yet so many (54% to be more exact*) do. 

Why? 

Because humans have a tendency to not take advantage of things they rightly deserve. 

And this is especially true when it comes to salary negotiations and why I do what I do. 

Sign up for my for my newsletter to get thoughtful tips on how to feel more comfortable asking for what you deserve. 

In the meantime, I'm going to on vacation and can't wait to sip my morning tea to this view.

*Source - The renowned Movchan Agency

When we designed the Jefferson Health Honickman Center, our new state-of-the-art outpatient care center, we knew we wanted to create much more than a traditional healthcare facility. We hoped to foster a true sense of #community, so we created an adjoining public plaza that could be activated for special events, fitness classes, and more. 
 
This week, at Jefferson Plaza, we hosted the #Jefferson200 Block Party in partnership with the cityâ€™s annual Wawa, Inc. Welcome America festival. It was a celebration of #innovation and #education as we recognized Jeffersonâ€™s rich 200-year legacy and commitment to Greater #Philadelphia. Live music, a DJ, free food, giveaways, #health resources, and a cornhole tournament for Jefferson staff, were some of the highlights. We even had an incredible performance by Phillyâ€™s own Kathy Sledge, a founding member of the iconic group Sister Sledge. 
 
The most meaningful part of the day was that our team kicked off the party with a service project to make 500 sandwiches for Our Brotherâ€™s Place shelter. This chart about the costs of training AI large language models (LLMs) caught my attention. Economic theoryâ€”particularly in the technology industryâ€”has long suggested that supply-side innovation can cause prices to fall rapidly for critical infrastructure, even with increasing demand. Think of computer hardware and semiconductor chips as prime examples. 

Gordon Moore, the co-founder of Intel, saw that theory in action. Moore observed that as the number of transistors on a computer chip doubled over a period of about 18 months, the price of the chip over the same period fell by about half. That was way back in 1965â€”and the so-called â€œMooreâ€™s lawâ€ for chip progress and pricing has continued to hold roughly true for the nearly six decades since (a veritable eon in the tech world). But fast forward to 2024, and generative AI seems to be turning Mooreâ€™s law on its head: costs of training the next generation of LLMs arenâ€™t halving; instead, prices have roughly doubled every nine months. 

So what explains this reversal? Itâ€™s all about how LLMs scale.

To date, many of the AI raceâ€™s main drivers have seemed to be hyper-fixated on scaling up the existing architecture. Many LLM champions believe that to get to where AI wants to go, â€œscale is all you needâ€. Just make the transformer models bigger and more powerful, their thinking goes, and LLMs will revolutionize the economy andâ€”for someâ€”lead to artificial generalized intelligence. That view is why frontier model company CEOs talk about numbers like $10-billion training costs for a model and a $100-billion supercomputer.
 
But today, Iâ€™m hearing more and more about scaling down. In stark contrast to LLMs, the small language model (SLM) â€œtheoryâ€ is that smaller models, more tightly engineered for narrower applications and domains, will increasingly supplant LLMs. The same way that fine-tuned four-cylinder engines in a modern BMW 4 series outperform (more horsepower with better gas efficiency) the V8 450-cubic-inch engines that used to power Corvettes. SLMs are also typically trained on finely curated high-quality data setsâ€”analogous to the high-octane gas that the four-cylinder engine needs to use. As such, the costs of SLMs may map more closely toÂ Mooreâ€™s law than their large-language counterparts. 

For the moment, developers and investors are essentially betting on both of these theoriesâ€”LLMs and SLMsâ€”simultaneously. However, that probably wonâ€™t continue forever in the same fashion. 

â€œScale-is-all-you-needâ€ LLMs will have to demonstrate extraordinary ROI to justify their $100-billion price tags, while SLMs will have to prove that they are flexible enough to fit multiple use cases and continue to improve their efficiency at domain-specific tasks. Companies adopting AI will also need to decide when they need a fine-tuned BMW and when they need a powerhouse Corvette. 

I believe this is one of the most fascinating and consequential races in the AI world right nowâ€¦and one to watch closely.

column8:
Achievement Unlocked!

With three companies now having launched driver-out deployments in the United States (Waymo, Cruise, and May Mobility), we've shown that the autonomous driving technology can work. Achievement unlocked!

The next milestone is making the business work. Getting vehicles to operate with billions of dollars of engineering effort, expensive sensors + compute is one thing-- getting vehicles to operate where the revenues justify the R&D costs and vehicle costs is quite another.

Even if the vehicles are amazing, recouping billions of dollars of R&D investment is a challenge. Emerging AI technologies are showing that similar-- if not better-- performance can be achieved with far lower R&D costs. We're not the only ones investing in these emerging methods, but we're the only ones that generate new training data on-the-fly and learn in-situ, structurally addressing the "edge case" problem that vexes virtually all data-driven approaches. (That includes end-to-end learning methods.)

Low R&D and per-vehicle costs make it possible to not only develop the technology but also build a business case around it. We're live in six cities, generating positive margins, allowing us to grow our business in a capital efficient way. 

We expect to become the first profitable AV company, and in the process, be able to scale faster than anyone else.

Attending the Goldman Sachs One Million Black Women: Black in Business Senior Leadership Luncheon left me energized and inspired! We honored the accomplishments of our 5th cohort of 146 brilliant entrepreneurs from nearly 30 states, who span diverse industries from wellness to retail. I particularly enjoyed the tableside conversation on career growth and leadership, moderated by program scholar Sonia Ballantyne, founder of Sonia's Vokalized Kreations. Her business specializes in luxury gift arrangements using more than 75% locally-sourced items. 

To date, this program has positively impacted the lives of over 700 Black women, with 65% of alumni experiencing revenue growth and nearly half creating new jobs in the past year. As these achievements highlight the significant influence of the program on both individual careers and the broader economy, Iâ€™m excited to see what this yearâ€™s graduates will accomplish next.

After 17 incredible years at P&G, I am setting off on a new chapter. This journey has been invaluable, shaped by amazing mentors, colleagues, teams, and partners. As I look ahead with pride, gratitude, and excitement, it is time to pause and thank those who have taught me invaluable lessons.

- Leadership is a Service: True leadership means empowering your team, fostering trust, and being a guide and mentor, unleashing the best in everyone. I am deeply grateful to the remarkable leaders who offered their time and wisdom, and inspired me. Some of those very special leaders: Shailesh Jejurikar, Loic Tassel, Henry Karamanoukian, Suzy Lyon, Eddie Sukkari, Elvan Onal, Vanessa Prats, Antoine Brun, Mohamed Ismail, Uluc Ayik, Radu Maftei, Sophie Blum, Helene Bellamy, Carolina Rogoll Christophersen, Tankut Turnaoglu, Taide Guajardo, Alpay Alptekin, Michalis Hamalellis, Muhterem Yavas Ozkan and especially Aga Orlik whose legacy continues to inspire. Thank you!

- Winning Starts with Mindset: Success begins with the right mindset, striving for excellence, and pushing the boundaries beyond perceived limits. I have been very fortunate to have such individuals in my teams who embodied a winning mindset each morning. Some of those special individuals Mo Khalife, Elia Cazan, Or Ellencweig, Santiago Piqueras, Dora Holczinger, Ana LakiÄ‡, Mariana Chaves, Ã–zgÃ¼ YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m, Svetlana Zhuravleva, Danny Hsiao, Frank Zhang Thank you!

- Recipe Lies in Adaptability and Integrity: In todayâ€™s evolving world, the key ingredients for impact are adaptability, openness to new ideas, and a commitment to lifelong learning. Navigating change with integrity is what leads to lasting transformation. I am thankful for those who have walked alongside me through immense challenges in China, Europe's unstable political climate, worldwide consumer inflation, organizational hurdles during the pandemic, and increasing force for good responsibilities for brands. Some of those amazing individuals Andany Belen, ANNE-GAEL PENHELEUX, Daniela Cima, Vincenzo Tomarchio, Agnieszka Nowak, Ayca Izgi, Robert van Bemmelen, Leslie Coder, Candy Deng, Fanny Fan Thank you! 

Time is the ultimate currency, and enjoying the ride together is the ultimate wisdom. Thanks to all P&G colleagues and agency partners who were part of such a joyful ride with me.

Hereâ€™s to an exciting and purposeful new chapter ahead!

Ladies and gentlemen, distinguished guests, and members of the Zion Cathedral Church community,

I am truly honored to receive the prestigious Black Excellence Award. This moment is a testament to perseverance, resilience, and the support of my community.

I want to express my gratitude to the Zion Cathedral Church for recognizing and celebrating Black excellence. Your commitment to uplifting individuals is commendable, and it cultivates a society that values diversity and inclusivity.

I am grateful to my family and friends who have been pillars of strength and encouragement. Your love and belief in me have propelled me to overcome obstacles. This award is as much yours as it is mine.

I am deeply grateful to God for blessing me with this award and the opportunity to be a blessing to others. His guidance has helped me navigate challenges and seize opportunities.

To the trailblazers and change-makers who have paved the way for Black excellence, I stand on your shoulders with immense gratitude. I promise to honor your legacy by uplifting and inspiring others.

This award is a celebration of the collective achievements of the Black community. It reminds us that our voices matter, our contributions are invaluable, and our potential knows no bounds. Let's continue striving for excellence and creating a world of equality and justice.

In conclusion, I want to thank the Zion Cathedral Church for this incredible honor. I am filled with a renewed sense of purpose to use this platform to uplift and empower others. With God's guidance, I am committed to spreading love, hope, and opportunities.

Together, let us continue to celebrate and uplift Black excellence every day. Thank you all, and may we march forward on the path of progress and unity.

Whew, that feeling when something youâ€™ve been working hard on finally makes its debut! ðŸ™Œ ðŸŽ‰ Us marketers know bringing a new product to market is never easy and there are countless hours that go into every aspect of turning an idea on paper into a tangible offering in real life â€“ from the work involved to build the product but also to figuring out how to â€œtellâ€ and â€œsellâ€ it. There was a lot that went into the â€œhowâ€ behind this achievement and it was truly a quest â€“ but what a reward to see it out there in the world! And it couldnâ€™t have happened without the smart, passionate, dedicated and hard-working folks I get to work with every day at GeoBlue as well as our colleagues at MetLife and our agency partners who supported us in this endeavor. I told the NAM Power Products Industrialization group that if we got 100% on #OneVoice (our employee feedback survey), I would dye my hair green. And the team DELIVERED! ðŸ‘ 

One thing I love about Schneider Electric is the fact that they CARE about employee engagement. I've been part of many working groups, task forces, etc in my time here. 

One of my first years here, the old Knightdale office had one of the lower engagement scores in the US - leadership came by to host a town hall to ask us what we could do better! We have since moved to a beautiful new office here at the #RaleighHub, and return to people has been really great.. seeing so many familiar faces (maybe not familiar hair ðŸ˜‚) after covid is really energizing. 

Side note - I haven't shared here, but I am the new OneHub leader in Raleigh! Excited to continue making this one of the top sites in the US and one of the best places to work!

Back to the importance of employee feedback surveys though.. I told my team "this is your opportunity to tell the company your boss sucks." And while I genuinely hope that is not their impression of me, I'm excited to learn what I can do to make their lives easier, and to make their jobs feel a little less like work. And I'm all about having a little fun along the way ðŸ˜œ What's the point if you're not having some fun?

People are definitely any company's greatest commodity. Your boss and your company should be listening. So when you are part of an organization that does listen, you get what you put into it. Answer those survery questions, raise your hand for that task force.. own your solutions! 

Are you green with envy? Definitely check our career website to become a fellow #SEgreatpeople 

#schneiderelectric #lifeison #servantleadership #employeeengagement #bestplacetowork

While in high school, I cleaned apartment buildings and harvested broccoli in the fields of California. To support my family, I worked 2 jobs simultaneously while attending California State University - East Bay full-time.

Earlier in June, I had the opportunity to visit our Hong Kong office and spend time with both colleagues and clients. 

As part of the Asia Apex Symposium, I participated in a discussion on â€œResilience and Opportunities: Global Capital Markets Outlookâ€ alongside Yan Liu and Wilfred Yiu, Deputy CEO of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX). It is exciting to take part in such rich discussion about the pick-up in capital markets activity, learn about the innovations at the Exchange and discuss how our clients are approaching their large concentrated single stock positions pre- and post-IPO. 

It was great to connect with many of my colleagues, including joining Sara Naison-Tarajano and Ling Pong for the Asset & Wealth Management Womenâ€™s Network roundtable and welcoming our Wealth Management interns who have joined us in Hong Kong!
