Infosys is an #emotion
Once an #infoscion, forever an #infoscion
You can take a person out of Infosys but you cannot take Infosys out of the person!!

These statements aptly sum up what #infosys means to me. It is the same emotion that made me return to this firm in 2015 and serve it again. However, as they say, all good things come to an end and unfortunately that time for me has come!

In this phase, I want to call out some of the incredible #leaders who make and have made #Infosys what it is and some of my team members whom I have had the good fortune and privilege of leading.

Let me start with the 6 leaders who left a deep impression with me, an impression that I have observed, imbibed and hopefully internalised.

1. Sandeep Dadlani: Sandeep is the reason for me rejoining the firm. Although I had worked with him for a very brief assignment; he wanted me to join back and helped revive the #saleseffectiveness department in the company. His energy, his #passion, his #drive is second to none and I have forever indebted to him for having brought me back.

2. Deepak Padaki: A #founder among the #nonfounders. Deepak was a personification of everything I have heard or known of our #founders. #Businesssavvy, #downtoearth, #softspoken but #purposeful are some of the many values that I was inspired through him.

3. Mohit Joshi: There are leaders who grow on you and continue to wow you with #values and #behaviours that astound and inspire you. Mohit is one such leader and I count myself lucky to have had the opportunity to serve under him.

4. Pravin Rao: #approachable and #excellence are 2 words which would sum up my respect and feelings for UBP as we fondly know him. The word #downtoearth can be defined by him. His story of the sheer diversity in experience and the lives he has touched is an #inspiration to say the least.

5. Jayesh Sanghrajka: Imagine an extremely strong #businesssavvy CFO, who is #worldclass in his domain and now combine that with #extreme people skills and that in a nut shell is Jayesh. People would do anything to just meet him, but I had the honour of reporting to him and boy, what an experience it was.

6. #Nandannilekani: One of the regrets I had in the combined first 13 years of my experience at Infosys was not being able to work with our founders, but clearly #destiny had saved the best for the last. It was only in the last 1.5 years that I had the absolute honour of meeting and working with Nandan (also known as the #CTO of #India) and what a ride it was. #visionary, #approachable, #responsive, #actionoriented, the list can be endless but it has been one of my most cherished memory of working with him in this stint.

Friday 28 June was the last working day of mine in this stint and I while I am of course excited about my next move, I cannot help but thank Infosys and the countless #infoscions who make the place what it is.

I talk about dreaming big a lot. But dreaming doesn't mean much if you never put them into action.

Myself and CEO of Lush Decor Home Decor, Paola Peretti, have our sights set on becoming the leading home decor company.

We know that this kind of goal requires more than just hard work â€“ it demands strategic goal-setting and unwavering commitment.

So, how can you set and achieve big goals for your company (or even yourself)?

1/ Dream big, but break it down:

It's okay to have a massive, audacious goal â€“ in fact, it's encouraged!
But to make it achievable, you need to break it down into smaller, measurable ones.

Set quarterly, annual, and 3-5 year targets that ladder up to your ultimate vision.

2/ Align your team: Your big goal should be the company's goal.

How can every team member understand how their role contributes to that larger mission?

3/ Celebrate the wins, big and small:

The journey can be long and challenging, so it's crucial to celebrate your progress along the way.
â€¢ Did you hit a key milestone?
â€¢ Did someone on your team go above and beyond?

Take time to recognize and reward these victories â€“ they'll keep your momentum strong and your spirits high.

4/ Measure, adjust, repeat: Big goals require big data. 

Consistently track your key performance indicators and be willing to course-correct if something isn't working!

5/ Embrace the discomfort:

Let's be real â€“ chasing a goal can be scary, uncomfortable, and downright daunting at times.

But that's where the magic happens. Embrace the butterflies, the late nights, and the leaps of faith.

They're all signs that you're pushing yourself and your company to new heights.

Lush Decor's goal is more than numbers â€“ it's about the impact we want to make, the lives we want to touch, and the legacy we want to leave.

And with a clear vision, a strategic plan, and an unstoppable team, I know we'll get there.

So dream big, my friends, and don't be afraid to set goals that scare you.

Thanks for reading!

column8:
The average wait time in the U.S. for patients to see a physician is 26 days, a 24% increase since 2004. Our friends at WakeMed recently showed that two techniquesâ€”breaking up old processes and embracing self-scheduling toolsâ€”can make quite a difference. All told, their approach has led to an increase of 75,000 visits annually, increasing outpatient revenue by 21%.
 
WakeMed used Epic analytics to identify the causes of scheduling bottlenecks, finding stringent scheduling processesâ€”like what time of day new patients can be seenâ€”to be a key culprit. While using that data to drive change, WakeMed embraced a better digital experience for patients, using Fast Pass to automatically offer appointments to waitlisted patients and using self-scheduling to help patients book more appointments without straining scheduling staff.
 
Congrats, folks!
 
Read more: https://lnkd.in/gcQ_XiWv

#healthcare #healthIT #capacity

AI therapy chatbots are increasingly being utilized as accessible tools to provide mental health support. They offer benefits like availability 24/7, no wait times, and customized support. 

However, challenges remain, such as the lack of human empathy and accountability, and the potential risks of privacy breaches. Despite their limitations, they have the potential to complement conventional therapy and help address the global demand for mental healthcare.

#AIHealth #MentalHealthMatters #DigitalHealth

In what feels like a genuinely bittersweet moment, I want to share that I will be closing a very meaningful chapter of my career in the next few weeks. After 2.5 years & (most recently) leading device-based Digital Wallets, I will be leaving JPMorganChase to pursue a new adventure. 

Working in the financial services industry for the past 4 years has been nothing short of life-changing, and I am so grateful to have had the opportunity to be in a space that is so intellectually stimulating, impactful, and professionally and personally developmental.

More importantly, I met some of the most incredible leaders and colleagues I have ever had the pleasure of working with. While it would be impossible to list out all of the people who have supported and partnered with me in this recent role, I want to call out a few of the ones I worked with especially closely: 

* My leadership/management team at JPMC: Mandar Mangalvedhekar, Nicole Black, Jon Rosner, Saad Khatri, Alisa (Becker) Hermann, Kelley McDermott. 
* My partner in crime on all things Digital Wallets: Mauricio Takahashi. 
* The fantastic humans whom I have been fortunate enough to manage throughout my time at the firm: Ryan Laughlin, Lilli R., Rohith Perumalla, Kai Lo, Arun Murugavel, and Jordan Lewis. 
* Inspiring technology leaders who have pushed me: Aaratee Rao, Nirmal Srinivasan, Devron Thompson, Raghu Vudathu, and many more. 

I look forward to sharing what is next for me, but in the meantime, I will post one of the many roles that are available on my current team in the comments section. Also, please check out the careers site to learn more. Anjana Menon

As we come together to honor #Juneteenth, I am filled with gratitude for the visible support I am witnessing from my friends and colleagues. This day holds immense historical weight because it marks the emancipation of enslaved Black people in the United States. But it is just as important that the celebration is a testament to the progress occurring as part of the unwavering fight for equality.
 
As the challenging moments grow this year regarding the discussion of equality and rights, we should lean into our shared humanity to keep us unified. We should double our commitment to listening to each otherâ€™s lived experiences, while finding opportunities to highlight our similarities, and embrace the benefitsÂ of diversity. Our collective strength lies in our ability to uplift one another, regardless of race, gender, culture, or orientation.
 
As a Senior Vice President at Sempra, I stand appreciative and humbly alongside you all. Let us continue this journey toward a better tomorrow, where every individual feels welcomed and thrives. Happy Juneteenth!

It is with mixed emotions that I announce my departure from Virginia Mason Franciscan Health after 5.5 fruitful years. Despite challenges like the pandemic, multiple reorganizations and financial hurdles, I am proud of OUR achievements:
- The Center for Cardiovascular Health stands out as our most integrated service line.
- We expanded with an active ECMO program and introduced an LVAD program.
- Our quality remains top-notch, with all 3 CT surgery programs earning 3 Star STS recognition nationally
- Our program's growth made us one of the largest in the Pacific Northwest and added key partnerships.
- We launched a cardiovascular disease fellowship program, only the second in our 4-state region 
- Honored in 2023 to have been the only top 50 ranked CV program by US News & World Report in WA, AK, MT, ID, and OR.
None of this would have been possible without our dedicated TEAM across the organization. A big thank you to my colleagues and executive leaders who supported us throughout. A special thank you to our CEO Ketul J. Patel for enabling me to perform to the best of my abilities
Wishing the organization continued success! (I will be watching closely:) Keith Sprague Thomas Kruse David Nosacka James Terwilliger Bhanu Gupta, MD, MSc Robert J. Moraca, MD Mariko Harper MD MS FACC Zhang Ming Dianne Aroh, FACHE Kerry Shannon Syd Bersante David Schultz

column8:
âœ¨ Meet your Lennyâ€™s Newsletter Fellows âœ¨

When I announcedÂ the launch of my fellowship programÂ three months ago, I had no clue how this idea would landâ€”much less how popular it would turn out to be.Â The caliber of applicants and the effort they all put into their applications was beyond anything I couldâ€™ve hoped for. I received over 1,600 applications, many of which came with heart-melting messages, laugh-out-loud-funny videos, and even a ChatGPT injection attempt ðŸ¤£

I read every application, watched every video, and looked at every writing sample. I wasnâ€™tÂ exactlyÂ sure what profile I was looking for when I started, but I knew I wanted to find people who were senior enough to have had firsthand experience building world-class, successful, and impactful products (to have real-life lessons to share with others), while also not so senior that this fellowship wouldnâ€™t meaningfully impact their career trajectory.

Iâ€™m excited to share the inaugural Lennyâ€™s Newsletter Fellows: Tara Seshan, Natalie Rothfels, and Jules Walter.

Tara has spent the past 10 years building software to solve hard problems in health care, finance, and climate. She spent two years as Head of Product at Watershed, seven years as an early PM and Business Lead at Stripe, and founded a health-care startup as an early Thiel Fellow. These days, sheâ€™s working on a new startup in the creative-tools space. She likes to throwÂ pancake block partiesÂ in San Francisco, record a podcast calledÂ The Red QueenÂ with her friends, and write about the friction between our private and working selves atÂ Working Assumptions.

Natalie is an executive coach working with co-founders and leadership teams to strengthen their relationships and build less toxic organizations. After a decade of building ed-tech products at Khan Academy and Quizlet, she felt the gravitational pull toward tending to the hearts of the humans behind the products. She is perpetually trying to sew the perfect pair of pants (still no dice) and recently launched a facilitation tool calledÂ The Ripple Deck. Sorry in advance if she asks how youâ€™re feeling and expects a real answerâ€”you can blame that on being a Certified Internal Family Systems Practitioner and a facilitator for Stanfordâ€™s â€œTouchy Feelyâ€ course.

Jules is a product leader at Google working on Gemini. Previously he was at YouTube, where he launched Primetime Channels with more than 40 streaming packages, such as NFL Sunday Ticket. Prior to Google, Jules spent four years as a product leader at Slack on their growth and monetization teams. While there, he was a key contributor to Slackâ€™s 10x growth. Jules is passionate about building helpful products at scale and improving inclusion and diversity in the industry. He serves on the boards ofÂ CodePathÂ andÂ Black Product Managers, two organizations he co-founded to support underrepresented people in tech. He lives with his wife and two kids in Berkeley, California.

Please join me in welcoming Tara, Natalie, and Jules ðŸ‘

column8:
I had the pleasure of joining the Aspen Ideas Festival last week to share views on the impact of AI on the workforce and the benefits that weâ€™re beginning to see. In a discussion withÂ President and CEO of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Mary C. Daly and moderated byÂ @CNBCâ€™s Julia Boorstin weÂ exploredÂ this transformational technology and its potential to change the way we learn and work.
 
As I told the crowd in Aspen, AI will redefine how we work.Â The revolution will be across the board, leading the path to autonomy â€“ from airlines using AI as a co-pilot to maintenance workers using AI as a partner to operators in in the energy sector managing safe operations with AI assistance. 
 
There is no question that AI will be a disruptive force, and I believe most of the disruption will be positive. Since it enables both upskilling and reskilling of workers, it will be key to the future of shaping the industrial workforce and our economy. 
 
Today we must begin reimagining the world with AI, so as the technology progresses, we can progress along with it. Iâ€™m optimistic.
 
If youâ€™d like to watch, you can seeÂ the entire discussion here: https://lnkd.in/eDwcgaTW. Our dialogue starts at 33:17 andÂ follows an interesting conversation on AI and Navigating Tomorrowâ€™s Economy, which features CEOs from Blackrock and GE Vernova.

Better Together: Generative AI, also known as GenAI, has the ability to generate new and unique outputs based on recognized patterns. It is revolutionizing industries such as healthcare, finance, and manufacturing. Predictive analytics uses historical data and statistical modeling techniques to predict future outcomes and behaviors, enabling businesses to make informed decisions. The combination of these technologies can enhance business processes. Exploring and Learning about these cutting-edge technologies together will allow you to think about data-driven business transformation.

I find this demo quite impressive (albeit without seeing anything more of it than an image and an assertion), but even if every bit of it comes true, I don't draw at all the same conclusion. 

In the end, programming is just how we talk with computers, how we tell or teach them to do what we want. Every time there is a new simplification of development that makes it easier for people to "program," two things happen:  less experienced people can develop programs that once took a great deal of expertise â€“ that is, they can ask computers to new and harder things â€“ and the frontier that those with expertise are exploring advances much faster, and things get complicated, iterative, and exploratory again. Just think back to  the transition from assembly language to compilers, from compilers to interpreters, from interpreters to systems like the web that made it possible to specify things in HTML and a bit of glue code that once would have taken a developer. What happened in each case? Programmers who did the old thing were obsolete only if they didn't learn the new thing, and more than that, help to invent the new thing. Opportunity increases faster than obsolescence.

column8:
It's a difficult thing in the digital world for banks to attract young consumers â€” and garner the loyalty of kids while they're young. 

U.S. Bank has found a promising solution through a partnership with fintech Greenlight. By integrating Greenlight's accounts and services into its own mobile banking app, U.S. Bank aims to attract the next generation of customers while providing valuable financial education and practical money management experience for kids

The partnership addresses a critical gap in traditional banking offerings: the lack of transaction accounts for children. With Greenlight's debit card and money app, kids as young as 10 can learn to handle money and transact cashlessly, all while being subject to parental oversight. Parents can set spending limits, monitor transactions, and establish savings goals for their children, fostering financial responsibility from an early age.

U.S. Bank sees two key benefits in this partnership. First, it differentiates the bank's "Bank Smartly" accounts, potentially attracting and retaining depositors who value financial education for their children. Second, by engaging with kids through Greenlight, the bank hopes to establish itself as the go-to institution when these young customers are ready for their first checking account.

Greenlight's Brandon Horne, general manager of partnerships, emphasizes that the company's bank and credit union partnerships are an additional channel for growth, not a strategic shift. By embedding the parental experience in the bank's app, Greenlight gives financial institutions more ownership in the customer experience and facilitates a smooth transition as kids approach adulthood.

Learn more in the full article by Steve Cocheo:

If you're looking for an experienced Agile Coach, I am now available for full time work!

I don't really like to talk about myself, but every now and then It's important we put ourselves forward, right? 

Did you know that I'm PSM3 certified from Scrum dot org, representing the highest level of depth and mastery of the Scrum Framework? 

I'm also an SPC6 with Scaled Agile. 

But who cares about certifications, right? 

What's more interesting is that I've trained and certified hundreds of people in these two frameworks, and worked as a coach and Scrum Master for nearly a decade drawing on these, and many other concepts, to improve the value delivery of organizations. Everything from team creation through to organizational transformation.

Lately, I'm most well-known for, #DysfunctionMapping, a tool now used around the world by thousands of people to find and solve problems and demonstrate measurable results. 

Built from my strong belief in framework agnostic, empirical coaching, my focus has been on taking what I've learned and using it to level up Scrum and Agile practitioners the world over. 

But I'm going to be honest, as much as I've loved travelling the world for conferences, running workshops and speaking at communities of practice, I'm really starting to miss working with real teams to solve real problems. 

So if you've been thinking about taking on a new coach, feel free to reach out for a chat and see if we might make a good team. 

And if you're looking for something more temporary, I'm happy to chat about a Dysfunction Mapping workshop, or part time consulting engagement too.

Most B2B companies are still running their content strategy like it's 2012. Pushing whitepapers and webinars to drive MQLs is outdated, ineffective, and way too expensive. Here's why:

Metadata published a report analyzing $37M ad spend on lead gen campaigns.

The result: only 0.2%(!) of MQLs converted to closed-won deals. 

That means you need 500 leads to acquire a new customerâ€”which is painfully inefficient given the average cost per lead of $123.

The driving force behind this is the significant shift in buyer behavior:

1. Buyers now prefer to educate themselves at their own pace, diving deep into content to find solutions to their challenges (without giving up their email address or phone number in a lead form).

2. The buying journey has become more dynamic and unpredictable, with dark social channels playing a crucial role in how buyers gather information.

3. Buying committees have nearly tripled in size over the past decade, leading to longer sales cycles and a greater need for multiple touchpoints.

_____

Your content strategy needs to reflect these changes. Here's how:

âœ… Conduct interviews with your 10 best customers and analyze 20 recent sales call recordings to identify pain points and objections.

âœ… Develop content pillars and topics that revolve around these pain points and objections.

âœ… Identify 3-5 internal subject matter experts (SMEs) who are comfortable on camera and willing to build their LinkedIn presence. Preferably include 1-2 people from the executive team.

âœ… Conduct bi-weekly interviews with each SME. Turn each interview recording into 1 long-form article, 4+ video clips and 10+ LinkedIn posts.

âœ… Publish this content on the personal LinkedIn profiles of your SMEs (3-5x per week). Publish the article and video clips on the website, repurpose the interview recording for YouTube and create a weekly newsletter with the best insights from the interviews.

âœ… After 2 months, start running LinkedIn Thought Leader Ads* to promote the top-performing LinkedIn posts to your target accounts.

*Paid social should mainly be used for content distribution, not lead generation. Would you rather pay $150 for 100 decision-makers to read your case study, or $150 for just one person to ð˜®ð˜¢ð˜ºð˜£ð˜¦ read your whitepaper?

âœ… Launch an employee advocacy program to turn the rest of your employees into an organic marketing channel.

_____

Buyer behavior evolvesâ€”so should your content strategy.

It's important for leaders to take time to learn, remind ourselves of our important mission and meld as a team. Last week was an incredible opportunity for all. We met with leading researchers, scientists and clinicians at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia to connect what we do at Labcorp with the advances they are working on everyday for children who are facing life threatening diseases and health challenges. We also took the time to think about the future of customer experience with the amazing Donald Chesnut, MS and connect  with a few of our local team members at the Philadelphia Phillies game. These experiences all culminated in the inspiration to work even harder for our patients, teams and customers.

At CHOP, we were in awe of the science, but as important, the dedication, commitment and humility of some of the world's leaders in their fields. I left inspired that the CHOP team and the broader community of pediatric researchers and scientists will find new and safer treatments for brain cancer and much more.

Thank you to the CHOP team: Liz Barone, Dr. Stephen Hunger, Dr. Mateusz Koptyra, Dr. Johannes van der Loo, Dr. Stephan Grupp, Dr. Jessica Foster, Dr. Michael Fisher, Dr. Jonathan ChenÂ &Â Dr. Vivek Allada. You inspired us.

This year, we celebrate a monumental milestoneâ€”Bel Fuse Inc.'s 75th anniversary! Founded by my grandfather and now led by my father, Dan Bernstein as CEO, Bel Fuse stands as a testament to enduring success and unwavering commitment to core values.

Growing up, I had the privilege of witnessing firsthand the dedication, resilience, and integrity that fueled the family business. Here are some fundamental principles that have been passed down through generations, shaping not only Bel's journey but also my approach as an Operating Partner in the private equity space:

- Respecting the Team: Bel has always believed in treating employees like family. This deep respect for the team has fostered a culture of loyalty, collaboration, and mutual growth. It's a principle I hold dear, knowing that a company's true strength lies in its people. 

- Running the Business the Right Way: Integrity has always been at the heart of Bel Fuse. My grandfather's mantra of doing business the right wayâ€”fairly, ethically, and transparentlyâ€”has been a cornerstone of success. This ethos guides my interactions and decisions as I work with founders to build sustainable and ethical businesses.

- Balancing Conservatism with Aggression: One of the most valuable lessons I've learned is the art of balancing conservative strategies with calculated risks. My father has and continues to excel at identifying moments to be bold while maintaining a prudent approach. This balance is crucial in driving growth without compromising stability.

- Consistent Leadership and Values: The importance of consistent leadership and adherence to core values cannot be overstated. At Bel Fuse, leadership is not just about steering the company but embodying the values that have been their foundation. I strive to bring this consistency to portcos I partner with, ensuring that the companies I support stay true to their roots while evolving for future success.

As I reflect on these invaluable lessons, I am filled with pride and gratitude. They have not only shaped Bel Fuse's legacy but also equipped me to support other founders on their journeys. In my current role, I leverage these insights to help entrepreneurs navigate challenges, seize opportunities, and build businesses that stand the test of time.

Here's to 75 years of Bel Fuseâ€”and to many more years of leadership, integrity, and success!

#BelHistory #Leadership #FamilyBusiness #Values #PrivateEquity #Legacy #BusinessGrowth #EmployeeFirst #CustomerFocus #Innovation

If tech is for all, why is there still such a gender gap? 
What keeps girls from entering and staying in tech. And what role does the transformation of work we undergo play? I am delighted to be participating in a panel at the Wave Fellowship Graduation ceremony at Google Switzerland! The panel will discuss the state of tech careers as we look to the future of technology and the role we all play in shaping it.

Spent 2 days last week at The Disney Institute learning about service excellence. 

Executive summary: To achieve exceptional service results , one has  to excel in three areas:
- careful design of new service and/ or redesign of existing services 
- intentional and repeated flawless delivery of service, consistency is key
- construction of a recovery safety net ( preferably immediately) when service experience doesnâ€™t go as planned. 

The above applies to external (customer facing) and internal (stakeholder facing) as they are inherently inter-connected. 

Grateful for the opportunity - thank you UHG! I am motivated, inspired and recharged to be a better leader, a team mate with intentional collaboration and an evangelizing internal stakeholder focused on nurturing an exceptional service excellence environment.

BSOTS is back with another Seven To Consider!

In 2013, The Spring Up E.P. by Shad + Skratch Bastid was released under a Creative Commons license.  That E.P.'s opening cut was co-produced by DJ Jazzy Jeff.  (And this is why I insist on digging through the CC music crates).  Show no. 184 opens with that one and closes with a drum and bass jam from Moki McFly's latest blocSonic release (winner of the 2024 Creative Commons Community Music Award for Album Of The Year). Now available wherever you get your podcasts.

Absolutely thrilled to share one of the most exhilarating experiences in business! Last week, I had the honor of standing on the platform as we rang the closing bell at the New York Stock Exchange for Navigator Gas (NVGS) in commemoration of their 10 years of trading. Looking over the trading floor, surrounded by the history and energy of the NYSE, I understood what it meant to see capitalism at its best where the belief that the free and fair markets offer every individual the chance to benefit from success. The adrenaline rush in that moment was truly indescribable!!

After we rang the bell, we were invited to sign the historic NYSE wall.Â As I added my name to a space filled with the names of so many visionaries and pioneers, I was overcome with a profound sense of pride and gratitude, feeling a deep connection to the legacy of excellence that defines the NYSE.
 
Finally, we were given a commemorative coin to mark the momentous occasion which symbolizes the agreement that formed the United Statesâ€™ first stock exchange.Â This beautiful keepsake is more than just a mementoâ€”itâ€™s a symbol of Navigator Gasâ€™s successes and the collective effort that has brought them to this point.

I want to extend a heartfelt thank you to the NYSE for this honor and to the amazing team at Navigator Gas for making this journey possible. A special thank you to Mads Peter Zacho, Oeyvind Lindeman, Dr. Heiko Fischer, Gary Chapman, Dag von Appen, Randy Giveans and the rest of the NVGS team for a truly unforgettable event! 

Hereâ€™s to the next decade and beyond! ðŸŽ‰

#NYSE #NavigatorGas #NVGS #BoardofDirectors

URGENT: Keep government from closing a landmark clinical trial for schizophrenia

As reported by The Baltimore Sun yesterday, the Maryland Department of Health, led by Dr. Laura Herrera Scott, has halted the only U.S. inpatient trial on ketogenic therapy for schizophrenia. After a 16-week review that revealed no health or safety concerns, the decision to shut down the study was based solely on the funding sources.

Given the limited availability of federal funding for mental health research, studies like Dr. Kellyâ€™s, funded by private foundations, are crucial. Among the dozen trials investigating ketogenic diets for serious mental illnesses, Dr. Kellyâ€™s research stands out as the sole trial of ketogenic therapy for schizophrenia available to inpatients, who typically suffer the most severe symptoms.

Roughly a dozen patients who had already volunteered were not allowed to participate after the study's closure. Isn't this a violation of patients' rights?

Three patient advocacy organizations, including one representing 750 Maryland psychiatrists, wrote to the health department to protest the decision. These pleas asking that the keto trial continue were ignored.

Help us get this decision reversed! Please sign and share Dr. Christopher Palmer's petition â€“ it takes less than 30 seconds. Sign here: https://chng.it/SbT7zHjNNz

Read and share the story from the Baltimore Sun: https://bit.ly/4ctVAKP

Watch and share our interview with the researcher leading the study, Deanna L. Kelly, PharmD, BCPP: https://lnkd.in/gMtCiS7X

Let's advocate for innovative science and better #mentalhealth treatments. Join us in ensuring patients get the choices they deserve.

column8: View my verified achievement from The Linux Foundation.

#Graduation season has just recently passed, and many new graduates and bright minds find themselves eagerly stepping into the professional world. It is seasons like this that I often think back to my own career and what I would have wanted to hear most when starting out. My advice to young professionals is to find the work thatÂ you're passionate about; for me, that was building relationships with people. Itâ€™s crucial to surround yourself with the folks you genuinely want to spend your career with, whether that means colleagues who share your values, leaders who you can learn from, or communities you most want to serve.
 
I remember Frostâ€™s old break room, the Copper Coin, where everyone gathered around 8:30 every morning before the start of each day. It was more than just a place for coffee â€“ it was where we connected with executives, listened to their stories and found new people to collaborate with. Those interactions were invaluable and formed the basis of my belief in the importance of community in the workplace. Offices and work environments certainly look different now than when I started out, which can make #networking feel inaccessible in our digital age. I encourage you to feel empowered to find and make those connections in a way that feels authentic and accessible to you. LinkedIn might even be the new Copper Coin for some folks today!
 
I often come back to a verse in Ephesians about â€œliving a life worthy of the calling you have received.â€ Even if your path differs from what you envisioned, the right people can make any job fulfilling. If, through our work, we help others become more successful, then we can truly say we've made a difference.

We had the wonderful opportunity to organize and host the â€œData and Analytics Weekâ€ at TIAA. This brought together industry experts, vendor partners and our very own TIAA associates.

Acronyms. We are all guilty of using them. 
Could they be affecting the rapport and trust you have with your network? 

In marketing, we'll talk about the KPIs, the OKRs, the ROI...

When we use "insider" terms and phrases that other people don't know, it can make them feel disconnected or even "stupid". 

Instead, simplify or explain what these terms mean so that you're using language that includes your audience. 

Building trust and rapport is the key to building and deepening all relationships. 

How are you showing up as a subject matter expert? 

Any additional tips or thoughts?

ð‡ðžð¥ð©ð¢ð§ð  ðð®ð¬ð¢ð§ðžð¬ð¬ðžð¬ ð€ðœð¡ð¢ðžð¯ðž ðˆð¦ð¦ðžðð¢ðšð­ðž ð–ð¢ð§ð¬ ð”ð¬ð¢ð§ð  ð€ðˆ (ð­ð¡ð«ð¨ð®ð ð¡ samvid.ai)

Businesses are built upon contracts, agreements, and reports, rich with facts and figures. Every business owner knows that critical knowledge obtained by summarizing and querying these documents can significantly boost productivity and mitigate risks. OpenAIâ€™s file_search API and Snowflakeâ€™s document AI offer vector and text search with RAG and client-specific models. These technologies improve the status quo but may not fully meet your day-to-day business needs.

Your businessâ€™ pain points might include:
âž¢ analyzing and forecasting data such as agricultural yield or financial projections.
âž¢ computing complex formulas such as shipping cost or carbon footprint from data in reports plus â€œworld knowledge.â€
âž¢ evaluating and negotiating contracts by assessing key levers and tradeoffs and leveraging historical data.

Serving these deeper needs requires high-precision data extraction and schema inference to enable computation and reasoning. Azure AI, DocSumo, and Eigen AI offer extraction, however, they are general extractors by document type. Whereas, hyper-customized extraction and reasoning wonâ€™t scale, and generic extraction of numerical and factual data, even with RAG, isnâ€™t good enough to reason with or compute from.

Iâ€™m helping samvid.ai push this envelope, with a product that scalably meets clientsâ€™ business needs, initially targeting SMBs. This tool extracts data from uploaded documents, infers schema with domain knowledge, and generalizes the ensuing high-level abstractions across domains. As table-stakes, we offer a 2-level nested summary and a chatbot over uploaded documents, with text and semantic search and RAG for baseline accuracy. We significantly improve precision over RAG by extracting the key facts (â€œessenceâ€) of the document into a knowledge graph and using OpenAIâ€™s or Anthropicâ€™s â€œfunction callingâ€ API to feed it back into the chatbot and reasoning engines. This ensures the accuracy required for customers in AgriTech, Logistics, Sustainability, and other domains. E.g., in Logistics, our system identifies discount tiers and surcharges for a parcel shipment based on dimensional weight (calculated weight based on package volume) and the dim factor specified in the contract, something RAG may miss.

With LLMs, we can reduce customer onboarding cost by distilling customer-agnostic â€œtemplatesâ€ from various types of extractors and extending these templates to other clients. This approach ensures that no clientâ€™s sensitive data is exposed to another, thus preserving privacy and isolation. This third-level application of AI gives us safe scalability while staying closely aligned to client needs. With this approach, we can create tailored extractors and implement diverse vertical use cases with low manual effort.

Please check out the demo video, or contact Ram Bala or Arun Rao for a full demo of these use cases.

column8: Thanks to United States Steel Corporation for hosting the next generation of decarbonized steel process innovators!

H2 Green Steel broke ground on the world's first full-scale green hydrogen steel plant in June 2022, with operations scheduled to begin in 2026. The technology cuts >90% of COâ‚‚ compared to conventional blast furnaces. The low-carbon steel comes at a price, and still, customers like BMW Group, Porsche AG, and Mercedes-Benz AG aren't just standing in line, some, like Mercedes, are even equity investors.

Equally important, by now H2GS is far from the only green hydrogen plant in the works. In 2022, two to three million tonnes of steel had been announced. A year later, over 40 million tonnes had been announced in Europe alone.

H2GS CTO Maria Persson Gulda joined us at a Climate Knowledge Initiative steel workshop last fall.

H2GS CEO Henrik Henriksson dropped by my climate class earlier this spring.

Today, the Columbia Business School CaseWorks case study was published, telling the story of H2GS https://gwagner.com/h2gs

Trying to bring about change at work 
but facing â€œnoiseâ€ or delays? Why?

With the right technical experts 

you can (relatively) easily introduce changes to an IT system, safety policy, or distribution process. 

These are non-linear, inactive systems that are known, ordered, and predictable.

Bringing about shifts in group behaviour is not the same as change in passive, mechanical systems.

Groups are active, dynamic ecosystems 
where patterns emerge as people interact, adapt or learn

and where change emerges from multiple parts, not just from top-down.

You must have the adaptive skills and Group Intelligence (GQ) to be able to navigate change in complex ecosystems.

column8:
âš ï¸ CAUTION: Critical thinking ahead!

The reason I focus so heavily on organization design is because the shape of the organization predisposes the experience that will be delivered. This is not an original thought: It's Conway's Law. (https://lnkd.in/gvew7i7B).

And the thing about Conway's Law is: It's a *law*. You're offering *will* reflect the shape of the organization that created it. Companies talk about how they don't want to 'ship their org chart.' They don't have a choice. So, make sure that org chart is what you want to ship.

And what's spurring this post is I just watched Nan Yu's 20-minute presentation from Config on this very subject, where he challenges the orthodoxy of product/feature teams, and encourages people to *think critically* about what they want to build/offer, and shape their organizations to deliver that. 
https://lnkd.in/g4SgYPur

The only bit of push-back I have for Nan (if he sees this post), is when he questions "Why is every team 5-8 people?," and cites Andy Grove's commentary about 5-9 direct reports for why this is the case. Reporting lines are not the reason for keeping it to 5-8 people. Instead, it's wise to invoke another law, Metcalfe's Law (https://lnkd.in/gS99jrEB), which shows that when you grow the a team, the number of connections within the team grows exponentially. So, while a team of 5 requires 10 links to stay connected, a team of 12 requires 66 links, which is unmanageable.

What a journey! Over the past couple of weeks, Thrivent moved two very important steps closer to forming Thrivent Bank, with approvals from the Utah Department of Financial Institutions and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Iâ€™m so impressed by and grateful for the incredible talent and unwavering dedication of our banking leadership team as we navigated a complex process with a vision grounded in genuinely client-centric banking. I couldnâ€™t be prouder of these recent accomplishments or more excited to partner with the Thrivent Credit Union team in the year ahead.

Ideally, someone other than you should be objectively measuring and reporting on your progress. If you're not hitting your targets, that's another problem that needs to be diagnosed and solved. There are many successful, creative people who aren't good at execution. They succeed because they forge symbiotic relationships with highly reliable task-doers.

That's all there is to it!

Remember that all 5 Steps proceed from your values. Your values determine what you want, i.e., your goals. Also keep in mind that the 5 Steps are iterative. When you complete one step, you will have acquired information that will most likely lead you to modify the other steps. When you've completed all five, you'll start again with a new goal. If the process is working, your goals will change more slowly than your designs, which will change more slowly than your tasks.

One last important point: You will need to synthesize and shape well. The first three steps--setting goals, identifying problems, and then diagnosing them--are synthesizing (by which I mean knowing where you want to go and what's really going on). Designing solutions and making sure that the designs are implemented are shaping. 

#principleoftheday

I have colleagues that have moved on before me. I am sharing my farewell email as I want to make sure this note gets to them too! 

Thank you to Sofia Calderon for organizing my farewell party. It was so great to see so many people I love and appreciate before my departure.

Here is the email:


Today is my last day at SEE. I could not go away without sharing my deep appreciation for each one of you. 
 
You all have had a profound impact on my life. You have, in the last 17 years, shaped me into the person I am, and I feel immense gratitude for that. 
 
I'm not only saying goodbye to a job or a company, I'm saying goodbye to the people who helped me become a citizen of the United States, to the people who supported me throughout my 3 pregnancies, to the people who prayed for my daughter and me when she was in the hospital for 2 weeks, to the people that opened the door for my husband to develop his chef skills at work. I'm saying goodbye to the folks who put people's safety and well-being first, before the job. This company gave me the opportunity to travel the world and meet amazing colleagues in Brazil, Mexico, Ecuador, Venezuela, Portugal, India, Spain, Turkey, Canada, people that despite the physical distance, have kept close and we have nurtured our friendships. So with that said (and the many things I didn't because this email can get VERY long if I do), you can only imagine how hard it is for me to take this next step in my career.
 
I'm entering a new chapter in my life which is hard to believe. I can only thank God for putting you all in my path. I am leaving a piece of my heart behind because of the people I will not get to work with on a daily basis that I genuinely admire and appreciate. No amount of words can thank you enough but I hope that just in these few, you all hear me say to each one of you THANK YOU SO MUCH!

I met a founder who said no to $250K at McKinseyâ€” & regretted it. â€œI had no idea what I was doing.â€ 14 years later, heâ€™s built a $150M ARR unicorn:

Blake is differentâ€” he spent 4 years fighting Al-Qaeda in Iraq.

He was responsible for the lives of 32 soldiers. 

Back home, after a Harvard MBA he tried consulting, but couldnâ€™t do it.

He wanted something bigger.

He started a startupâ€”but knew little about business and nothing about tech. 

â€œI was technically homeless at the time. I was sleeping on my buddyâ€™s couch. I had declined $250K/ year at McKinsey... I had no idea what I was doing.â€

2 years and multiple pivots later, he launched ID.me, an ID verification platform. 

It helped veterans access veteran-specific discounts from brands like Under Armourâ€” & helped brands increase loyalty, conversion, and cart size. 

It grew to 2M users in 1 year.

Today, 130M Americans have an account.

ID.me does $150M in revenue, at 80% gross margins, growing 30% per year. 

Blake raised $400M and his company is worth more than $1B.

But it took 14 years & it could have gone a different way.

I asked him if heâ€™d ever thought about going back and taking that McKinsey job. 

â€œAbsolutely.â€

â€œBut I couldnâ€™tâ€” combat just changed me.â€

Itâ€™s not just the money or the impact. 

Itâ€™s the desire to create. To build something from scratch.

Most founders I know havenâ€™t gone to warâ€” but they feel the same drive.

Thereâ€™s nothing quite like turning an idea into reality.

Thereâ€™s nothing quite like going from zero to one.

/// 
Listen to the full episode on The Product Market Fit Show.

I have been in the ecosystem of tech trends and futurists for decades. While the substance of the ideas and trends has changed over time, the key to progress remains the same: 
 
Keep. Innovating.
 
This was the theme of my recent keynote address at the 2024 Oracle Summit where I was privileged to speak on behalf of Deloitte. With an audience of industry leaders, I discussed the macro forces that drive greater simplicity, intelligence, and abundance in the technologies that shape our world.
 
Act one of the proverbial play was a look back and forward on the macro technology trends shaping the future of business, government, and society.Â Act two focused on six implications/recommendation specific to AI:
 
â— Capability evolution:Â expanding (and converging) modality and capacity.Â With the point that image, video, audio, text, etc. all add nuance and insight to reasoning and perception.Â Super-charged as they are layered with context (cultural, functional, personal, etc.)
â— Hardware is eating the world:Â A play on Marc Andreesenâ€™s credo, looking at how infrastructure is moving from utility/afterthought to a strategic fulcrum.Â In the cloud, on the edge, and in the next-gen of end-user devices
â— Hyper hybrid futures:Â Multi-models (beyond LLMâ€™s), architectures for flexibility and fine tuning, and agentric patterns
â— Data foundations:Â perhaps the most important headline:Â the HUGE importance of data strategy, management, and governance.Â For 1st, 2nd, and 3rd party dataâ€¦as well as potential future business models
â— Clock speed++:Â The rise of DevEx w/out borders; AI + cloud + cyber supported by platforms + flow + culture/talent
â— â€œFull contactâ€ leadership/sponsorship:Â Oppenheimer-esque enterprise initiatives.Â Beyond SteerCo consensus or â€˜success theaterâ€™
 
My advice to the leaders to the room is my advice for all of us â€“ be the force that drives us all forward, stay curious, and keep innovating. 

Huge shoutout to Pavel Krumkachev, Mauro Schiavon, Drew Scaggs, D`Arcy Mathias, So Chan (Hong), Christopher Winn, Corinne Johnson, Vincent Senawi , Jason Maynard and the rest of thethe team who helped bring the event to life!

Ferrari is accelerating its journey towards carbon neutrality with the installation of a new 1 MW solid oxide hydrogen fuel cell plant at its Maranello facilities, built by Bloom Energy. This innovative plant now provides 5% of the energy required for Ferrariâ€™s production activities, significantly cutting fuel consumption and emissions.

The new fuel cell plant represents a major step forward in Ferrariâ€™s commitment to becoming carbon neutral by 2030. Compared to traditional CHP (Combined Heat and Power) cogeneration systems, this plant reduces gas requirements by approximately 20%, offering substantial energy savings. Additionally, it boasts flexibility in energy sources, including hydrogen, natural gas, biomethane, or a combination, converting fuel into electricity without combustion.

One of the most impressive benefits is the reduction of over 99% of pollution that contributes to smog and particulate matter, making this plant not only efficient but also environmentally friendly.

Ferrari CEO Benedetto Vigna commented, â€œFerrari is working harder than ever to achieve carbon neutrality by 2030, through the adoption of leading edge technologies and of a scientific approach that are written in our DNA. We are thrilled to partner with Bloom Energy, as both our Companies are highly committed to a decarbonization path, and proud to host its first European installationâ€

#Ferrari #BloomEnergy #HydrogenPower #CleanEnergy #CarbonNeutral #SustainableFuture #DrivingHydrogen

Just over 34 years ago I started at a company called Community Mutual Insurance Co (CMIC).  Little did I know what a career ride I would have. That company merged with the Associated Group to create the original company called Anthem, Inc. Anthem merged with several other BCBS licensees and ultimate became a publicly traded company in the early 2000's. We then acquired WellPoint and changed our corporate name to @WellPoint.  Years later, name change back to @Anthem Inc.  and currently Elevance Health. 

Through those years have been blessed to work in three strategic business units (Medicare, TRICARE, and Commercial) and held multiple positions in IT where I ended my career.  Through it all, I have been amazed at the progress of the company but even more impressed with the people that I have met and their dedication to doing the right thing.  One can only hope that at the end of your career that you have been able to make a difference in your work, provide value for your company and customers -- But, most important to me is providing some leadership and guidance to those you work with to allow them to flourish and grow.  My hope is that they continue to do good things as I start my retirement journey.

Just over 34 years ago I started at a company called Community Mutual Insurance Co (CMIC).  Little did I know what a career ride I would have. That company merged with the Associated Group to create the original company called Anthem, Inc. Anthem merged with several other BCBS licensees and ultimate became a publicly traded company in the early 2000's. We then acquired WellPoint and changed our corporate name to @WellPoint.  Years later, name change back to @Anthem Inc.  and currently Elevance Health. 

Through those years have been blessed to work in three strategic business units (Medicare, TRICARE, and Commercial) and held multiple positions in IT where I ended my career.  Through it all, I have been amazed at the progress of the company but even more impressed with the people that I have met and their dedication to doing the right thing.  One can only hope that at the end of your career that you have been able to make a difference in your work, provide value for your company and customers -- But, most important to me is providing some leadership and guidance to those you work with to allow them to flourish and grow.  My hope is that they continue to do good things as I start my retirement journey.

Iâ€™ll be teaching at the @AAOS1 Surgical Skills in Total Hip and Total Knee Arthroplasty Course and I hope to see you there! 

Register now: http://bit.ly/4asMb4s

 Our iconic powdered sugar sprinkler that delights strawberry eaters and cake decorating fans has undergone a revolution!
 
 After the entire PPK range switched to Kraft paper, the iconic powdered sugar sprinkler is getting a major metamorphosis! Daddy and Erstein have swapped their plastic packaging for cardboard.

 A real environmental and economical plus!

ðŸ˜… The term "open-sourced" is so misused in LLM research. Many popular LLMs claim to be open-sourced, but they often lack all the pieces needed for reproduction.

For example, all open-sourced LLMs from Meta and Google do not disclose the datasets used to train their LLMs and as of today, data source is a key differentiator for LLM performance.

Just found a helpful effort that tackles this issue to some extent.

The The Model Openness FrameworkÂ (MOF) defines specific criteria that AI model producers must adhere to for their models to be classified under one of three openness classes: Open, Partially Open, or Closed. 

These classes are determined based on the extent to which the model's development artifacts are made publicly accessible under permissive licenses. Key components include source code, training data, model architecture, and documentation.

â›³ The Three MOF Classes
ðŸ‘‰ Open Class: Models in this class provide complete access to all development artifacts under permissive licenses. They enable full transparency and reproducibility.
ðŸ‘‰ Partially Open Class: Models provide access to some but not all development artifacts, or some artifacts are released under more restrictive licenses.
ðŸ‘‰ Closed Class: Models in this class have limited or no access to critical development artifacts, hindering transparency and reproducibility.


Just noticed that on their website, many popular LLMs aren't listed, maybe due to some pushback ðŸ˜… 

Nevertheless, using frameworks like MOF helps build trust and accountability in AI research by stopping false claims of openness and making sure models are really open. It's something that we should be aware about!

column8: The best part about going into the Wells Fargo San Francisco office is the ferry commute on days like this. â˜€ï¸ Happy Summer!

How far would you walk for good customer service?  Yesterday I walked a half mile to our local farmerâ€™s market for a loaf of rye bread.  Our local bakery was there but they only had sourdough.  Their bread is good so I compromised.  As I a laid the bread on the counter to pay, a group of four walked up at the same time.  I called it a tie and let them go first.  They werenâ€™t there to buy but to chat.  After about 5 min of waiting while they caught up with the owner, I put the bread back and walked away.  Then walked ~1.5 miles round trip to another bakery and got my rye bread.  So my answer is at least 1.5 miles. 

In healthcare we often make people figuratively walk more than 1.5 miles for good service.  Thatâ€™s all changing.  Welcome to the data economy where we anticipate, see, and correct when things go off the rail without making our customers walk 1.5 miles.

Happy 4th of July Weekend! As I reflect on what it means to be an American, one of the things that comes to mind is our responsibility as Americans to not only pass down what is great about our country to the next generation but to come together and work to fix all that is not so great. 

I had the chance recently to bring my kids to my office and not only show them where mom works but talk to them about some of the healthcare challenges we are facing.Â It was wonderful to hear the questions they had and the ideas on how we can make it better. ðŸ˜Š While their simple answers are certainly not enough to fix the significant challenges we are facing today it still left me energized and proud of the work the American Medical Association is doing to improve health outcomes for all Americans.

Hi LinkedIn Community! I shared this via other social channels, but I have so many co-workers, Vendors, and Industry connections here whom have been checking in on me, so Iâ€™m sharing this status update of my Cancer situation with you all. ðŸ‘

My 12th and FINAL Chemotherapy session was Wednesday!! I still have to finish the session for another day (I carry a take-home pouch connected to me, that distributes more chemo through me for a couple of days). After this, Iâ€™m scheduled for a scan to ensure Iâ€™ve Won this battle (I can only Choose to be confident I did), and return to a life with more Energy and ability to focus on being here for my Family. 

This experience was full of so many things in my life:
âœ…Fear
âœ…Unconditional Love from my wife (as well as celebrating our 19th Anniversary)
âœ…Optimism
âœ…Ability for me to meet up and hang out with my long time best friend/brother, Roman Rosario 
âœ…Humility
âœ…Becoming a DudePa (aka Grandfather) to my daughters baby, Elliott
âœ…Awareness
âœ…Education
âœ…Ability to work a busy job that I love
âœ…Some good times being able to get out and ride my mountain bike on my non-chemo weeks ðŸ‘
âœ…Some great concerts
âœ…Continuing to be able to coach my sonâ€™s football Team. 

Iâ€™m so grateful for Everyone who spent time checking in on us, Family & Friends who visited to help us out, tons of Co-workers at U.S. Bank who care for me like crazy, and my great neighbor Ryan; who is facing an insanely harder battle with Cancer than I am. 

Others who inspired me are my mother in-law, who is a Survivor; and one of my favorite Football coaches whom I both played for, then coached with; who was not able finish his battle 5 years ago; but I know he faced it courageously with a fighters mentality, and has left so many great memories in the lives he touched. 

Iâ€™m still somewhat shocked to have found out I had cancer, so I hope EVERYONE takes my advice to make it a Priority that when you hit age 45, youâ€™ll check with your doctor to get tested. If anyone has any questions about it, donâ€™t hesitate to reach out to me.

Iâ€™ll still continue to be checked for cancer every year and promise Iâ€™ll be an advocate for others, if I find someone learns they have Cancer. I am doing my best to stay Optimistic that Iâ€™m a Survivor, and looking forward to getting back to a life of normalcy. I have a few other smaller medical things Iâ€™m managing (back issues) but not as scary as Cancer was (just more pain management). 

Thank you, EVERYONE, for your support and thoughts for my Family and I. #HereWeGo ! ðŸ¤žðŸ˜ŽðŸ¤™
Iâ€™m happy to share that Iâ€™m starting a new position as Head of Transformation Strategy, Global Financial Crimes (GFC) Investigations at Morgan Stanley!

Yesterday was quite a day in my educational journey. I never thought I would actually make the decision to go back to school again but alas we are at that point. I received my acceptance letter for the Ph.D. program in Data Science and Analytics. This is definitely an exciting time and looking forward to getting started. I never would have imagined I would made it to this point, but I know how awesome this will be to complete and a sense of pride for my wife and kids to know the hard work I will have put in. I will start in October this year and the completion will be dependent on once the start of my thesis, how long it takes to finish and defend. Ready to rock and roll, get this done, and get to that Dr. Jones, and the kids are very excited to make fun of me for it once that day arrives ðŸ˜‚. Onward and upward, here we come! To be continued....

Padmini Tampi **1945 - 2024** 

My mother (Amma) passed away yesterday. 

Amma was a larger-than-life figure for all of us in the family. She had a passion for teaching children (which began with my education), and was always kind and supportive of the less privileged. 

Many of her past connections remained in touch to the end, a testament to her lasting impact. 

I was fortunate, over the past two years following Ammaâ€™s terminal illness diagnosis, to have been able to spend time with her. My heartfelt thanks to all of my work and personal connections who supported me during this period.

Thank you, Amma, for everything. I promise, to try and be the best version of myself, as I know you would want.

Rest in peace. Om Shanti.

If youâ€™re thinking about moving away from a traditional, monolithic commerce solution to a composable one, Stanislav Publika, Senior Technical Director of Composable Commerce at Astound Digital has one key piece of advice:

â€œStart lean. Start thinking about not implementing everything at once. Start with implementing something that will definitely work first, and then start iterating to improve on it.â€

Too often, people underestimate how much time and effort goes into switching to a composable solution and end up facing scope creep when they make the change.

If you instead focus on making small changes and iterating as you go, you will be far more successful.

For more insights like this, tune in to this weekâ€™s episode of The E-commerce Toolbox, featuring Stanislav and Astound Digitalâ€™s Head of Revenue Anton Grebener:

column8:
I had never been kicked out of a startup program until this happened.

Our health tech startup SeamlessMD was several months into an accelerator.

We were 1 year old and still didnâ€™t have a live hospital customer.

Every two months there would be a big accelerator event where every company still in the program had to sit before all of the mentors and get grilled on their progress.

The mentors were some of the most successful tech entrepreneurs in the country - which meant it was a huge privilege to participate.

But it also meant they knew their stuff and could credibly call companies out if they were struggling.

Mentors would openly debate in front of the companies what they were excited about and what also made them deeply concerned.

To make companies earn the right to keep participating, 2-3 companies which made the least progress would be kicked out every two months.

We were halfway through the program and had been unscathedâ€¦ so far.

We showed up to the meeting proud to say that we had met all of our recent goals.

We then launched into discussing a partnership we were exploring that we felt could dramatically change the trajectory of the business and get us hospital customers faster.

And thatâ€™s when things took a nasty turn.

Many of the mentors tore our proposal apart. They thought we were giving away too much.

Later that day we found out we were kicked out. 

While we knew it was possibleâ€¦ we were stunned.

The reason?

They thought we â€œlacked the backboneâ€ to succeed in the complicated healthcare industry.

We were a few kids just out of university trying to break into healthcare, competing against companies led by veterans with 20+ years of experience.

Why would anyone trust us?

Thatâ€™s probably why we still had 0 live hospital customers despite working on our company for a year.

What really hurt was that the message came from some of the most successful entrepreneurs in the country.

We could have said: â€œI guess theyâ€™re right. Weâ€™ve worked for a year on this and have nothing to show for it. Letâ€™s just give up.â€

But we didnâ€™t.

We took it on the chin. 

We picked ourselves back up.

Over the next 12 months we:

â†’ Launched our product at 2 hospitals and 2 clinics

â†’ Had our 1st abstract presentation at a medical conference by a customer

â†’ Expanded our product from just a mobile app to an integrated web and mobile app

â†’ Had our 1st ever patient user organically blog about using SeamlessMD

â†’ Won 1st place at the TieQuest business competition

Today SeamlessMD is used by hospitals and health systems across North America, is backed by 40+ studies and evaluations and is the only solution in our space with direct turn-key integrations with all of Epic, Cerner and MEDITECH.

Now the mentors were right that the partnership structure we proposed was bad (it didnâ€™t end up happening).

And maybe they were right that sometimes we were meek.

But they were dead wrong about our drive, grit and commitment to our mission.

column8:
An exhausting but amazing day.

Freedom Alliance, joined by our partners at U.S. Bank, presented the gift of reliable transportation to US Army Combat Wounded Veteran Justin Shellhammer and his family through our "Driven To Serve" Program. Partnering in this program since 2018, this marked the 45th vehicle presentation overall and the 4th of 2024. 

Justin served our nation faithfully, deploying 6 times in 5 years. He has served in both Iraq and Afghanistan, and his time in the latter was cut short when he stepped on a landmine, resulting in the amputation of his left leg below the knee. Justin also served post military as a Law Enforcement Officer for 2 separate agencies in South Dakota before Post Traumatic Stress led him into his second retirement. He now calls Ohio his home with his lovely family, and we all had a great time spending the day together.

It was hot and humid, but the weather held off long enough for the vehicle presentation, followed by Justin and his family driving his new vehicle in the following parade through downtown Columbus. They finished right before a heavy storm came through, which finally cleared up in time for us all to arrive at the VIP area just as the Red, White and BOOM fireworks began. Billed as the largest fireworks display in the midwest, it did NOT disappoint.

A great day had by all, and I'm confident I will sleep well tonight. 

Back home tomorrow for a 2 day break before heading to Montana to welcome combat veterans flying into Missoula for a weeklong retreat. The train keeps on moving, and we are fortunate to have many patriotic Americans supporting our mission.

Tomorrow, take a moment to remember the sacrifices made by our nation's finest, and be thankful that such great men and women lived, suffered and endured, and in some cases died, for us to continue this American way of life.

Tom Kilgannon Len McMorrow Jenny Palmberg Aaron Lieberg

I have colleagues that have moved on before me. I am sharing my farewell email as I want to make sure this note gets to them too! 

Thank you to Sofia Calderon for organizing my farewell party. It was so great to see so many people I love and appreciate before my departure.

Here is the email:


Today is my last day at SEE. I could not go away without sharing my deep appreciation for each one of you. 
 
You all have had a profound impact on my life. You have, in the last 17 years, shaped me into the person I am, and I feel immense gratitude for that. 
 
I'm not only saying goodbye to a job or a company, I'm saying goodbye to the people who helped me become a citizen of the United States, to the people who supported me throughout my 3 pregnancies, to the people who prayed for my daughter and me when she was in the hospital for 2 weeks, to the people that opened the door for my husband to develop his chef skills at work. I'm saying goodbye to the folks who put people's safety and well-being first, before the job. This company gave me the opportunity to travel the world and meet amazing colleagues in Brazil, Mexico, Ecuador, Venezuela, Portugal, India, Spain, Turkey, Canada, people that despite the physical distance, have kept close and we have nurtured our friendships. So with that said (and the many things I didn't because this email can get VERY long if I do), you can only imagine how hard it is for me to take this next step in my career.
 
I'm entering a new chapter in my life which is hard to believe. I can only thank God for putting you all in my path. I am leaving a piece of my heart behind because of the people I will not get to work with on a daily basis that I genuinely admire and appreciate. No amount of words can thank you enough but I hope that just in these few, you all hear me say to each one of you THANK YOU SO MUCH!

GASP!!!Â Coming up for air after an amazing 6 weeks at Ulta Beauty.  What'd I miss??? ðŸ˜€ 

Netflix just release their latest iteration of their Culture Memo.Â One of the things I love is how direct and honest this memo is.  They know where they need to improve and move to address it.  I especially love the "Sports Team" analogy. 

Culture needs to be actionable.Â A piece of paper with some hand-wavy "values" is meaningless without the ability to hold people accountable, and just as important, enable and trust your people in creating something great. 

While I'm only 6 weeks in, I can FEEL the great culture here at Ulta Beauty.Â I intend to make it even better.Â Those of you who know me know that I'm big on culture and I put my money where my mouth is on enabling it.

Ulta have a mission to bring #joyforward.Â I would add that we are also creating an amazing #techforward culture!  Would love to hear from you and share ideas on culture, or better yet, come join us!

Recently, I had the privilege to speak at a prominent technology event organised at the CIO level within the bank. We chose the theme "Engineering TOIL," focusing on difficulties like fully defining TOIL, avoiding discussions of SRE, connecting TOIL to waste in the value chain, and emphasising that waste affects everyone, not just engineers.

The event witnessed record-breaking registrations and participation, setting a new standard that surprised both the organising team and us. The responsibility to deliver a successful session was significant.

Our session covered the essence of TOIL, its measurement within the bank, analysis of engineering and DevOps data using AI tools, showcasing how TOIL impacts productivity and engineering maturity, and presenting strategies to overcome TOIL challenges. Importantly, we engaged the audience by seeking their assistance in addressing these issues. 

It will be interesting to hear how you measure TOIL and what you include in your inner and outer loops. Are your calculation tools, surveys, or a mix of both? Let's exchange notes. 

A few of the questions asked of us are mentioned in the comments section, if they interest or intrigue you. 

#toil #technology #google #waste #flow #valuechain

In his latest Fintech Takes, Alex Johnson called Evolve Bank and Trust's lax standards "a feature not a bug."  Immediately some chimed in with convincing arguments such as "no it wasn't" (without evidence) while others, responding to the hack with "it could happen to anyone."

To be fair, it is unlikely many institutions can withstand a sustained assault from a quasi-nation state actor. HOWEVER, this is why best practices such as Encryption at Rest and intrusion detection are critical for anyone storing PII and providing access to the nation's banking infrastructure. A cybersecurity expert told me the the stance should be WHEN, not IF, and that Evolves response time is a clear indicator they were not prepared. 

Now let's address the elephant in the room. It was not a closely held secret in the industry that Evolve was running fast and loose. You don't need to be an industry insider to or expert to question how a bank of that size can add so many channel partners at that pace without hiccups. As I've said before, it is a quadratic scale of complexity. 

Our Alloy Labs members that play in BaaS started a Center of Excellence three years ago in anticipation that the industry would need to be better at self policing and standard setting. Some of it, like our nomenclature guide and Roles  & Responsibilities which we developed with Unit, Treasury Prime, Lithic, Currencycloud, we've made public (see links below). Others are availble only to members or happen behind closed doors with our next session in Chicago the end of the month. If you are a BaaS bank interested in doing it right, consider joining us. 

https://lnkd.in/gHpqcX9h

Not true.

Mommy and daddy come first. If mommy and daddy arenâ€™t rightâ€¦the whole thing doesn't work.

Iâ€™m grateful for this opportunity and proud to work for an organization who understands that evolution is pivotal. If we want to best serve our customers, employees, shareholders and society, we must adapt, progress and push forward.  Itâ€™s one of the many reasons why Iâ€™ve proudly donned the title of V Teamer for over two decades, and itâ€™s exactly what both myself and Verizon are doing as we enter our next chapter.

Today is my first day as Global Chair of PwC. Itâ€™s a great honor to take on this role at such an important time, when global megatrends like technological disruption and the climate transition are driving businesses to radically transform how they create, deliver and capture value. 

I firmly believe that we have the right strategy for our network. By bringing together multidisciplinary teams, powered by technology, we can help our clients and stakeholders build trust, solve important problems and deliver sustained outcomes.

Over the past few months, I have had the opportunity to sit down with my colleagues on the new Network Leadership Team to talk about our priorities for the future. We reinforced our commitment to three strategic focus areas: help our clients to reinvent their business models, build trust in what matters and manage the climate transition.

I am excited about what the future holds and look forward to working with our new Network and Global Leadership Teams, as well as our people, clients and stakeholders around the world as we take PwC into the future.

#PwCProud

Everythingâ€™s coming up Jen! June has been an overwhelmingly awesome month for me. I announced earlier that I accepted a new role and now I am very excited to share that I bought my first home! 

After living in apartments most of my life, I am so excited that I own this house. That I can paint anything. That I can fill the walls with nails. That I can splurge on a fancy wifi fridge. That I have a front porch where I enjoy the sounds of south city. That I have a backyard where Iâ€™ll try to grow a plant or two (maybe).

So far:

- I described a saw by the sound it makes when it saws â€œDo I need the kkshkshksh saw?â€
- I have amazing friends who have helped me install security systems, assemble furniture, and enjoyed floor picnics.
- I live across the alley from a brewery and it makes me so happy to smell the hops!

It's essential to understand that true leadership doesn't involve belittling others or undermining their confidence. Instead, it's about inspiring individuals to believe in the attainability of what seems impossible. It's about nurturing and empowering people to reach heights they never thought possible. It's also about making a positive impact not only within your community, company, and department but also in the lives of your employees and, by extension, the world.

As a leader, your goal is not to showcase your own greatness but to illuminate the remarkable potential within your team. By doing so, you inspire and motivate them to achieve beyond their expectations.

The best GTM leaders I know have brought in $1B's in revenue. Theyâ€™ve hired 100's of the top salespeople and built rock-solid systems to consistently hit their goals. Here's the #1 most important skill they all have in common:

They deeply understand SaaS metrics and financial statements.

Have you ever read a technical SaaS article or something written from a VC firm and said, â€œthis is too complicated, I will skip this one! â€ 

Many of best GTM leaders had that same reaction early in their career. 

To be the best, you have to fight through those uncomfortable moments, get comfortable with the learning curve, spend time educating yourself, and challenge yourself to think deeply about these topics.

Iâ€™ve found Dave Kelloggâ€™s writing to be extremely useful here. 

I read every single article he puts out.

If you're an up and coming VPs, CROs, CMOs, this write up is a great place to start: https://lnkd.in/e6S_Pxjz

Here are key points (but I recommend reading the full thing):

- Target pipeline coverage is NOT just the inverse of Win Rate
- There is a distinction between win rate and close rate over time
- Itâ€™s important to snapshot your pipeline at given periods through the quarter â€“ he points to the importance of Week 3 conversion rate
- There are implications of increasing pipeline â€“ both from an ownership perspective and a cost perspective

TAKEAWAY:

With classes Pavilion offers, smart veterans like David Kellogg and Jason M. Lemkin graciously sharing their learnings, and more VC blogs than ever, there is no excuse not to be educated on these topics.

Itâ€™s very easy to say â€œthatâ€™s too complicated for my roleâ€

But to be the best, SaaS and financial literacy is a must have

For the up and comers â€“ get to studying!

After 4 incredible years at Goldman Sachs, I have decided to take on a new opportunity. I am so grateful for all the memories, skills, and experiences I gained while working at GS. I couldnâ€™t have imagined a better place to start my post-graduate career. 

Huge thank you to Revathi M, Kosi Anazia, and Lilian Sotolongo for playing such positive roles in my GS experience. 

Iâ€™m very excited to be joining the Markets Data Lake team at J.P. Morgan and look forward to whatâ€™s in store!

After a 27 year career at GS spanning 3 offices (NY, Tokyo, London), 3 divisions (Operations, Controllers, Risk), and 2 lines of defense, I decided that the time has come for a break with my family and to begin working on what the next chapter will be. 

Taking a moment to reflect on key events which impacted and grew my experience and perspective â€” the GS IPO, the establishment of the EUR currency, the Y2K transition, the events of 9/11, the financial crisis and its regulatory aftermath (Dodd-Frank, etc), MiFID, Brexit, COVID, the advent of digital assets, mobile and cloud technologies, and more. Itâ€™s been an enriching experience to have navigated and learned from all of these events and the business transformations which followed. 9/11 and COVID also necessitated empathy and focus on the human impacts on colleagues, family, and friends.

GS taught me a wealth of skills, both financial and leadership. The people of GS over the years instilled the cultural values which became a part of me.

My desk included messages, milestones, and mementos from colleagues and from the many affinity networks that I supported over the years.  I kept the messages and milestones, and left the network items for the next generation of leaders to use to show their support and spark good conversations.  Profound gratitude to all of my colleagues, teammates, mentors, sponsors, and friends over the years.

Looking forward to some travel adventures this summer and to catching up with my network.

Thank you to U.S. News & World Report and Elizabeth Whitehead for hosting a crucial panel discussion to drive awareness and action to protect patient care and safety, and to my fellow panelists, Erik Decker and Marc Maiffret for their expertise and dedication to advancing cybersecurity in healthcare.

Our discussion emphasized the profound impact of cyber incidents beyond data lossâ€”they erode patientsâ€™ confidence, undermining safety and disrupting care delivery. We highlighted the urgency for robust cybersecurity measures across the healthcare sector and necessity to adopt an adversarial mindset, constantly pressure testing our defenses to stay ahead of sophisticated threats. Together, we underscored the importance of collaboration and shared defense in safeguarding our healthcare systems.

ðŸ¥ˆUnilever is still only about half the size of P&G (if you exclude their business in food/nutrition where they compete with giants like NestlÃ© and Danone , with brands like Lipton -correction-sold to CVC in 2022-, Hellmann's, or Ben & Jerry's).

P&G (Tide , Pantene , Olay , Crest , Gilette, etc) Â has grown faster Unilever (Dove , Axe , Pond's , Vaseline, etc) in the past 5 years: 4.5% CAGR vs. 3% % CAGR but slower in the past decade: 1.1% versus 1.7%

ðŸ’¸ #Profitability:

ðŸ“ˆ #MarketCap:

ðŸ†P&G is the sweetheart of investors. Its market cap is 3X Unilever ($390B versus $135B).

ðŸ¤‘Unilever is currently trading at 14X EV/EBITDA (TTM) and 2.5X Sales (TTM). P&G is trading at a premium 17X EV/EBITDA (TTM) and 5X Sales (TTM).
