Both companies have a global footprint but with brands and products often adapted to the local tastes of consumers. They have grown through a combination of #acquiring existing successful brands and developing their own new brands.

Is TOGAF still relevant in our agile world, or is it a relic of the past?

Weâ€™ve all seen methodologies come and go. TOGAF, once the gold standard, is now often viewed as the stuffy uncle at the agile family reunion.

Let's face it: TOGAF's extensive documentation and numerous artifacts can feel like overkill in today's fast-paced environment. The Architecture Development Method (ADM) with its 10 phases and 50+ deliverables can make even the most seasoned architect break out in a cold sweat.

But here's the thing: while TOGAF might seem outdated, its core principles still hold value. The key is adaptation.

Instead of treating TOGAF as a rigid mandate, we should view it as a flexible framework. Cherry-pick the parts that add value to your organization. Need a solid business architecture? TOGAF's got you covered. Want to ensure your technology aligns with business goals? There's a phase for that.

We need a hybrid approach. Use TOGAF's strategic elements to guide your overall architecture, but implement them using agile methods. Think of it as building a skyscraper (TOGAF) with Lego blocks (Agile).

For instance, replace lengthy documentation with collaborative workshops focused on strategy. Transform static artifacts into living documents that evolve with your organization. Build relationships and embed EA closer to execution teams instead of gate-heavy processes.

Remember, the goal of Enterprise Architecture is to align IT with business needs, not to produce perfect diagrams. TOGAF provides a robust framework, but it's up to us to apply it judiciously.

So, is TOGAF still relevant? Yes, but not in its pure form. Understanding its fundamentals is crucial, but applying them with agility is key.

What's your take? How have you adapted traditional EA frameworks to fit an agile world? Share your experiences!

I regularly post about Enterprise Architecture and emerging tech trends. Follow for more insights on navigating the evolving IT landscape.

#EnterpriseArchitecture #TOGAF #Agile #DigitalTransformation

Ok but why does this automated LinkedIn DM suggestion sound like a distant relative about to ask for $100 that he SWEARS he'll pay back next week?

I'm not a LinkedIn social selling expert. Far from it.

But, the most compelling DMs usually make the other person feel seen, heard, or understood. 

We don't have to use excessive flattery or praise. 

The word "impressed" or "impressive" has been grossly overused by AI-generated copy. 

Here's an uncommon DM I like. 

Use it when a new connection liked/commented on another person's post you found helpful.

Ex:

"Followed Nate Nasralla yesterday because of you. I tried his "accurate vs. optimistic" email on a stuck deal today. Thanks for introducing me to his content! Any other creators you'd recommend for Enterprise Sales? Either way - glad to be connected."

PS - should go without saying, but don't fake or automate these. It's not a volume play.

I have colleagues that have moved on before me. I am sharing my farewell email as I want to make sure this note gets to them too! 

Thank you to Sofia Calderon for organizing my farewell party. It was so great to see so many people I love and appreciate before my departure.

Here is the email:


Today is my last day at SEE. I could not go away without sharing my deep appreciation for each one of you. 
 
You all have had a profound impact on my life. You have, in the last 17 years, shaped me into the person I am, and I feel immense gratitude for that. 
 
I'm not only saying goodbye to a job or a company, I'm saying goodbye to the people who helped me become a citizen of the United States, to the people who supported me throughout my 3 pregnancies, to the people who prayed for my daughter and me when she was in the hospital for 2 weeks, to the people that opened the door for my husband to develop his chef skills at work. I'm saying goodbye to the folks who put people's safety and well-being first, before the job. This company gave me the opportunity to travel the world and meet amazing colleagues in Brazil, Mexico, Ecuador, Venezuela, Portugal, India, Spain, Turkey, Canada, people that despite the physical distance, have kept close and we have nurtured our friendships. So with that said (and the many things I didn't because this email can get VERY long if I do), you can only imagine how hard it is for me to take this next step in my career.
 
I'm entering a new chapter in my life which is hard to believe. I can only thank God for putting you all in my path. I am leaving a piece of my heart behind because of the people I will not get to work with on a daily basis that I genuinely admire and appreciate. No amount of words can thank you enough but I hope that just in these few, you all hear me say to each one of you THANK YOU SO MUCH!

The end of a very special eraâ€¦. 

Where can I even begin? 6.5 years ago I made the decision to move to Sydney, Australia for a role as a Clinical Educator with Permobil Australia. Itâ€™s been the experience of a lifetime and now after 6.5 years my journey is coming to an end.

Itâ€™s been a privilege and honor to have been part of the Clinical Serives team and to have built this team over the last 6 years with the most incredible individuals that possess the very core values of Permobil and who strive every day to provide the best possible support to clinicians. I could never have imagined a more perfect team to have been a part of. Tracee-lee Maginnity Rainy Wu Tilly Brook Roseanna T. and with the support of the incredibly talented Mau Itagaki.

And finally a big thank you to Owen Dawes for giving me this opportunity of a lifetime, for always believing in me and for supporting me through all my crazy ideas and dreams. 

I leave with incredible sadness but also with so many wonderful memories. And as each journey comes to an end the next one beginsâ€¦.

ðŸ˜… The pace of RAG research is super impressive, but not all of it is practical for real-world use cases. 

Many latest research works seek to improve performance over basic RAG architectures, however, they struggle with complex implementation and long response times.

This new paper investigates existing RAG approaches and their potential combinations to identify optimal practices. Through extensive experiments, the authors suggest several strategies for deploying RAG that balance both performance and efficiency.

The infographic in itself (below) is extremely useful too.  It breaks down the pipeline into smaller stages and lists methods for each stage.

Two and a half years ago, I made the difficult decision to resign from my full-time Business Analyst position and accept a short-term contract role at St. Jude, joining a brand-new team with no guarantee of a permanent position. I took this leap of faith to contribute to an organization that does incredible work in finding cures and saving children's lives.
From the start, I dedicated myself to driving change and supporting departments in their technology onboarding processes, encouraging them to let Day One alleviate some of their burdens. Along this journey, I have met some truly amazing individuals and made lifelong friends.
A year after joining, I was thrilled to be hired as the first full-time member of the Day One team. Today, I am excited to announce my promotion to Sr. Business Analyst.
I feel blessed to be a small part of the first workday experience for the extraordinary individuals at St. Jude. Their dedication and passion inspire me every day, and I am honored to continue contributing to such a noble cause.
ðŸ’“ Thank you to everyone who has supported me along the way and the Day One Team. Here's to many more achievements together!

It is bittersweet to share this personal announcement with my LinkedIn community. After five rewarding years as the Executive Director of Harlem Lacrosse - Philadelphia, I am stepping down to make way for new leadership. During my tenure, weâ€™ve expanded our reach to support over 200 young individuals in Olney, collaborating with three neighborhood schools and numerous partners throughout Philadelphia.

There are too many individuals to list, but I want to include a heartfelt thanks to my colleagues, volunteers, partners, Advisory Board members, and donors who have made my role a true joy over the past five years. It takes a village, and ours is pretty special.

As I prepare to pass the baton, I am calling on this incredible network to help us find a passionate and dedicated individual to take over this role. We are looking for someone who will bring fresh energy, passion, and leadership to continue empowering our youth. The ideal candidate will be a go-getter, eager to drive projects forward independently, and a strong people manager. If you know someone who fits this description, please share this opportunity. Together, let's set the stage for even greater achievements in the next five years and beyond.

Coming back from vacation, I have had the ability to reflect and transition into my new role as immediate past chair for the Portland Regional Chamber of Commerce as my term as chair officially ended on June 30th.  I look forward to my last two years on the board before I will term off at the end of June in 2026. 

I still remember my first board meeting in 2012 and how excited I was to get involved with such a vital business organization.  The chamber represents over 1,300 businesses with a collective workforce of 70,000 employees in its membership.  The chamber is doing amazing work in helping to advocate for businesses and their employees, to help and create housing solutions to attract needed workforce to the area, to address the challenges of childcare that continue to be a barrier for many people, and to work with businesses large and small to address the challenges they face.

I am fortunate that I had the opportunity to learn from amazing business leaders in our community and follow in the footsteps of prior board chairs during my tenure that included James Cohen, Michael Bourque, Jim Erwin, Al Swallow, and Asha Echeverria.  I am also thrilled to watch Georgia Wraight step into the role as chair as I know she is another remarkable leader and have been honored to get to know her over the past several years.  To all of those I have served on the board with, thank you for your time and energy and all that you do for the region.

I want to recognize the amazing staff of the chamber: Eamonn D., Estela Pineda, Rachel Carruthers, Riley Legere and Tommy Johnson.  Small but mighty is an understatement for all the work that you accomplish.  You are all incredible individuals that are helping move Maine forward and cannot thank you enough for all you do.

I would also like to thank Quincy Hentzel for the countless lunches at the Cumberland Club, executive meetings at the chamber offices and coffee meetings to discuss the organization.  I am forever grateful for your unmatched leadership in the community and am happier to call you a great friend!

Lastly, I would like to thank my family for accommodating early morning meetings, meetings during days off and many nights I got home late.

As immediate past chair, I have the distinct pleasure of stepping into the role of board chair for the Greater Portland Business Education Collaborative, a 501c3 organization established by the Portland Regional Chamber.  I thank Asha Echeverria for all her work in establishing this entity and being the founding chair for the past two years and Jack Lufkin for agreeing to not only take over as Treasurer for the Portland Regional Chamber when Al Swallow asked me to be Vice Chair in 2020, but for also agreeing to be Treasurer for this new entity.

David escaped from a full-time job in a toxic environment where the best employees quit, and the worst people were promoted to management positions. The people with all the ideas were shunned and pushed aside, while the tush-kissers with no plans got promoted. 
 
The harder David worked, the worse he got treated. Finally, when a completely unqualified person got promoted to be his manager because that manager had a personal relationship with one of the VPs, that was the last straw; David resigned. It was hard for him to leave the company he worked so hard for, but he felt a huge weight lifted off his shoulders the minute he was out of there. 

I came across this story in Liz Ryanâ€™s article in Forbes, and it resonates with the experiences of numerous individuals in organizations around the globe. Great employees who came into the organization with an inspired heart and a spark in their eyes, ready to make a difference, got uninspired and demotivated when they soon realized that their environment was toxic to the core. 
 
Never settle for any toxic, fear-based organization. 

Remember, your professional development, health, and energy are of utmost importance. Don't let a toxic work environment compromise these. There are always other options out there, and you deserve to work in an environment that values and nurtures you, helping you become the best version of yourself.

Thrilled to be teaming up with the Giant Ventures team!

Two cornerstones of my professional investing career have been (i) bridging the EU/UK and US startup ecosystems and (ii) a maniacal focus on providing candor, empathy and commercial value to the founders I've been lucky to back. When I made my mind up over a year ago that I was ready after 13 years of CVC across 2 Fortune 500 companies to transition to a pure financial role, I sought out up-and-coming funds with founder first ideologies who similarly recognized the synergies of cross-Atlantic investing and the massive energy transition investment opportunity, especially in Europe. On the value-add front, I am swapping out a big OEM-based commercial GTM machine with a proprietary partnership that Giant has built with McKinsey and one of the most hyper-connected group of strategic advisors, LPs and venture partners I've ever come across. Giant backs purpose-driven founders solving the worldâ€™s biggest problems and for a small taste of Giant's convening power and thought leadership, you should check out a recap of our recent Giant Ideas summit in London where we had Ray Dalio and Richard Branson, among many others, speak: https://lnkd.in/gymZZMv5

I will be mostly focused in my part-time capacity on helping drive Series B opportunities for Giant's Early Growth (EGII) fund. If you're an LP potentially interested in the $150M fund we're closing now, I'd love to chat. And more importantly, if you're a founder with a GIANT idea across climate + healthcare + inclusive capital, drop me a note at grant@giant.vc

Growing up, my family provided a safe and stable home to more than 50 foster siblings. Because of this, Iâ€™m very aware of the many challenges children in foster care face, including the loss of critical support systems as they transition into adulthood. Caring for all kids, no matter their circumstances or their age, is important to me and important to UnitedHealthcare.

To help youth transition out of foster care, we've developed three training programs centered on independence and support. The first helps teach those in the child welfare system life skills they'll need after aging out. The second helps families gain and retain their foster caregiver license. The third helps providers better understand the unique needs and challenges facing foster youth. These programs are just some of the initiatives weâ€™re working to improve the well-being of kids in the foster care system.

Another secret in the heart of Atlantaâ€¦â€¦..


Georgia Tech is the top producer in the country of current employed AI graduates per JLL research.

Recently in collaboration with NVIDIA, Tech has created The AI Makerspace, a supercomputer hub that gives students access to computing resources typically available only to researchers or tech companies. It means hands-on experience for our students, deepening their skills and preparing them to be the new generation of AI professionals.

Additionally, Tech AI, the AI Hub at Georgia Institute of Technology, brings together hundreds of thought leaders, researchers, doers, and teachers across campus, working together to advance AI - using it responsibly to create new products, educate students of all ages and backgrounds, and develop tomorrow's AI workforce.

Appreciate Tech leaders including Pascal Van Hentenryck and Ãngel Cabrera for their dedication on these initiatives!

I am super excited to share that earlier this week I was promoted to Senior Release Train Engineer at Humana! 

 
Release Train Engineer, you ask? What about project management? 


This role is a step up the proverbial ladder from being a PM, and is a role that comes from the Agile world. In really simple speak, I will be taking on the responsibilities of a program manager, but with an Agile focus.

1 Year Later... 

It has been a year since my last day at Verizon and what a year it has been! 

This past year, I prioritized my self-care.Â Whatever that needed to be at the moment.Â Sometimes, that meant being busy, sometimes resting, sometimes doing a project, and sometimes thinking and writing.Â This was a year of learning and unlearning.Â There were moments of pure happiness and crippling fear.Â Iâ€™m thankful for this journey and the amazing friends and family I have to support me. 

My success metrics have shifted significantly. I used to look at compensation, title, year end ratings, how much work I accomplished, etc.Â Now I look at percentage of happiness. Â Iâ€™m generally a happy person,but I can honestly say I am sitting at a higher percentage than I was a year ago.Â The best part is that I am in control of that number.Â I can remove things from the equation to increase the percentage all the time.Â If something is not serving my happiness, it gets removed, or in the cases where I canâ€™t remove it, I come up with ways to limit the impact it has on me.Â Itâ€™s hard !!!! But itâ€™s the best work I can do for myself! 

Recently, I saw a friend. I was talking about my small business when she stopped me and said, â€œLook how happy you are. I havenâ€™t seen this version of Chris in years.â€Â Itâ€™s amazing when others notice, too ðŸ˜Š

I added a few other things to my year-end performance reviewâ€”it feels like a â€œleading ratingâ€ to me! 

âœ… Enjoyed some amazing vacations.
âœ… Wrote and published my first book 
âœ… Packed up and sold our home
âœ… Relocated to the Jersey Shore
âœ… Laid the foundation and significantly grew my small business 
âœ… Filled my calendar with countless catch-up calls, videos, and lunches, reconnecting with amazing people 
âœ… Many therapy sessions deconstructing what I want to carry forward and leave behind from my corporate career 

I think the smile is a bit different in the pictures.   Let's go, Year 2 !!!

Zonzon is thrilled to announce that Dana Lowry, owner of Grandwest Properties LLC in Colorado Springs and Mikayla Keitz (Community Manager) have joined our platform to bring â€œcommunityâ€ back to apartment living! ðŸ¢âœ¨

By partnering with us, Grandwest Properties is taking an innovative step to address retention by connecting their residents and building vibrant communities through events/meetups organized and hosted by Zonzon. This intentional resident retention strategy aims to foster deep roots and create multiple social connections among residents, significantly increasing renewals.

I completed the certification "Introduction to FOCUS" from FinOps Foundation.

What is FOCUS?
FOCUS,Â the FinOps Open Cost & Usage Specification, is a technical specification and toolkit to build and maintain an open standard for cloud cost, usage, and billing data across all major cloud service providers. FOCUS aims to make billing data more consistent and usable across Cloud, SaaS, and even internal billing sources, improving your understanding of your costs and allowing everyone to speak the same language to make better decisions.

In less than 48 hours after #HurricaneBeryl started to clear our territory, Entergy Texas has made significant progress on restoration efforts with less than 145,000 customers remaining without power. We are on track to have more than 50% of the peak outages restored today and will continue to focus on the most heavily impacted areas.

As we continue to restore around the clock, maximum estimated restoration times by region/city were established and communicated yesterday evening to our customers. Our detailed View Outage map also helps the community understand the progress made and where power has been restored.

The men and women of Entergy and those supporting us from out of state are committed to getting power on to every customer. Today, as we also recognize National Lineworker Appreciation Day, I couldnâ€™t be prouder of our line workers who are safely and diligently performing some of the most heroic work to power our communities. #ThankALineworker #SETX

column8: Hurricane Beryl hit the Texas coast as a Category 1 storm and continued its destructive path up through our service area across Arkansas. Many thanks to our hard-working crews who not only help recover our communities after hurricanes, tornadoes and other natural disasters, but also keep the lights on each and every day. #ThankALineworker

As a former Vice President of Customer Service for Entergy New Orleans, I deeply understand the frustrations and challenges that come with losing power during severe weather events. Hurricane Beryl has significantly impacted our communities in Texas, and my heart goes out to everyone affected. 

On this National Lineworker Appreciation Day, I want to extend my heartfelt gratitude to all lineworkers for their essential role in our communities. I know from experience that our dedicated line workers are working tirelessly, around the clock, to restore power to impacted homes and businesses in Texas. Their bravery and dedication are nothing short of heroic. While most people seek safety away from the storm, our lineworkers head straight into it, undeterred and resolute in their mission to restore normalcy. 

I have absolute confidence in Eliecer Viamontes, President and CEO of Entergy Texas. He is a proven leader who will not rest until every single customer is restored. The men and women of Entergy are on the ground, and working long hours through the night to restore power as quickly as possible. 

For specific information regarding restoration and storm damage, customers can visit the Entergy newsroom. Here are some essential safety tips to keep in mind if you lose power:

ðŸ’¡ Stay away from downed power lines and assume they are energized.

ðŸ’¡ Report an outage on the MyEntergy site or call 1-800-9OUTAGE. Thereâ€™s no need to speak with a representative if you report online.

ðŸ’¡ Use your portable generator safely. Do not run it in enclosed spaces. Only connect your generator to the whole house if installed by a licensed electrician to prevent backfeed to the distribution system.

ðŸ’¡ Minimize opening refrigerator and freezer doors to keep food cold longer.

ðŸ’¡ Please stay clear of our workers as they safely restore power.

ðŸ’¡ Avoid walking or driving through floodwaters.

Download the free Entergy app and follow the company on Twitter or Facebook for the latest updates. 

Stay safe, everyone. We are all in this together.

Microsoftâ€™s own lessons learned in their M365 Copilot rollout.Â These tips are SPOT ON and should be a huge help to an organization looking to drive value from Copilot or Gen AI more generally.Â Whatâ€™s not here is a sense of the big lift behind executing against these recommendations.Â The rewards of Gen AI adoption (or any digital transformation) are extremely attractive but â€“ shocker - they wonâ€™t come without investment and commitment.
Here are a few items that particularly stood out to me:

â€œGaining confidence and ability early on (for example, asking Copilot to recap a meeting) helps users maintain a healthy growth mindset when they hit the inevitable road bumps.â€ â€“ in my experience those road bumps came early and often, and we saw a significant drop-off in participation when other success factors like leadership support or peer learning opportunities werenâ€™t in place.

â€œRolling out Copilot to entire teams at onceâ€”even if theyâ€™re small onesâ€”is crucial in promoting peer-to-peer learning: It encourages sharing and learning among the group members, multiplying the impact of the technology. It also allows organizations to see patterns to help identify whatâ€™s working (or whatâ€™s not).â€Â I think this is very true â€“ particularly the peer-to-peer learning piece.Â Too bad itâ€™s so expensive that itâ€™s difficult to justify â€œlicenses for allâ€ in the early stages.

â€œThrough managers and rollout leaders, we identified people who were most excited to dive into the technology and share what they learned with their peers. We then empowered them to lead internal trainings and create quick demo videos to share their skills. That grassroots approach allows others to see the potentialâ€”and inspires them to explore the technology for themselves.â€ - Yes.Â Great.Â No notes.Â Dig into the piece to read more about the AI council. 

" 'You have to celebrate people who are adopting AI and showcase their efforts,' says Hossein Nowbar, Chief Legal Officer at Microsoft. 'We had early adopters of AI join me onstage during our department-wide summit to talk about how they are leveraging AI and the efficiencies they gained.' This recognition inspires others to join the AI journey."Â - this is so important.Â Leaders not only have to recognize and celebrate, they have to role model adoption themselves, set a clear expectation that their teams will lean in, and create space and time for them to do so.Â This simply will not come without learning curve.Â Itâ€™s not just that the technology is new, we are all going to have to go through some discomfort to change our work patterns.  If an employee's immediate manager is not actively accommodating this learning and discomfort,  the effort will fail.

https://lnkd.in/eDVq7irM

#M365Copilot #GenerativeAI #DigitalTransformation

column8:
Ditch the stand-ups. Or don't. What matters is the intentionality, knowing what good looks like, and iterating/adapting as needed.

The hardest part, IMHO, is knowing what good looks like. If you've never worked on a team with rich collaboration between engineers, you can easily rationalize ditching the stand-ups because they feel like a waste of time. It *feels* superfluous.

If, on the other hand, you've experienced different cultures and approaches and understand the Why behind the practices, you can pick, choose, and adapt.

Growing up, my family provided a safe and stable home to more than 50 foster siblings. Because of this, Iâ€™m very aware of the many challenges children in foster care face, including the loss of critical support systems as they transition into adulthood. Caring for all kids, no matter their circumstances or their age, is important to me and important to UnitedHealthcare.

To help youth transition out of foster care, we've developed three training programs centered on independence and support. The first helps teach those in the child welfare system life skills they'll need after aging out. The second helps families gain and retain their foster caregiver license. The third helps providers better understand the unique needs and challenges facing foster youth. These programs are just some of the initiatives weâ€™re working to improve the well-being of kids in the foster care system.

column8: After 44 years of working in the healthcare industry,  yesterday I turned my laptop off for the last time.   Through these years Iâ€™ve been so fortunate to work for Pharma/bio pharmaâ€™s best - J&J (24 years and where I met Jim Mossop), Novartis, Merck and the last stretch of 12 years with BMS. Iâ€™ve been surrounded by incredible leaders, mentors, and colleagues, often finding myself in roles I never expected -  the twists and turns of my career path have provided experiences, insight, travel across the world and most importantly personal growth and satisfaction that permit me to sit back this morning and feel deeply fulfilled and happy.  Most importantly are the people - many I am blessed to call  friends and who will share in this next phase of life.  Cheers!
column22: Wishing you Joy and fulfillment in your next chapter

column8:
This year, Fresenius Medical Careâ€™s St. Wendel plant celebrates its 50th anniversary! Since its founding in 1974, this manufacturing site, located in Saarland, Germany, has grown into one of the world's largest production and export sites for dialyzers, and one of the most important global technology centers for Fresenius Medical Care.

With more than 1,000 patents having been registered at the site since its inception, the site has developed into a leading center of innovation and quality in dialyzer manufacturing. "It is the outstanding spirit of innovation that has made St. Wendel what it is today and has helped make dialysis treatment more effective and accessible for patients worldwide." says Dr. Katarzyna Mazur-HofsÃ¤ÃŸ, Member of the Management Board of FME and responsible for the Care Enablement segment, the MedTech division.

It's been a journey of innovation and dedication to improving patient care and our innovation is inextricably linked with this manufacturing site. St. Wendel has been the birthplace of significant scientific breakthroughs that continue to positively influence our patients' lives today.

Join us in celebrating the 50th anniversary tomorrow and explore a collection of photos showcasing the incredible journey and the dedicated team behind its success. ðŸŒŸ

Read more in the press release here: https://lnkd.in/dSzFVvKP

#TogetherAhead #ProudtobeFME #Dialysis #HealthcareInnovation

During my recent visit toÂ Fort Jackson, South Carolina, I was reminded of the critical role our team plays in operating theÂ electric and natural gas systemsÂ on the base. Itâ€™s more than just infrastructure; itâ€™s the backbone that supports overÂ 60,000 traineesÂ annually, who carry the spirit of Fort Jackson to every Army unit around the globe.

Our work is vital for the installation, and the teams supporting this effort showed such a commitment to excellence to bolster the resilience of our armed forces.

The energy we provide does more than just power the base; it fuels the training and lives of those who dedicate themselves to serving our nation. Iâ€™m proud of our teamâ€™s dedication, and I appreciated the red-carpet treatment!

After 23 incredible years at Intuit, I am hanging up my cleats. It has been a true blessing to be part of a company that has made a significant impact on the financial well-being of numerous SMBs and Mid-Market companies worldwide. My elite teams always balanced fun with hard work, striving to delight customers and defend, retain, and grow our customer base.

I am immensely grateful to everyone I have had the pleasure of working with over the years, from Intuit employees to QuickBooks Solution Providers and Intuit App partners who have become like family to me. While the list of names is too vast to mention, each person has played a vital role in shaping my career, and to all of you, I simply say, "Thank you."

As I bid farewell, I am excited to shift my focus towards myself, my family, and youth sports. If anyone knows of a tennis team I could join, recommends a great golf instructor, or has impromptu vacation suggestions, I am all ears. #onward

Allyson Felix holds a record 20 World Championship medals and 11 Olympic medals, including seven golds. She is acutely aware of what it takes to be an elite athlete, and an elite athlete mom.

She is teaming up with Pampers to create the first-ever Pampers Nursery in the Athletes Village at the Paris Olympics. The nursery will offer a space for moms to bond with, nurse and play with their babies, helping to alleviate some of the pressures of competition.

â€œI just knew how difficult it was to compete at the top level after I had my daughter, and some practical things were really hard. And so when I joined the Athletes Commission of the IOC, I really wanted to be that voice for athlete moms, and just take away one less thing for them to worry about in the pressure of competition,â€ said Felix. Bravo ðŸ‘

Today, I hit my 10 year work anniversary at Walgreens Boots Alliance I can't help but remember all the awesome people I have worked with during my time here. Things I have learned: 
- GSD
- Double everything
- Scale is hard
- Breaking production is not okay
- Innovation is what you make it
- If you aren't having fun are you even working?
- We can move very quickly when we need to
- I think you are mute: "Yes that's on purpose"
- Big things can be done with small budget
- Product management is a hell of a job

Great coworkers are why I have continued to stay at this company, some have left, some have come back, some I still work with today. I decided to come work at this company because I knew it would be a challenge to try to meet customers retail & healthcare needs at huge scale; people have changed, company has changed, but I have just stuck with the mantra we are helping people, truly helping people, and I think there is something great about that. #SeeYouInAnother10

I hadn't considered that certifications would still be part of my career when I pivoted to owning my own business, but here I am, excitedly sharing my latest certification. Likely many won't be surprised that this one is in the education space (I do love teaching and helping others learn), this time it's not learning about technology or process.... well maybe a little process... ðŸ˜‰ I'm now certified as a Sallie Tomato Educator.  ðŸŽ‰ 

Sallie Tomato is a major supplier of bag making supplies - cork, faux leather, hardware, patterns and much more.  I have been a fan of the business for years and when I opened my own company I was looking for ways to partner with the businesses that I loved.  Sallie Tomato happened to be looking for Educators - if you know me, you know how I love a great serendipitous moment!  I couldn't be more excited about the opportunity. One aspect of my business plan included classes and events and now with this certification I feel even more empowered to build upon that plan. 

If your goals include learning a new skill like bag making, reach on out and let me know. I'd love to hear from you!

Today I attended a brilliant â€œHerStoryâ€ event at Morgan Stanley, hosted by â€œWomen in Wealthâ€, because I wanted to re-meet Melanie Schnoll Begun after having thoroughly enjoyed my time with her a few weeks ago at the MS Global Volunteer Month golf event we shared.

Melanie did not disappoint. During her fireside chat, which was brilliantly moderated by the amazing Anna Winderbaum, Melanie told us the story that has led to her amazing professional and personal success â€” all in her wonderfully authentic and humorous way. 

I especially loved her story about joining the Firm, being the only woman in her group, and how she moved from being a lawyer to now running a hugely successful business, as Head of Field Engagement & Philanthropy Management at Morgan Stanley. 

For me, her quote of the day relates to her absolute self-awareness and confidence: â€œI am here at Morgan Stanley because I was incredibly qualified.â€

It's definitely been one heck of a journey to get here with lots of ups and downs, but I'm thrilled to share Kudos has raised another round of funding and we're very excited for this next chapter! 

Thanks to Xfund, Oversubscribed Ventures, Precursor Ventures, Freedom Trail Capital, TiE Global Angels, Net Zero Angels, Reverb Capital and others for believing in our vision and supporting us on this next step of our journey. Brandon Farwell Patrick S. Chung Charles Hudson Phil Schwarz Sara Foster Jason Scott Matt M.

Ilan Tagger Moira Finicane Isabelle Keba Tanner Wildason James Keighley

Healthcare cybersecurity is often approached, assessed, analyzed, and managed from a functional perspective. In the world of interoperability and complexity of the digital health ecosystem, measuring security measures and costs arenâ€™t enough because nothing tied to cyber is ever finished. As threats have evolved and expanded, digital health has followed. But for many entities that find themselves in the have-nots of healthcare in terms of resources, effective cybersecurity defenses and policies have not moved as quickly.

The reality is that something must change, and it absolutely must start with leadership, then permeate through the entire workforce. In First Health's most recent white paper, "Cyber Resilient Digital Health: Itâ€™s Not Just About Security Anymore" EVP David Finn, outlines direct examples of the rise in patient safety impacts from healthcare cyberattacks and how healthcare leaders can move forward with cyber resilient digital health.

For more on how First Health's Cybersecurity Performance Improvement Services, visit https://lnkd.in/gRrt4RK or contact First Health's Digital Health Experts at sales@firsthealthadvisory.com.

Our pride in having the opportunity to invest in Envestnet cannot be overstated. Together with our investment partners, and the strategic investors joining us on this journey, we are eager to contribute to Envestnetâ€™s next phase of growth.

Itâ€™s time to start exercising some new muscles here at Commonwealth Fusion Systems: the business of providing our powerful magnet technology to other organizations.

Our first commercial deal in fusion magnets is with University of Wisconsin-Madison. We designed and built two high-temperature superconducting (HTS) magnets in a collaboration that began in 2019. Now weâ€™ve taken the major step of delivering and installing them at the universityâ€™s Physical Sciences Lab. Experiments should begin soon at WHAM â€” short for Wisconsin HTS Axisymmetric Mirror. From our fusion lab to theirs!

If you want to see some real-world fusion energy hardware, check out our video here of the unboxing of the two magnets.

We nicknamed the magnets Thing 1 and Thing 2, inspired by the twins in Dr. Seussâ€™ The Cat in the Hat. Theyâ€™re the high field â€œmirrorâ€ coils in WHAM, and hydrogen nuclei will bounce back and forth in a tube-shaped magnetic field between them. The magnetic mirror approach mostly fizzled decades ago, but our HTSÂ  superconducting electromagnets and some plasma physics breakthroughs mean theyâ€™re worthy of investigation again and ultimately could become a new path to fusion commercialization.

Which brings me to our magnet business. Our primary job is to build our own fusion machines, starting with the SPARC tokamak thatâ€™s under construction now at our headquarters in Devens, Massachusetts. But our expertise lets us help other parts of the fusion market, too, and better magnets make many approaches to confining a plasma and triggering fusion better.Â  We are pro-fusion, and thus we are pro-fusion magnets.

We delivered the magnets as a full, integrated package with cooling, instrumentation, and software to control them. The WHAM magnets were possible because of our abilities not just in manufacturing but also modeling, design, and testing, integration â€” all things we do for SPARC.

It was a learning experience for us, too. Some of the technology we developed for WHAM helped us with SPARC and other possible projects with other customers inside and outside fusion.

Speaking as a plasma physicist, itâ€™s fantastic to see this kind of progress in fusion energy again, enabled by new technology, better physics, and great partnerships. I have fond memories of working in the long-thin West Cell at MIT that was built to hold a long-thin mirror decades ago. Turns out, it was just ahead of its time and a bit short of HTS. 

Congratulations to the CFS team and our Wisconsin colleagues for building WHAM. Weâ€™re eager to see it up and running, and for the team to take it to the next phase!

Here is my latest interview by AdExchanger, focused on my role at Uber and Retail Media Networks (RMNs) in general.

Thanks James Hercher for capturing my key thoughts. Here are my top three:

1ï¸âƒ£ UberEats Ads is a multi-layered RMN: in one order, consumers start with restaurants (meal), move to CPG (drink/food they can add on top), and may finish with entertainment (movie?). There is a big opportunity for a synchronized experience, set of ad products, and GTM strategy.
2ï¸âƒ£ Uber Ads is a full-funnel, omnichannel platform: across two popular apps and CTV assets, users may go from food search to in-car tablet exposures during a ride, with touchpoints also in-app and offsite. Our deterministic audience and scale can serve multiple use cases.
3ï¸âƒ£ For RMNs, there is always a balance between ad monetization and the risk of sales loss. At UberEats, weâ€™re trying to elevate Ads from monetization-only to a business growth lever as well, i.e., how we fully leverage ads to accelerate our delivery flywheel.

If you have 3 minutes to read through, Iâ€™m curious to hear your thoughts on RMNs and where you think the next S-curve is coming from. For the best insight, Iâ€™ll buy you lunch in Miami or NYC ðŸðŸš—

Time is the one thing you can never get back, and money canâ€™t buy it! Eight years ago, we set up 1st Select to ensure we could enjoy a good work-life balance and spend quality time with our families. The last three days perfectly exemplified why we made that decision.

I spent three days with my youngest son. We decided on Sunday night to take a spontaneous trip to Germany, and it was a fantastic experience. I hope itâ€™s something heâ€™ll remember for a lifetime.

No lectures or moral of the story here, just a simple message: if youâ€™re working at a company that doesnâ€™t allow you to see your family, attend sports days, leavers assemblies, etc., find somewhere that does!

column8:
I celebrate 20 years at Infosys today! They say time flies when youâ€™re having fun, and it turns out two decades isnâ€™t that long if you really enjoy your work. 
 
What Iâ€™ve learned really boils down to the work Iâ€™ve done and the hundreds and thousands of people Iâ€™ve connected with. Thatâ€™s the beauty of Infosys. Itâ€™s hard to sum it all up, but Iâ€™ll take a shot with 5 things that have stayed with me over the years.

1. Thereâ€™s always something exciting brewing. I like to think thatâ€™s because Infosys isnâ€™t just a technology company. The projects you get to work here are so diverse, everything from demystifying banking products to digitizing cross-word puzzles to AI analytics for tennis players to addressing scope 3 emission. Thereâ€™s no telling what youâ€™ll end up doing. You can start your career as a chemical engineer, but still find opportunities to work on the stuff youâ€™re most passionate about on a global scale. (I did).

2. Colleagues become friends, and over time, they start to feel like family. And itâ€™s not just your teams at Infosys, but also the partners you work with closely. Thereâ€™s camaraderie, and thereâ€™s the joy of seeing them grow with you over time. There will be many babies in your team, and eventually, theyâ€™ll have babies. I too, became a parent at Infosys, and thereâ€™s no feeling like your teammate bringing their newborn over to the office to meet you.

3. Thereâ€™s always something to learn, and someone to learn from. Be it a brief conversation with the co-founders or a tech architect youâ€™re working with on a project, you always leave a meeting feeling like youâ€™ve added more grey cells, and in my case, quite a few grey hairs too. A mid-life crisis might include packing a bag and going to college on a campus full of 20-somethings in Stanford to reconnect with academics. (I got through it).

4. It wonâ€™t feel like a job. At some point, youâ€™ll certainly feel like what you do is making a difference. In such a purpose-driven company, itâ€™s inevitable. There are few things so special as seeing social impact in action. Iâ€™ve witnessed the joy and hope that simple initiatives, like providing laptops and coding lessons, can bring to children and adults alike.

5. Sometimes, you'll pinch yourself to see if it's real. Because when you've stayed long enough, youâ€™ll realize how far you've come. The journey with the Infosys brand, from the early days of trade events and brochures to global forums on snowy mountains, stadiums, airports, and iconic figures showcasing your logo, has been truly fulfilling. Standing in Times Square, NYC, witnessing the campaign you've helped create and seeing the Infosys logo displayed prominently, you take a moment to look back with pride. (Next upâ€¦Las Vegas Sphere, Super Bowl adâ€¦why not? ðŸ˜Š)

So with much gratitude, a big thank you to Infosys, to everyone in it, and especially to my wonderful team (over the years). Itâ€™s been quite a ride. Thank you for the 20 years, and hereâ€™s to many more.
 
#proudinfoscion #twodecades

10 signs that you are working for the right leader. 



1. They praise you publicly for a job well done. 
2. They see you as a human first. 
3. They tell you what you need to hear, not what you want to hear.
4. You respect them and learn from them on a daily basis.
5. You feel safe being vulnerable with them. 
6. They consistently use clear language in communication with you. 
7. They hold you accountable to being the best version of yourself. 
8. You roar laughing with them regularly. 
9. They are crystal clear on the timeline and what is expected of you for your next promotion.
10. You believe that they are a good human.


Number 2 and 10 should be dealbreakers. 

Don't compromise on that.

Friends and colleagues,
Today is my last day at Elevance Health. After nearly 3 decades and through many chapters with the company, beginning with the formation of HealthCore in 1996, being acquired by WellPoint in 2003, running HealthCore as a subsidiary and finally leading Elevanceâ€™s Enterprise Analytics Core as their Chief Analytics Officer, I am officially retiring. Through all of these periods, what has held true has been our commitment to our mission to improve healthcare outcomes by providing richer insights to those who have to make critical decisions impacting the patient. 

We have accomplished much over the last 28 years, but nothing has been more impactful to me than those with whom I have shared this adventure, the two most prominent being my wife, Diana, and my business partner, Mark Cziraky, who has been with me from the outset.Â To him, and the rest of the tremendously talented team I leave behind, I hand the task of completing mission. 

There are so many that have shaped my thinking, my career and my life over that time period and to all of you I am so very grateful.

As we reflect on the first half of 2024, I couldnâ€™t be prouder of our employees and all they do. To have World Wide Technology recognized #19 by the Fortune Great Place To Work US and recognized in India, UK, Singapore, and Brazil is a true testament to our incredible employees and our culture transcending globally. During our Mid-Year Corporate Update, we celebrated our employees, our culture, community leadership awards and our award-winning intern program in its 25th anniversary. Our global supply chain operations had a record-breaking quarter, a testament to the dedication of our teams and their amazing performance supporting our customers around the globe. We highlighted best-in-class examples of employees across the business developing and deploying use cases for WWT AI tools in support of their day to day activities while improving customer experience. And we celebrated some of our latest successes in empowering customers with new insights, opportunities, and solutions using the WWT Advanced Technology Center (ATC) our Cyber Range and AI Proving Ground. These achievements are driven by our talented WWT teams and our exceptional partners! Matt Horner walked us through our strategic partnership with NVIDIA and the massive opportunity in front of us. We are proud and excited to be supporting our customers in their AI journeys and empowering them with increased productivity, enhanced data and insights, differentiation, and innovation. 

WWTâ€™s dedication to collaborative innovation and inclusivity is at the heart of our culture, and I am honored to be part of such a strong global team. Thank you to our customers, partners, and employees for being part of this extraordinary journey. Let's continue to make a new world happen, together! Sara Goellner Krista Bush Robert (Bob) Ferrell

Inspired by her own core values and gratitude for their service, Sarah Currie leads over 800 nurses and advanced practitioners working to fulfill the mission of St. Jude. 

Currie has spent her whole life helping the most vulnerable â€“ from fixing broken bird wings as a child to delivering and inspiring holistic bedside care for pediatric patients. After completing her training at the Kent School of Nursing, she found her purpose working in neonatal intensive care units (NICU) on both sides of the pond. 

â€œI have always thought of nursing as an art and a privilege. To meet patients where they are, and render aid and comfort to help them manage whatever life transition is ahead of them.â€ 

As Chief Nurse at St. Jude, Currie is responsible for setting and executing the vision for nursing care across clinical areas of the hospital. The lifetimes of experience collectively shared by her team members are driven by a philosophy of care defined by excellence, hope, passion, and dignity. 

â€œI cannot think of any other way I would rather spend my days than working with our wonderful team, pursuing the inspirational mission of St. Jude Childrenâ€™s Research Hospital.â€ 

Learn more about how Sarah Currie is inspiring and leading the next generation of nurses in the latest investigator Insights on St. Jude Progress.

There's something for employers of all sizes on WPXI's "Our Region's Business" this Sunday at 11 on Channel 11, going from global mergers to the smallest of small businesses in just 30 minutes.

Dave Burritt, president and CEO of United States Steel Corporation is back with us to make the case for the company's combination with Nippon Steel Corporation.  He says the deal is in the best interest of all stakeholders, including employees and the communities where it operates. 

Karen Riley, the relatively new president of Slippery Rock University of Pennsylvania, will be in studio to talk about Rock Teach, an initiative to recruit, mentor and provide financial support to encourage minority students to become teachers -- and the largest planned estate gift in university history that's made it possible.

We're off to Morris Organic Farm in Irwin, Westmoreland County, to learn about a new side gig, hosting campers, that's bringing extra revenue to farmers and small businesses across our region and the country. Harvest Hosts COO Wesley Clark explains how his membership service makes it possible. 

Sadik Roberts is batting cleanup.  He's co-owner ofÂ Pyramid PGH, a husband/wife digital marketing firm and one of six small businesses selected by the Pittsburgh Pirates and PNC to receive $100,000 of free marketing support as part of their ongoing "Going to Bat for Small Business" program.Â Sadik says Pyramid PGH emphasizes community to set his agency apart.

After Sunday's broadcast, we'll be taking the next four weeks off, preempted by NBC Sports for the Paris Olympics and other programming.  See you again August 18th.
#camping #farmtotable #steel #steelmaking #steelindustry #smallbusiness #marketing #advertising #education #teachers #dei #diversity

Leadership is such a tremendous responsibility because you have the influence to help someone become the very best version of themselves and, in the process, make a profound impact on their life.

Why would anyone take this for granted, especially when dealing with people?

Building confidence, mentoring, and coaching takes time and energy. Still, itâ€™s worth it, and if you can help somebody build their self-esteem and confidence, it will pay dividends for the person and the organization.

ð“ð¢ð«ðžð ð¨ðŸ ð›ðžð¢ð§ð  ðš ð¡ð®ð¦ðšð§ ð«ðžð©ð¨ð«ð­ ð ðžð§ðžð«ðšð­ð¨ð«? Ready to become a strategic advisor? Here's how...

In our recent posts, Brian Cariveau and I advocated for Business Intelligence staff to move towards becoming a strategic business advisor instead - but how do you start that journey? Here are some tips to get started:

ðŸ. ðð®ð¢ð¥ð ððžðžð© ðð¨ð¦ðšð¢ð§ ð¤ð§ð¨ð°ð¥ðžðð ðž ðŸ¤“: Know the business you serve and before you build your next report, be sure to know what questions it'll answer, and how knowing the answer can be tied to business value. 

ðŸ. ð‚ð¨ð¥ð¥ðšð›ð¨ð«ðšð­ðž ð°ð¢ð­ð¡ ð¬ð­ðšð¤ðžð¡ð¨ð¥ððžð«ð¬ ðŸ™: The job doesn't end when the dashboard is published - follow up regularly with users to find out if it's still useful and how it could be improved. (bonus: it's easier to improve than making an all-new dashboard later)

ðŸ‘. ðƒðžð¯ðžð¥ð¨ð© ðš ð©ð«ð¨ðšðœð­ð¢ð¯ðž ð¦ð¢ð§ðð¬ðžð­ ðŸ’¬: Armed with your domain knowledge and the conversations you've had with your stakeholders, you're in a much better position to anticipate questions/needs and can start proactively offering solutions. Be bold, it's not easy when you're used to working of a request-queue, but it's worth it. 

These simple steps are key because they shift your focus from simply fulfilling requests to actively shaping business outcomes. By understanding the business, collaborating with stakeholders, and developing a proactive mindset, you become an invaluable partner.

Yesterday I penned a post that encouraged others to bet on themselves.Â As I started my first cup of coffee this morning, I realized that there was another type of bet that could make a big impact on someoneâ€™s life.
 
Bet on someone you just met.
 
Very early in my engagement on LinkedIn I wrote about the talented people that are seeking new professional challenges.Â That post occurred during the annual March Madness basketball tournament, and I reminded people that a lot of championships have been won by players coming off the bench.
 
I want to encourage those of you with the power to hire someone to look beyond the basics. 
 
I assure you that someone who lost a job due to no fault of their own has learned lessons that will make them a more dedicated employee. 
 
I assure you that a parent who took a break to take care of a premature baby will be forever grateful that you saw that as a sign of the quality of their character. 
 
I assure you that someone who had a few jobs over a couple of years isnâ€™t damaged goods, but rather gained a lot of self-awareness. 
 
I assure you that a student who didnâ€™t complete their degree, may have made the best decision for themselves and would be ideal for an apprenticeship. 
 
I know there are exceptions to every one of these, but I also know the dignity that comes with being gainfully employed. 
 
All I ask is that you look below the surface and, when the opportunity presents itself, make a bet on someone you just met. 
 
Do it today (ok, itâ€™s the weekend, so do it on Monday).

In these weekly leadership messages, I try to personalize them with my own experiences and beliefs.â€¯ My dadâ€”who has been my life-long role model and heroâ€”passed away five years ago this week, so I am repeating the leadership message I sent on the day of his funeral.â€¯ I encourage you to take a few moments and reflect on the people who most influenced you and the person you are today.â€¯ â€¯Here is the message dated July 16, 2019:

It's been sad to see the vitriol and misinformation about the restoration work being done by CenterPoint Energy since Hurricane Beryl's landfall.  It's an effort that is more efficient and fast than any of our previous major event restorations, but you wouldn't know that from criticism being leveled at the Company.
Yes, as an employee engaged in the response, I'm biased towards the great work being done, but I'm also a customer and there is nothing I would love more than to have power at my home.  I'm tired, and tired of being drenched in sweat trying to sleep after these long days, but I know that our folks are working around the clock to make that happen. 

One particularly galling observation from the peanut gallery is about our crews supposedly "doing nothing."  There are several reasons crews may look to be inactive. They may be documenting their recently completed work and reporting on progress to help get restoration estimates to customers. They may be in cue waiting for a crew ahead to finish their work so they can continue the work in an efficient manner. (For example, waiting on a cut and clear team or veg crew to finish). Finally, safety is the number one priority in this business, and these workers are outside working 16-hour days in this weather and need to take breaks to rest and rehydrate to stay healthy and safe.  Our crews are always contributing to restoration efforts, and I hope you'll join me in appreciating the work they do.
We're thankful for the kind and uplifting messages we've received from our neighbors.

Intel D2 P1/P2 extreme energy efficient HPC datacenter running at 1.06 PUE with Disaggregated Intel Xeon Servers received the LEED Platinum certification

On July 1st, 2024, the latest D2 P1/P2 modules (42 MW) received Industry LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) highest certification rating of Platinum. Last year, the prior generation D2 P5/P6 received LEED Gold certification recognition.

D2 currently is hosting 400,000+ disaggregated servers (5+ Million Xeon high clock cores) enabling sub-server-module level upgrades at lowest cost and significantly reduced e-waste, 700+ Petabytes of scaled cluster high-performance storage, and 800,000+ extreme low latency network ports with its 78.5 MW operating power running at 1.06 PUE. D2 at its full build-out capacity of 117.5 MW will host more than 1,000,000 disaggregated Intel Xeon and AI Accelerator servers.

Worldâ€™s leading extreme energy efficient hyperscale D2 datacenter, operating at 1.06PUE, with its high-performance computing scale is efficiently and reliably enabling Intel IDM 2.0 strategic Intel Product and Intel Foundry execution.

column8:
â€œEmergency preparedness and management is a community effort. With the increase in severe weather conditions and our changing climate, it's even more important that we work together to grow our resilience.â€ In a new blog post, Alyssa Okamura, from our digital communications team, reflects on her experience at Hawaiian Electricâ€™s Wildfire Safety Symposium, held this past April in Hilo.

Wildfire safety experts from utilities, agencies, research institutes and the state were invited to this two-day technical symposium to focus on reducing Hawaiiâ€™s wildfire risk by sharing insights about collective actions to keep our communities safe and discussing immediate to long-term strategies for both safety and grid resilience. Panel discussions featured wildfire experts from around the world, with representatives from California, Australia, and Puerto Rico. Each of these organizations is at a different stage of wildfire safety planning and offered advice and insights from their own experiences.

Everyone was willing to share and learn from one another. The symposium was a space to collaborate and served as a platform for curiosity and clarification. When it comes to the safety of our customers and community, it was about uplifting each other so that everyone could keep their people safe.

â€œI also became more aware of how challenging the planning process for wildfire safety protocols and a Public Safety Power Shutoff (PSPS) program can be,â€ writes Alyssa. â€œEveryoneâ€Šâ€”â€Šresidents, businesses, emergency responders, water companies, telecommunications providers âˆ’ will be impacted and thatâ€™s why it is so important to work together to prepare.â€

Read the full blog at https://lnkd.in/g7EXcdKQ

View the Wildfire Safety Symposium presentation slides and event program, at https://lnkd.in/gUQ4-YpD.

Are you tracking opportunity cohorts?

User cohorts are default standard in product teams. 

Yet, opportunity cohorts seems to be seldom used in revenue analytics, or?

Ofc, cohorts came with their own challenges, but are a good way to compare how opportunities created each week develop over time.

You can slice and dice them by e.g.:
- Lead source
- Industry
- Segment
- Territory

If referred to win rates, it can help answer questions like:
1. Has my win rate gone down/ up over time?

2. Are there severe differences by lead source, industry, territory, segment?

3. What can we learn

As we all live in fast changing environments, it's sometimes hard to pinpoint what has driven the change.

BUT, knowing that there has been a change is a good starting point.

Curious what you think?

PS: I know you love cohorts Robert Gimbel

Iâ€™m happy to share that Iâ€™m starting a new position as Chief Marketing Officer at AMFM Healthcare!

AMFM Healthcare is an integrative residential treatment provider specializing in primary mental healthcare in California, Virginia, and Washington state. We firmly believe in the importance of clinical excellence as the foundation for effective mental healthcare.

AMFM Healthcare offers a range of mental health treatment options depending on age and an individual's treatment needs.

AMFM - 24 hour residential treatment care in one of our state-licensed homes run by licensed healthcare professionals. Each of our homes is designed to provide a calming, peaceful environment conducive to healing. In residential treatment our team works with each client to create a custom treatment plan. Our clinical team uses a variety of methods such as group and individual therapy as well as a wide range of activities that help our clients develop important coping skills they can use to help maintain their recovery.

Mission Prep - Mission Prep aims to provide support and sustainable change for adolescents and families who are challenged by primary mental health struggles. We firmly believe in treating the entire family system and allowing families to address the challenges of their children in a safe, sustainable way. At Mission Prep we are committed to preparing teens for the challenges of life and giving families the fresh start they need at our teen mental health treatment programs.

Mission Connection - Mission Connection is a compassion-driven, evidence-based, clinical program. By embracing the telehealth platform, we are able to offer virtual outpatient support to adults struggling with primary mental health diagnoses such as anxiety, depression, and mood disorders. We provide the same level of quality care as we do at our residential programs with our team of masters and doctorate-level clinicians developing custom treatment plans that cater to each clientâ€™s specific needs.

The Career Path, Reinvented

I read an article this morning and thought the premise makes so much sense.

In our early life we are constantly asked and ask ourselves what we want to do for a career.  Our parents, in too many cases, raced through their early-chosen career choices to retire as soon as possible to escape to what they â€œwanted to doâ€, only to find a lack of meaning still.

Today, we all realize, particularly the youngest of us, that career paths are more like career adventures, certain to twist and turn and occasionally find they lead to new paths. From a teacher to a coach, business person to minister, banker to artist, anything to entrepreneur.

And the cool thing is that no one really limits any of us to a single path.  We can have multiple paths.  And â€œretirementâ€ as a term should probably be retired, because today it so often means a new career path or two.

I know so many of you who are reading this have already made one or two or three career path changes or addition.  Most of the rest of you will make a change or addition, too. 

If youâ€™ve taken the road less travelled already, good luck on more of themâ€¦ if not youâ€™ll surely find yourself on an exciting new path one day.  And if you simply love what you do so much you wouldnâ€™t spend a moment on another path, then Iâ€™m sure you are reinventing what even that path is.

Exciting adventures aheadâ€¦

There are few things in life one can say with absolute certainty. 

I can say this with absolute certainty: The world is a lesser place without Geert Broos. 

In 1991 I embarked on a grand adventure, moving my young family to Morocco with Procter & Gamble.  My new boss was Geert.  Little did I know that beyond a boss, I would also gain a lifelong friend. And have the honour of knowing one of the most exceptional human beings ever. A person who truly embodied â€œA man for othersâ€. 

In 1992 I was touring the Sahara Desert with my family and brother Jerry Lafferty.  On a narrow road I had an accident, rolled the car 4x whilst my wife, sister-in-law, and daughters watched from the trailing vehicle in horror.  Everyone was injured but I was in a coma in the middle of the desert.  Who saved the day? Geert and his wife Ann Broos Delbrassine.  Geert dropped his whole life and boarded a plane to the closest city. He handled the police. Got me transferred to a hospital. Got the cars taken care of.  The next day he got us all airlifted back to Casablanca whilst he drove our one good car back. When we landed in Casablanca, Ann was waiting and got us to the hospital. 

Itâ€™s exceptional, but thatâ€™s who Geert and Ann Broos are. 

We went on to become lifelong friends and meeting up through the years.  This is all of us in a mini reunion in Casablanca in 2018. 

In the subsequent years I would occasionally find myself having to describe Geert to someone. We both were in Coca Cola together in the early 2010â€™s.  I can talk all night about the exceptional businessman Geert was, an amazing international career in both P&G and Coke.  I can share many stories of his exceptional athleticism, from running to squash to basketball.  I will let others talk about this. I want to focus on the man.  I would tell people this: 

â€œIf you take someone like me, you will find people who love me and people who hate me. I am polarising and I can be a real asshole. But Geert Broos? This is the finest man I have ever known, a person who gives himself and always puts others first.  If you donâ€™t love Geert Broos, quite frankly there is something wrong with you. Maybe some kind of brain damage perhapsâ€¦â€

The finest man I have known in my 61 years.  He is gone too soon after a courageous battle with cancer; and this world is a far lesser place without the perpetual smile and optimism of Geert Broos. 

Rest well my friend.  And thank you for being there for me.  I will be there for your family, whenever they need.

FRIENDS, We did it! In the largest GOP Primary (by # voters) that is not a statewide race in Utah, we just WON the nomination with 58%! 

Thank you to everyone who helped GOTV, who has volunteered, donated, and spread the good word of Team Rachelle! This was a statement Primary win. 

The work is not done â€” in Salt Lake Countywide races, unaffiliated voters determine the outcomes of races between the two parties. Team Rachelle is positioned well for the General, and with this being the largest open seat race in Utah that is a true Purple race, Iâ€™ll be continuing to campaign across SLCo all the way up through Election Day in November. 

It means the world to have support from my family, my business partners, my broader professional network, the Governor and many elected officials across the state of Utah, and many folks Iâ€™ve met along the campaign trail. 

Iâ€™ve knocked on 1000+ doors across SLCo in the past two months. I love getting to know people I would have never met had I not decided to run for office. The more people I get to know, the more Iâ€™m convinced that Iâ€™m lucky to call SLCo my home, and the more Iâ€™m convinced that the Salt Lake Valley has the potential of being The Best metropolitan area in the West over the next 10 years. It would be an honor to bring my talents and skills and approach to solving problems to the County Council. 

Weâ€™ll be in parades and doing lots of community-focused events this summer. If you want to get involved, weâ€™d love to have you! And if you want to be plugged into frequent updates of my campaign, follow along on my Instagram account at @rachellemorrisut or Twitter at @rachelle_morris.

And before I wrap, I want to give special thanks to my core campaign team of Jordan Hess and Michael Jolley. Those were the two men I wanted to run Team Rachelle with me this year, and I know I hit the jackpot with this team. 

Onward to the General this November!!

DriveU steadfastly focuses on generating predictable, living wages to tens of thousands of its driver partners. Our mantra has always been 'Without happy drivers, we don't have happy customers and consequently a prosperous business'. Towards that goal: 

(a) Payments - We pay drivers the very next business day for all trips they completed before mid-night the prior day (vs. industry norm is reconciliation and payments made once a week). 
(b) Transparency - They know, how much the customer has paid and they are guaranteed 80% of trip earnings. 
(c) Predictable income - The DriveU team works really hard to ensure sufficient demand for drivers to earn enough in a month. See chart below (as a compare, an average Indian engineer with less than 3 years of experience earns â‚¹ 40,000/month - so this is pretty, pretty good... especially since it doesn't include tips!)

Now you know one of the secrets behind our success. #DriveU #drivers #gigeconomy #capria

Allow me to be dramatic for a moment:

When youâ€™re transforming to a product-led organization, change management is futile without the necessary change leadership approach to drive the process.

Not sure if this applies to you? If you're in the midst of transformation and keep saying or hearing these phrases, you might have a change management vs change leadership power struggle on your hands:

â€œWe donâ€™t do change wellâ€

â€œWe canâ€™t handle much moreâ€

â€œOur employees are resistantâ€

â€œOur leaders are strugglingâ€

â€œWe need a better change management plan!â€

Summer Miller, Ed.D. and I helped a recent client through this exact conundrum and the "aha" moments were abound. 

If you want to learn more about how we diagnosed the issue and helped our client navigate it, check out today's article. 

It covers the difference between change leadership and change management, the benefits of a change leadership approach, and the necessary mindset shifts every leader needs to make in order to support a successful transformation toward product-led ways of working.

I'm thrilled to share the success of our recent Safety Summits, where we had an opportunity to train over 500 of our dedicated coworkers on a variety of crucial safety topics. ðŸŽ‰ 

Organizing and executing this event was no small feat. It required nimble planning across multiple venues, coordination among dozens of speakers and guests, and a tenacious commitment to excellence from our GOST team. Despite all the challenges we have faced, we have received great positive feedback, and the experience has been very rewarding.

As Substation Safety Lead, I had the honor of training over 125 colleagues on the importance of safety culture and the hierarchy of controls, with the help of James Hopkins, EIT. Seeing the engagement and enthusiasm from participants has reaffirmed the value of these initiatives.

We were especially fortunate to have senior-level directs and vice presidents join us, engaging us and our audience. Joe Bentley's & Raj Beasla, MBA presence and support underscored the importance of safety at every level of our organization.

The training event has not only enhanced our knowledge and skills but has also had a significant positive impact on our company safety culture and engagement. The collective effort and dedication of everyone involved has strengthened our commitment to creating a safety workplace for all.

A huge thanks to all who participated, contributed and volunteered to making this event a success. There are many names that I want to mention, but I cannot possibly fit them all into this post! But here are some special thanks to Sujean Wu, P.E., S.E., PMP Shahneam Reza, PE Jose Jiminez Jr, Nick Johnson Samantha Estrella Brit Gage Safwa Ali James Hopkins, EIT John Villalpando Khalid Tarar Josue Martinez, PE, PMP, Lean-6Ïƒ Jairo Ballesteros

Together, we are owners of our safety culture and are making a difference! ðŸ’ª

Some great news â€” Enel North America has won Best Solar Ecosystem at the North American Agrivoltaics Awards! Huge congrats to our Atwater and Eastwood solar siteÂ teamsÂ at our Aurora solar farm.
 
These Minnesota sites are truly special. They've hosted a 5-year agrivoltaics field study by the DOE's Argonne National Laboratory and the National Renewable Energy Laboratory with support from MNL. We saw some incredible results: 3x increase in insect abundance, 20x increase in native bee populations and an uptick in plant diversity. 
 
Enel pioneered some of the first â€œecovoltaicsâ€ practices at Aurora several years ago. Today, weâ€™re honored to have set a new benchmark for the integration of solar power and ecosystem services. 

Renewables and sustainable land use arenâ€™t mutually exclusive â€”Â we can say that with confidence.Â ðŸ

Let me show you what happens if your team lacks Clinical DNA when building Digital Health solutions:

â†’ Clinicians expected to use the tech far more than they actually could 

(e.g. for remote monitoring, assuming providers both want and are able to monitor every single data point recorded by a patient)

â†’ Prioritizing shiny tech instead of providing a real solution that fits the clinical workflow 

(e.g. providing AI predictive insights that no clinician uses because thereâ€™s no existing workflow where it makes sense to use the insight)

â†’ Disruption of day to day clinical workflows that will lead to low user adoption 

(e.g. assuming frontline staff have endless hours to manually enter data into your system)

â†’ Providing a â€œshell productâ€ where clinicians must spend hundreds of hours creating clinical content from scratch for each surgery, health condition, etc.

â†’ Patient education is at too high of a reading level.

*****

What would you add?

#digitalhealth #healthcareinnovation

"Everyone has a plan until they get punched in the mouth" - Mike Tyson

A 58 year old heathy man was seen at Lake Men's Health clinic for a routine annual physical exam. His lab tests were perfectly normal. Specifically he had a normal cholesterol level of 188 with an LDL of 120. 

His family history was significant in that his father suffered a heart attack at age 62.

He related to us that he had been living a healthy lifestyle, eating very little red meat, watching his carb intake, and working out 5 days per week in a Cross Fit Gym. His body fat was below 10%. 

His plan was to never suffer the heart problems that his father did.

Because of his family history of premature coronary artery disease, we recommended he undergo a coronary artery calcium test. This simple 12 minute CT scan identifies the presence or absence of coronary artery plaque by identifying coronary artery calcium. 

As a reminder, a "normal" coronary artery calcium level is "0." A score of 100 indicates minimal plaque. A score of 400 indicates the presence of severe coronary artery plaque.

Our patient's coronary artery calcium score was 914 (see below), with the majority of his plaque in the Left Anterior Descending coronary artery (widow-maker lesion) and in the Right Coronary artery.

He was promptly referred to a cardiologist. Fortunately his stress test was negative. He is currently on aggressive medical treatment and will be monitored closely by his cardiologist for any progression of his disease.

â€¢ Julio Melara Pete Bush, CFPÂ® Michael Hackett James Craven Richard Pellerin Chrislyn Miller Maher Camryn Curtis McCarter, MBA

column8:
This month I've left my 375,000 person global firm as a owner/partner and don't plan on going back to that type of big corporate job again. It has been so rewarding to work with incredibly talented colleagues and clients and it was also all-consuming, hard work. Having now aged out of our partnership terms It feels like gaining new freedom. It's like I stepped out of one door, closed it behind me, and 1,000 more re-opened: serving on boards, working with startups, recording music, producing a documentary, speaking gigs, sailing, time with my wife to hang out and enjoy life. I've already started teaching at the University of Southern California's Iovine and Young Academy (innovation school) and who knows, maybe another book following "Big Ideas" will be in the works at some point too. 

I've had the amazing opportunity to get to know Chip Conley and the MEA team over the las 2-3 years. He was founder and CEO of a chain of hotels that he sold to a larger company and then joined AirBnB early as a "wisdom worker" to extend beyond a rental listing website to a hospitality and lifestyle brand. Now he has founded MEA Wisdom to empower others in making the shift from the full-time corporate grind into the freedom of a whole life. I'm so grateful for MEA and Chip's team for showing the path. 

As a kid I remember watching the movie "Trading Places" and at the end, the vision for freedom and the good life was captured between Eddie Murphy's and Dan Aykroyd's characters. As one goes sailing by on a boat and the other is on the beach, they toast each other...
"Looking good, Billy Ray!" 
"Feeling good, Louis!" 

Here's an article I guest published with Chip that goes a bit deeper on making the shift and feeling good! 
https://lnkd.in/gMP3Hrms

#chipconley #meawisdom #ey #IYA #usciya

PFAS, also known as per-and polyfluoroalkyl substances, are a class of chemicals used in various industrial applications, including the fluorination process. Recent studies have found that the fluorination process used during the manufacturing of certain types of plastic bottles can lead to the formation of PFAS. 

Graham offers a suite of different technical solutions that can help achieve the same barrier properties as fluorination without the use of harmful PFAS chemicals. Contact sales@grahampackaging.com to learn how Graham can provide solutions to help protect your product and the environment.
