Remember to raise your hand for opportunities, ask questions early and often, and know that you can, and should, love your job. #CenteneIntern

This week, I had the pleasure of flying out to St. Louis, Missouri to attend the inaugural Intern Summit at Centene Corporation! After a month of remote work, it was refreshing to connect face to face with fellow interns and executives from across the company, especially having the privilege of hearing from top executives Sarah M. London, Tanya McNally, Brian LeClaire, Shannon Thornton Susko, Susan Smith, and Alice Hm Chen. 

During the summit, I had the opportunity to engage with members under the Business Technology Solutions team, including a memorable conversation with CIO Brian LeClaire. We discussed new AI technologies and how we can leverage them for UX design processes at Centene. I also gained invaluable skills in overall professional development, furthering my growth. I look forward to applying the insights Iâ€™ve gained and fostering these new connections as I continue to grow my career. 

Special thank you to the entire university relations team for making this happen! I am extremely proud to work for a company that cares this deeply about our success. #OneCenTeam #CenteneIntern

Mayor Brandon Johnsonâ€™s department leadership choices are commendable, with a historic increase in African-American women appointments. One standout is Commissioner Marlene Hopkins, a pillar of dedication and efficiency. 

Having called on Marlene several timeâ€™s during my time with the Alderman, her reputation preceded her as the go-to person for building-related matters. Her unwavering commitment and hands-on approach to ward issues are unparalleled. With over 25 years in City Government, predominantly in leadership roles, Marlene's impact is undeniable. 

Noteworthy is her academic achievements, earning two degrees while reshaping the City's building codes. Marlene's talent and accomplishments are truly awe-inspiring. Chicago is fortunate to have Commissioner Hopkins at the helm, ensuring a brighter future for our city. 

#Leadership #CityGovernment #Dedication #Chicago #CommissionerHopkins Chicago Department of Buildings #Someoneyoushouldknow

Driven by the mission of advancing cures for pediatric catastrophic diseases, St. Jude Childrenâ€™s Research Hospital unites the brightest minds in science and medicine with world-class resources. The knowledge generated by the groundbreaking research at St. Jude is translated directly into clinical progress, improving outcomes for patients. 

The annual scientific reportâ€”Translating Science Into Survivalâ€”spotlights key breakthroughs from the last year highlighted by work that accelerates scientific discovery. We dive deep into four features: using CRISPR gene editing, understanding and preventing infectious diseases, how protein structure guides therapeutics, and the molecular make up of brain tumors. 

â€œIn our 62-year history, we have made tremendous progress in curing the incurable, treating the untreatable, decreasing the side effects of therapy, and accelerating the adoption of diagnostic and therapeutic approaches globally to improve cure rates,â€ said James R. Downing, MD, President and CEO. â€œThe work described in the Scientific Report underscores the unique scientific culture at St. Jude and illustrates how it drives our faculty and staff to tackle the most challenging problems and answer the most complex questions.â€ 

To learn about the ways St. Jude continues to change the future of research and treatment, read the 2024 Scientific Report. https://ow.ly/Bhrg50SHrCR

Update from the field: While power was restored for our residential customers by the end of last week, some of our equipment serving industrial customers near Channahon sustained more significant damage.

Our hardworking crews have continued to work around the clock for an entire week to restore these customers that were impacted by the 100+ mph winds that ripped through our service territory last Monday evening, and we're happy to share that we expect power to be restored early tomorrow morning.

INCREDIBLE effort on this removal and restoration plans.  Itâ€™s an honor to be part of such a talented, dedicated team. 16 heavy duty dozers to hold that tension!  I have a new appreciation for Transmission Line design.

â€œEver since I was a young boy, I've played the silver ball" - The Who 
 
Those who know me know one of my hobbies is pinball. I love the combination of mechanical and electrical, physical and digital, artistry and engineering, strategy and chaos. As an arcade junkie growing up in the 80â€™s, pinball had two advantages to my second love of video games.

1) No matter how good you were, luck and physics made every game unique.Â You could master the patterns of Donkey Kong or Ms. Pac Man (or: later, Street Fighter IIâ€¦which spurred my short lived career hustling quarters across the greater Cincinnati area in high school).Â But a game with a steel ball moving 90 mph smashing into physical targets presented a MUCH higher bar for greatness.

2) If you played well enough, youâ€™d get rewarded with free games. It was easy calculus: a little bit of skill would let my one dollar allowance stretch a ton further.

I bought my first machine in 2000 (The Whoâ€™s Tommy!), but actively tried to keep anyone at work from finding out.Â At the time, being a deep technologist (OK, geek) wasnâ€™t exactly endearing to corporate America. I was busy buying cuff links and Franklin Planners trying to show that I had â€œbusiness chopsâ€.Â But it didnâ€™t take long to realize that my authentic self was not just tolerated, but celebrated.Â And making time to nurture and tinker with your hobbies outside of work is essential to cultivating your own well-being.
 
That same original pinball machine is in my home office (along with some friends); depending on how I position my camera, itâ€™s visible during video conferences with clients, teammates, and the media.Â Proudly on display and something I love showing off.Â During an interview last month, it caught Billy Hurleyâ€™s eye while we were talking about Technical Debt. 
 
Which launched a follow-up piece with IT Brew focused on multimeters, solenoids, and how years of fixing up and troubleshooting my collection of pinball machines relates to my day job.Â Call it â€˜Zen and the art of pinball maintenanceâ€™ - with some corollaries to rolling up sleeves to harness emerging tech. 
 
â€œBriggs provides the realistic vision for companies considering quantum computing, industrial metaverse, and advanced physical roboticsâ€”technologies that have barely arrived long enough to be broken and troubleshooted. But he doesnâ€™t really have to take apart machinery these daysâ€”professionally, at least.â€ 
 
Grateful to Billy and the team at Morning Brew for so accurately capturing my love for pinball machines, extensive metaphors, and spot-on pop culture references. ðŸ˜‰
 
You can read our full interview for yourself here: https://deloi.tt/3VAkQrJ

Iâ€™m excited to announce that I will be taking on the role of Global Leader of McKinseyâ€™s Insurance Practice, in partnership with my colleague and friend JÃ¶rg Musshoff.
 
Many of my clients and colleagues whoâ€™ve known me for years know that the Insurance Practice has been a home for me since the very early days of my career at McKinsey.Â Iâ€™ve had the privilege to serve carriers in every major region, across the Life, P&C, Brokerage, Reinsurance, Private Equity/Private Capital industries.Â And Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of serving established corporates as well as insurtech disruptors.
 
The industry is going through an unprecedented period of change and is at a true inflection point, spurred by shifting customer expectations, a changing risk landscape (including the effects of climate change), the arrival of GenAI, a shifting macroeconomic (and interest rate) environment, and geopolitical factors affecting multinational players and their clients. 

All of this creates significant risk and opportunity for players in every part of the industry, and I am excited to partner with the entire Insurance practice, full of amazing leaders, to help our clients and the industry meet the moment.
 
I also have so much gratitude for the full #LeapbyMcKinsey team for an amazing ride over the past 5 years.Â Together, we helpedÂ build over 600 new businesses with our clients across industries, including 20 â€œunicornsâ€ and two â€œdecacornsâ€ â€“ and last year alone, we helped generate over $140 billion in value and more than 20,000 jobs.Â I have no doubt the Leap team will scale to new heights in the coming years.Â Special thanks to my co-leaders in Paul Jenkins and before that Ralf Dreischmeier.

Speed with which this thing has evolved in last 24 hours is just amazing. Somebody has lit the fire under democrats. Kamala Harris has become shoo-in candidate; public having spoken with $81 millions contribution in 24 hours!

Kamala's first speech in Delaware where she went to take charge of the campaign machinery was articulate and forceful. She went for DJT's jugular, calling him a convicted rapist.

Republicans have been caught flat-footed. Republican conference in Milwaukee seems like it was eons ago. JD Vance speech in his hometown rally was silly, calling Kamala an enabler of Biden's wasted three years. 

It seems that Democrats are going to fight this election on two fronts, touting their achievements (Obama care, Chips Act,  Infra-structure  Bill and Inflation Reduction act, 15 million jobs, Re-energized NATO)and calling out DJT's shenanigans. Age shoe is on the other foot now. DJT is the oldest candidate ever to run. He will be compared against a vibrant Kamala rather than senile Joe.

105 days and counting till election day!

I get asked this all the time, â€œwhat do you miss most about the militaryâ€? 

The answer is simpleâ€¦

[CAMARADARIE] 

A group of individualsâ€”most from wildly different backgroundsâ€”working together to achieve a common goal. 

Under extreme conditions,

And insurmountable odds,

Integrating AI models can improve productivity. But for a significant impact, it's essential to integrate your company's data. The real breakthroughs happen when you combine 1st and 3rd party data, both structured and unstructured.

This transforms off the shelf AI into an assistant that feels tailored to your business needs. 

Everyone wants ChatGPT to:
-Speak like their business
-Understand their specific vocabulary
-Reflect their unique style and tone
-Incorporate CRM and other 1st party data

With a smart data strategy you can make this happen.

I discussed this and much more with Ben Salzman and Millie Beetham on the ZoomInfo Labs Podcast. Check out the clip below, and Iâ€™ll include a link to the full episode in the comments.

Another cookie curve ball from Google, but to quote the Marketecture Media pod, the changes weâ€™ll see are likely just â€œcookie deprecation by another method.â€ Here's our take on why it's business-as-usual:

- Google has said they are now putting the choice to opt-out in the hands of consumers, potentially something similar to Apple's ATT framework. If thatâ€™s the case, weâ€™ll see 70-80% of consumers opt out of cross-site tracking.

- This will mean cookies can no longer be the primary mode of tracking, and user identification will continue to shift in favor of first-party identifiers like HEMs.

- The pressing need for permissioned, first-party purchase data does not change, and still crucial for optimizing and measuring real business outcomes. 

- Giving consumers choice in how and when they share their data, as proven by Google's decision, is the future of the industry.

column8:
You get to the finish line with a great team. I'm enormously proud of and grateful to the technology team at Intermountain Health for all their accomplishments in the last few years to improve care for patients and enhance the efficiency and experience for our caregivers. It's not easy work, but it's been vital work.

Being the Chief Digital & Information Officer at both SCL Health and then Intermountain Health has been a great privilege and honor. I want to reflect on some of what the team has accomplished over the last few years:

- Consolidating 9 EMRs to one with Epic

- Achieved a 10 Gold Star Rating on ourÂ current Epic platform ranking in the top 3% in the nation

- Moving from multiple ERP systems to one with Workday

-Â Standardizing to a single contact center tech stack with Salesforce, Genesys, and Hyro

- Combined multiple ServiceNow environments to a single instance

- Deployed digital assets to improve patient access and experience with Kyruus Health and Zocdoc

- Transitioned multiple Microsoft and Google cloud environments to one with Microsoft Azure 

- Deployed Qualtrics to the enterprise for patient, caregiver and provider engagement

- Initiated dozens of AI initiatives including ambient listening, virtual nursing and other digital assistants

- And more...

When I consider all that hasÂ been accomplished, it is the right time to find the next challenge,Â a new starting line. It's always sad to leave one place, but the team at Intermountain Health is top notch and I'm so grateful to have served.

TheseÂ are exciting times for all of us in healthcare IT. I want to thank the many partners who work in this space that are so valuable to the successes we've had but mostly to the people, the caregivers who commit and contribute to the mission each and every day.

I quit my dream job of designing rocket engines exactly one year ago, and what an incredible year it's been.

It wasn't an easy decision - at Relativity Space I was helping architect one of the largest privately-developed rocket engines ever to challenge SpaceX's dominance of the industry. But I've always had an even bigger ambition of helping build a city on Mars, and had been realizing for several years that transportation was just one small piece of the puzzle.

It's now been one year since I co-founded Cosmic Robotics. We build autonomous solar farm construction robots that radically accelerate the installation of renewable energy to the grid. With current labor shortages in construction, this is a critical technology necessary for meeting the US target of installing 600 million more solar panels by 2030. 

But we won't stop at just accelerating Earth's transition to renewable energy - our long-term vision is to make sustainable life multiplanetary and to autonomously build cities on both Earth and Mars.

Diving into entrepreneurship, not to also mention an entirely new industry, several new fields of engineering, and moving to a new city has made the last year incredibly challenging. But these audacious missions keep me excited for every day and keep me pushing the boundaries of what I thought I could do - here's to many more years of building the future!

In coordination with the National Security Council, The White House the AHA initiated a partnership with Microsoft to develop a suite of free and heavily discounted, (non-profit pricing) Microsoft cybersecurity services for rural hospitals.  The AHA developed this creative partnership to help fill the resource gap for hospitals in most need - and where long distances between emergency departments creates the greatest risk to patients during hospital ransomware attacks.

A hugely important commitment to the openness of Meta's AI ecosystem by Mark Zuckerberg: "Open Source AI Is the Path Forward "
Llama 3.1 is free, open, and on par with the best proprietary systems.
To maximize performance, safety, customizability, and efficiency, AI platforms must be open, just like the software infrastructure of the Internet became open.
- Open Source AI is good for developers: fine-tuning, distillation, safety, efficiency, privacy, flexibility, portability, affordability, and a large ecosystem of contributors.
- Open source AI is good for Meta: the larger the community, the faster the progress.
- Open source AI is good for the world: enables more diversity in languages, cultures, value systems, and centers of interest in AI assistants. Enables a wider access with less concentrated control.

The question leaders are asking regarding AI has evolved from â€œifâ€ (the answer is YES), to â€œwhenâ€ (the answer is NOW), to â€œhowâ€. To gain context and provide some practical tips on how to advance the AI transformation, ServiceNow teamed up with Oxford Economics to develop our first annual Enterprise AI Maturity Index study: https://lnkd.in/dS4NjHhe

We surveyed ~4,500 executives along five dimensions: AI Maturity, Strategy, Talent, Governance, and Investments. My biggest takeaway, the pacesetters are doing things a bit differently:
â—¾ 62% of pacesetters have robust ROI measures in place vs. 28% of others
â—¾ 64% of pacesetters have top-down C-suite involvement vs. 34% of others
â—¾ 61% of pacesetters have the right AI skills in place vs. 30% of others

We all know that getting AI right and transforming at pace are critical to our organizations. The full report has several valuable insights and observations on what AI leaders are doing to get ahead: https://lnkd.in/dSkmaMDq

What began as jotting down a LinkedIn post with a few key takeaways from nearly two weeks in India slowly morphed into multiple paragraphs of appreciation, engagement highlights, and a call to action.

Thanks to the #USSpeakerProgram, this past month I had the opportunity to travel to Chennai, Kolkata, and New Delhi with the guidance and support of team members across these cities' US Consulates or US Embassy offices, including their respective American Center hubs. The US Speaker Program graciously invited me to share my experiences working on topics ranging from #TransportationElectrification, #CleanEnergyTransition, #BatteryCircularity, #SupplyChainSustainability, #Equity, and #WomenInSTEAM.

Read more in the article to see where I went, ask me any questions about my reflections, reach out for any requests to connect with the incredible contacts and friends I've made, refer someone you know my way if I can help them explore a career in STEAM, and, finally, consider your role in this time of transition. What is one thing you commit to do to convert your concern, motivation, or restlessness into a positive impact?

The list of names of every individual or organization across multiple continents who supported me on this trip is inordinately long, so I'll make sure to start by acknowledging and thanking Peggy Pope and the entire US Speaker Program team, including Madhuri S., Brindha Jayakanth, ANUTOSH BISWAS, Sucharita Bhattacharjee, Juan Clar, Neetu, and Kashish Sethi from the U.S. Department of State, the host institutions and organizations I note in my article, and Kayla Gibbs and other team members from the Michigan Public Service Commission who did an excellent job researching, deriving insights, and designing materials to communicate core messaging for ten days' worth of dialogs, presentations, and relationship building.

Since 2023, our Southern California Edison (SCE) Inspections organization has been intentional in our collaboration with our IOU peers Pacific Gas and Electric Company and San Diego Gas & Electric. We understand that the challenges we are facing as well as the opportunities and solutions we are developing are not specifically unique to each individual company and that we are stronger together. By coming together, we can better support our common mission of providing safe and reliable electricity to our customers and the State of California. Our group focus areas include: (1) Â Accelerate speed to value â€“ share best practices and avoid hurdles others have already crossed to create tangible results on shorter timelines that are more cost effective and drive higher quality; and (2) Present a unified front to support our regulators â€“ by coordinating our efforts and making holistic data-driven recommendations to the CPUC we enable the best opportunities to improve our operating environments for our customers.

On July 8th and 9th, we had the pleasure of hosting our IOU partners for workshops. We used to the workshops to: (1) understand the status at each IOU relating to inspections (2) focus on priority shared initiatives; and (3) solidified and enhanced working relationships to enable us to move faster and smarter. Albert Ma Kristi Gardner Matt Peacore Zining Yang, PhD Ephraim Maniago Raymond Fugere Andrew Abranches Klavdianos John Rusty Vance.

On July 19th, myself and Russell Ragsdale, made a focused trip up to PG&Eâ€™s innovative Dublin office space to learn more about PG&Eâ€™s successful initiatives around: (1) Reinventing inspections, (2) comprehensive pole inspection program, and (3) mega bundling of M&C work to enable us to understand how to incorporate best practices at SCE that can enable safety, quality, and affordability breakthroughs. 

The inspections teams across the IOUs are committed to continue investing in this collaboration and harnessing the resulting value. Thank you to my partners Jason Regan at PG&E, Joshua Fredriksson at PG&E and Jennifer Kaminsky at SDG&E for partnering with us and co-investing with us. Also, thank you to Mathew Rommel and the R&A Consulting LLC team for recommending, shaping, and facilitating these interactions.
Weâ€™ve had some wins, but we know there is much more work to do, letâ€™s keep driving!

One of the greatest mistakes of my investing career was passing on investing in Uber in the angel round twice.

I was literally in the room when Uber was invented. 

And yet I still passed on investing in the angel round ...

....Twice. 

And part of the reason I invested in the next round was because my brother AJ took the first Uber ride in New York City when the founder of Uber came and asked us to test it.

And that was the moment I realized, Uber doesn't sell transportation,.. 

Uber sells us time.

The reason all this infrastructure matters in an app environment is because it's just seamless, there's less friction.

The number one emerging thing in society in value is time... 

people value time over everything.. 

which is why convenience and lack of friction win.

column8:
Our Mars Petcare business began in Europe in 1935 and we have deep routes across the continent serving pets and pet parents for almost 90 years. Our European Supply Chain serves as a critical backbone for the region, consistently producing healthy, nutritious food and treats for pets while constantly striving to be more sustainable, efficient, and agile.
 
Over the past few weeks, I had the privilege of visiting our factories in both Birstall, UK as well as Bokros, Hungary. And while they may be hundreds of miles apart, their shared commitment to taking care of our Associates, pets, pet parents and the planet was unmistakable.
 
During all my factory visits we spend time reviewing our progress on building Smart Factories of the future across our network as part of our focus on becoming a digital first organization. I particularly enjoyed meeting SPOT, a clever autonomous robot, during my recent visit to Birstall. SPOT showed off some of its skills and is working closely with our Associates to spot potential issues and improvements earlier than previously possible, significantly improving efficiency in our factory.
 
Thank you to our Supply Chain Associates across the world for all you do to bring quality and innovation to life each day! 

#abetterworldforpets 
#proudlyMarsPetcare

column8:
Thanks to CrowdStrike and Delta Air Lines, I'm in Minneapolis for an unplanned three-day stopover, and mad at the CIO-industrial complex.

What has happened is that across the 1990s and 2000s, all the businesses that had no particular interest in computers were forced to computerize anyway.  Most of the time, CEOs were uncomfortable with computers and got no value out of the transition, just another cost center to pay.  They took someone that was hanging around the C suite and gave him the title of CIO.

Now you have somebody that is uncomfortable around computers, running a cost center.  The only measure of his importance is the size of the budget, and the only way to get any positive attention is to cut the budget.  (If you don't know how to make the spreadsheet bigger every year while "cutting costs" all along, you are not executive material, sorry.)  These CIOs are never going to build anything that matters to the business, because they have none of that talent working for them, and can't hire any.

What they do is write giant checks to a handful of vendors that the entire CIO herd uses.  The vendors have massive sales teams that are dedicated to pandering to the CIOs, so the CIO will spend most of the year golfing and watching NFL games from Cisco or Microsoft skyboxes.  This works great and everyone is happy and content.  There are CIO conferences, CIO magazines, CIO podcasts, and CIO awards ceremonies that all sustain and perpetuate this culture.

Unfortunately now it's 2024 and these CIOs run hollow "IT" organizations that are completely dependent on vendor support contracts.  There is no adaptability or resilience because there is no skill or capacity in-house.  Also, those clunky, overpriced vendor products that were nice-to-have in 1999 are now business-critical.  Now, a vendor screwup will bring your whole house down.

Tens of thousands of businesses have all done the same thing, so we have a monoculture where one screwup at one vendor can cripple a meaningful fraction of the economy.

That's why after 4 days, Delta still can't reboot its Windows computers and can't fly planes.

It is great to celebrate the incredible accomplishments highlighted by the Mars 2023 Sustainable in a Generation Report! This report is a testament to our commitment to delivering strong financial performance while continuing to invest in our sustainability initiatives. Running a successful business topping the $50+ billion mark for the first time in 2023, means we have the capacity to invest in impactful initiatives making our business more sustainable. Over the past eight years, we have grown our business 60% and reduced our greenhouse gas emissions by 16%. 

I am proud to say that we have committed $2.7 billion over three years to accelerate our journey to Net Zero. Â A good example of how we are doing this, is our investment in logistics efficiency by reducing travel distances while maximizing vehicle utilization. Our state-of-the-art London Thames Gateway facility is a result of a $400 million investment from MARS UK and DHL. Equipped with 3,700 solar panels, it generates 27% of its power needs and is among the top 1% of environmentally friendly non-domestic buildings in the UK. 
 
These accomplishments represent our commitment to sustainability and creating positive impacts on our planet and communities. Together we can drive change for a better future.

I encourage you to explore more Mars initiatives through our Sustainable in a Generation Report. 

https://lnkd.in/dpACwtQW

#SustainableInvesting #MARS #ProudlyMars

As we celebrate Purpose Month at Zoetis, I am reminded of the values instilled in me from a young age. Growing up in Morocco, my father always told me to "be a good Moroccan ambassador wherever you are." This principle has guided me throughout my life and career, and it resonates deeply with our mission at Zoetis.
From the time I was a little girl, I believed in being good and doing good in the world. This belief is more than a personal mantra but a professional commitment that I see reflected in everything we do at Zoetis. This month, we celebrate our commitment to nurturing the world and humankind by advancing care for animals. 
One of the many ways we live our purpose is through community engagements. Recently, our Zoetis Tech & Digital (ZTD) team participated in a dog toy-building event as part of our ongoing partnership with American Humane. Last month, our US Pet Care team partnered with American Humane to match $50,000 in contributions to support Pet Preparedness Month, helping animals in need during natural disasters. These events are a testament to our commitment to making a positive impact beyond our immediate work environment. They highlight the importance of collaboration and the joy of giving back to our communities.
I am proud to be part of a team that shares this dedication to purpose. Together, we strive to make a difference, guided by the values that have shaped us. Here's to continuing our journey of being good and doing good, every day! 
How are you living your purpose?
#PurposeMonth #Zoetisproud #CommunityEngagement #LivingOurPurpose #americanhumane
